item.title: Exelixis Q2 Earnings- Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Exelixis's top organisational priority continues to be the COMET trials with cabozantinib for CRPC. Good progress continues to be made, with expected top-line data in 2014. Meanwhile, the commercialized form of this drug for medullary thyroid cancer (COMTRIQ) registered sales of $4m in the quarter.
COMTRIQ Progress Update
Exelixis calims to be continuing to see gains and improved market penetration of the MTC market and reiterated its assumptions about the size of the market in the US (500-700 drug eligible fist and second-line metatstatic patients diagnosed each year with MTC.
Exelixis has expanded the size of its sales force from 5 to 15 due to a realisztion that the market is less concentrated than previously anticipated.The sales force continues to be outsourced through a contract sales organisation.
In Europe. Exelixis partner SOBI is waiting for a final oprinion from the CHMP.
COMET Trials In Post Chemo CRPC

Earlier CRPC Treatment Studies

Exelixis is also actively working on advancing cabozantinib in the earlier line of treatment of CRPC patients prior to chemotherapy. It is on track to initiate two earlier line Phase I/II studies, one evaluating the combination of cabozantinib with enzalutamide and one evaluating the combination of cabozantinib with abiraterone towards the end of 2013 or early 2014.

Other PhIII Indications

Exelixis claims to be working very actively on the initiation and execution of two new Phase III pivotal trials in metastatic renal cell cancer and hepatocellular cancer.The Phase III study in RCC was initiated in May 2013 and is now screening patients. It is a 650-patient randomized open label study that is comparing cabozantinib with everolimus in patients who have received and progressed on or following at least one prior VEGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
The HCC trial will be initiated shortly. It is a 760 patient study in patients who have received prior sorafenib and will compare overall survival between patients treated with cabozantinib and those receiving placebo

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: TPG Is Exploring The Sale of Specialty Drugmaker Aptalis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A Reuters exclusive is suggesting that Aptalis is up for sale with a price-tag of $3bn.
Venture capital company TPG Capital LP has owned Aptalis since 2008 and is apparently working with JP Morgan Chase and Evercore Partners on the sale of the business.
Nature of Buyer Interest
The report suggests that a number of potential buyers have reviewed the business and consider the asking price of more than $3bn yoo high. These include Sun Pharmaceuticals and Salix. Both are reported to be no longer pursuing the deal. Elan and Forest seemingly also reviewed the business earlier in the year and bowed out for different reasons.
Alternatives To A Sale
It is suggested that TPG may yet consider other options such as an IPO or a dividend recapitalisation should a deal fail to materialise.
Company History
TPG Bought the drugmaker formerly known as Axcan Pharma for $1.3bn in 2008 and merged it with Eurand Pharmaceuticals in 2011. The combined company was renamed Aptalis.

item.title: EU Regulatory Changes On The Horizon For Generic Products
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Companies planning generic product submissions in the EU are to have new guidance on how to demonstrate the bioequivalence of specific active substances by the end of this year
The EMA already has a general bioequivalence (BE) guideline in place that explains the requirements for demonstrating bioequivalence for generic products but the new guidance will make the assessment more transparent and predictable.
The EMA also said that a more consistent approach to assessing applications based on bioequivalence data is now needed across all submission routes — centralised, decentralised, mutual recognition and national.
The first set of guidance (on oral immediate-release forms) is expected to be released for public consultation following the October CHMP meeting. Individual products will then be selected by the network of regulatory agencies based on the need for guidance.
The guidance will be based on the previous regulations and will further cover:
  • BE study design elements
  • ie, the main pharmacokinetic variables and width of confidence intervals.
  • Whether in vivo BE studies can be waived for that substance under the Biopharmaceutics Classification System-based biowaiver approach
  • ie, where an assumption of in vivo equivalence can be made based on in vitro data

item.title: Small Molecule Progress For OncoTherapy As MELK Inhibitor Moves Into Clinic
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: OncoTherapy Science has initiated a clinical program for its first small molecule drug candidate, OTS167. Its' use is being investigated in patients with refractory locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors unresponsive to standard therapies. Enrolment in the US Phase I trial has begun.
The intravenously infused MELK (maternal embryonic leucine zipper kinase) inhibitor is part of the Snf1/AMPK kinase family and is not expressed in normal cells, rather it is up-regulated in various cancer types and involved in cancer cell cycle, growth and apoptosis processes.
Preclinical studies with OTS167 have shown potent activity in models of lung, breast, prostate and pancreatic cancers. The company however is not alone in the field - the Canadian firm Lorus Therapeutics, MELK inhibitor program (LOR-500) is in the preclinical stage with breast cancer and malignant glioma as potential indications.
In addition, OTS has recently decided to pursue the clinical development of other small molecule candidates against another unidentified novel kinase target, isolated through genomic expression profiling techniques. The lead molecule in the series, OTS964, has potential against lung and bladder cancer.
In the peptide vaccines area, OTS has licensing deals for various pipeline projects with Otsuka and Shionogi.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Afinitor in Advanced HCC Did Not Meet Primary Endpoint of OS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Another one bites the dust in the ever-increasing line of set of backs within the HCC field. Novartis has stated that they will no longer proceed with regulatory filings of Afinitor in this indication.
Novartis announced that results of a global Phase III study showed that Afinitor® did not extend OS compared to placebo in patients with locally advanced or metastatic HCC after progression on or intolerance to sorafenib.
Alessandro Riva, Global Head, Oncology Development & Medical Affairs, Novartis Oncology stated "While we are disappointed with these results, Novartis remains committed to studying everolimus through a robust research and development program to address unmet needs in different types of cancer. To date, Afinitor has proven efficacy in a number of tumor types, including hormone receptor positive advanced breast cancer, advanced pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors and advanced renal cell carcinoma."
Afinitor development will continue in other diseases with high unmet needs including GI and lung NET, HER2 positive breast cancer, lymphoma and TSC
Study details
The Phase III study, EVOLVE-1 (EVerOlimus for LiVer cancer Evaluation-1), is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial examining the efficacy and safety of everolimus versus placebo, plus best supportive care (BSC), in adult patients with advanced HCC whose disease progressed after treatment with or who were intolerant to sorafenib, a targeted therapy. The study results continue to be evaluated and will be presented at an upcoming medical conference.
EVOLVE-1 involved 546 patients and was conducted at 156 sites worldwide. Patients in the trial were randomized (2:1) to receive therapy with everolimus 7.5 mg/day orally plus BSC or placebo plus BSC. The primary endpoint was overall survival. Secondary endpoints included time to tumor progression, disease control rate,time to deterioration of performance status, safety and quality of life
From http://www.novartis.com, see original source.

item.title: HuGel Initiates New Korean Comparative Study With Botulax In Post-Stroke Upper Limb Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: HuGel has started a randomised multicentre comparative PhIII trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of Botulax vs. Botox in 186 patients with ULS.
Endpoints
Primary is the change in MAS from baseline to week 4 and for writs flexor muscle tone specifically.
Secondary
  • Change in MAS for elbow, finger and thumb flexor from baseline to week 4. week 8 and week 12
  • Change in DAS from baseline to week 4,8 and 12
  • Global assessment investigator evaluated and patient evaluated at week 4, 8 & 12
Trial Timeline & Location
Study start date August 2013, Estimated completion November 2013 (primary outcome). Six centres in Korea are mentioned as participants.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01915459
Source: ClinicalTrial.gov

Having made good progress with strengthening its balance sheet and focusing its business it now feels better positioned to strengthen its portfolio.

item.title: Bayer Enters Into $540m Cancer Immunotherapy Agreement With Compugen
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bayer yesterday announced a new oncology collaboration and license agreement with Compugen covering the research, development and commercialisation of antibody based therapeutics targeting two novel immune checkpoint regulators discovered by Compugen.
Together the companies will pursue a preclinical research program, whilst subsequently Bayer will take over full control of further development.
Bayer makes the point that the latest immunotherapies have demonstrated impressive durable clinical benefits, even for end-stage patients with difficult-to -treat tumours such as metastatic melanoma and NSCLC.
Deal Terms
Upfront payment of $10m plus milestone payments for both programmes of up to $500m. Additional milestone payment sof $30m are associated with preclinical activities.
Compugen is also eligible to receieve mid to high single digit royalties on worldwide commercial sales.
Source: Bayer.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Drug To Treat Polycystic Kidney Disease May Not Gain US Approval
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: FDA's Cardiovasucular and Renal Drugs Advisory Committee voted 9-6 yesterday that the overall risk/benefit profile of Otsuka Pharmaceutical's tolvaptan does not support is apporval to slow kidney disease in adults with polycystic kidney diseaxe (ADPKD). The PDUFA date is Sept 1st.
Tolvaptan a vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist is already approved in the US under the trade name Samsca for the treatment of hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatraemia. However, in May the FDA issued a safety alert regarding potential liver toxicity, based on data emerging from an ADPKD trial. It stipulated that the drug should be used for no longer than 30 days and should not be used in patients with underlying liver disease because of the risk of liver injury potentially leading to liver transplant or death.
Source: Biocentury 5th August

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: SIMPONI Recommended for EU Approval in Adult Patients with Moderately to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Based on the CHMP's positive opinion, a final decision from the European Commission is expected during the third quarter of 2013.
Janssen Biologics announced that the CHMP adopted a positive opinion recommending the use of SIMPONI® (golimumab) for the treatment of adult patients with moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis who have had an inadequate response to conventional therapy or who are intolerant to or have medical contraindications for such therapies.
If approved, SIMPONI will be the only biologic therapy available for this patient population that is administered subcutaneously every four weeks following an induction regimen.
The CHMP adopted the opinion based on a review of data from two pivotal studies in the Program of Ulcerative Colitis Research Studies Utilizing an Investigational Treatment (PURSUIT)

item.title: AstraZeneca Feeling More Positive - Q2 Highlights
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AstraZeneca highlighted that despite a number of setbacks, real progress has been made in the second quarter against their strategic priorities
AstraZeneca Q2 2013 highlights
  • 2Q revenue down 4% CER: ~ $500m decline from loss of exclusivity
  • Good progression of growth platforms: $400m (double-digit growth @ CER)
  • 5 key growth platforms include: Brilinta, Diabetes (Byetta/Bydureon, Forxiga and Onglyza), Emerging Markets, Japan and Respiratory
  • Growing late-stage pipeline:
  • 2 NDA submissions
  • 1 Phase 3 start
  • 3 late-stage projects added via business development
Pipeline Chart — no movement seen with their AKT inhibitor in P1.
Recent pipeline news includes:
  • Forxiga (dapagliflozin) NDA resubmitted in US; 11 January 2014 PDUFA
  • Moxetumomab (unresponsive or relapsed hairy cell leukaemia patients) Phase III start
  • Headline results for SAVOR study
  • Onglyza met its primary safety objective of non-inferiority and did not meet the primary efficacy objective of superiority for a composite endpoint(CV death, non-fatal MI, non-fatal ischaemic stroke)
  • Presentation at ESC in Septembe
  • Fostamatinib (rheumatoid arthritis) will not progress to regulatory filings
  • Growing portfolio of late stage assets; Omthera and Pearl acquisitions,FibroGen collaboration

item.title: re: Pasireotide PAOLA Study Has Completed & Met Endpoint
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Pasireotide PAOLA Study Has Completed & Met Endpoint 
Comment: Alongside its Q2 earnings, Novartis made a preliminary announcement about the Pasireotide (Signifor) PAOLA study, the second phIII study with pasireotide LAR in inadequate responders to octreotide LAR or lanreotide. It noted that the study had met its primary endpoint and that regulatory discussions with authorities are now underway.  ...
These announced timelines for the Phase 3 were expected and positive results for the primary endpoint of PAOLA study were expected as well. They are the assumptions taken into consideration in the 4 year Somatuline forecast model
This study confirms what has been observed in the other pivotal phase 3 study (C2305) where pasireotide 40 had a better efficacy than Oct LAR 20 on GH and IGF1 (proportion of patients with a reduction of mean GH level to <2.5 µg/L and the normalization of IGF-1 to within normal limits (age and sex related) at 12 months) in medically naïve patients with active acromegaly . The results were elegantly presented in May 2012 by Novartis claiming that pasireotide LAR patients were 63% more likely to achieve full biochemical control than those on Sandostatin LAR, the current standard of care (but absolute values [pasireotide LAR(31%) vs Sandostatin LAR (19%)] were less impressive !!).
This PAOLA study is in a different study population, patients have active acromegaly but inadequately controlled on SSA ( not naïve); the control arm for this study keeping the uncontrolled patients as they are on LAR 30 or ATG 120. The primary endpoint is GH and IGF-1 levels at 24 weeks for pasireotide LAR 40 and 60 mg versus octreotide LAR 30 or lanreotide ATG 120. Based on Novartis announcement, it means pasireotide could control part of these inadequately controlled patients when they switch to pasireotide 40 or 60mg ( active arm). This is on line with what we are expecting from pasireotide, a slightly better efficacy than SSA 1st generation. No absolute numbers and thresholds for defining controlled acromegaly are disclosed so far.
Pasireotide was granted an orphan drug status in October 2009, for both Cushing’s disease(CD) and acromegaly. Our current approval assumption for acromegaly was April 2014 with pasireotide as a 2nd line after SSA 1st generation, assuming there is no delay due to the hyperglycemic deleterious effects that pasireotide has. A special warning for hyperglycemia will probably be “granted” to pasireotide. Most KOL remain reserved due to hyperglycemia-related side effects and tend to position pasireotide anyway as a second-line treatment, to be used after failure of existing SSA.
For Cushing disease, after priority review and fast-track and orphan drug designations, FDA has approved pasireotide for Cushing's disease patients for whom surgery has been unsuccessful or who are not surgical candidates but requested 3 postmarketing studies including a clinical trial to assess hyperglycemia management, a long-term prospective observational cohort study of patients with Cushing's disease treated with pasireotide, and focused safety monitoring for reports of serious hyperglycemia, acute liver injury, and adrenal insufficiency.
When we know that the unmet medical need for Cushing disease is more important than for acromegaly and that Cushing disease is generally a more severe condition than Acromegaly, it will be interesting to see how FDA will assess the benefit /risk ratio of pasireotide in acromegaly
At franchise level and as a follow up of the pasireotide war gaming (multidisciplinary session organized last October by the Endo Franchise and then shared with regions and countries for sensitization and implementation of the counteracting plan at country level) , the franchise will monitor closely the NOVARTIS strategic approach re- pasireotide in acromegaly and will adapt and fine tune the counteraction plan accordingly.

item.title: re: Pasireotide PAOLA Study Has Completed & Met Endpoint
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside its Q2 earnings, Novartis made a preliminary announcement about the Pasireotide (Signifor) PAOLA study, the second phIII study with pasireotide LAR in inadequate responders to octreotide LAR or lanreotide. It noted that the study had met its primary endpoint and that regulatory discussions with authorities are now underway. 
This announcement could be a reason of the silence around PAOLA during last Novartis communications in international congresses (ECE, Endocrine).
They might have launched the filing process very early, and since Health Authorities usually do not appreciate massive communication while data are being reviewed, Novartis adopted a low-profile attitude.
Their next congress communication or presence might be different.

item.title: Pasireotide PAOLA Study Has Completed & Met Endpoint
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside its Q2 earnings, Novartis made a preliminary announcement about the Pasireotide (Signifor) PAOLA study, the second phIII study with pasireotide LAR in inadequate responders to octreotide LAR or lanreotide. It noted that the study had met its primary endpoint and that regulatory discussions with authorities are now underway.
This announcement could be a reason of the silence around PAOLA during last Novartis communications in international congresses (ECE, Endocrine).
They might have launched the filing process very early, and since Health Authorities usually do not appreciate massive communication while data are being reviewed, Novartis adopted a low-profile attitude.
Their next congress communication or presence might be different.
PAOLA study design
SOM230C2402 is a multicenter, randomized study of double-blind pasireotide LAR 40 mg and pasireotide LAR 60 mg versus open-label octreotide LAR 30 mg or lanreotide ATG 120 mg, in patients with inadequately controlled acromegaly.
The Q2 earnings release notes that:-
"First results from the Phase III study SOM230C2402 showed that a statistically significant greater proportion of acromegaly patients treated with pasireotide LAR saw a reduction of mean GH levels to < 2.5 µg/L and normalization of sex- and age-adjusted IGF-1 at 24 weeks versus continued treatment with octreotide or lanreotide, meeting the primary objective of the study."
Full results of the study will apparently be submitted for presentation at an upcoming congress.
Regulatory Status
Novartis mentions its plans to include these results in regulatory
submissions for pasireotide LAR in acromegaly and claims to have initiated discussions with health authorities worldwide.
Below is a reminder of Joe Jiminez's statement regarding launch expectations over the next 2 years delivered at the JP Morgan Conference in January 7th 2013. His slide stated an expected US approval for Signifor in acromegaly within 12 months and an EU approval within 13-24 months.

Comments
These announced timelines for the Phase 3 were expected and positive results for the primary endpoint of PAOLA study were expected as well. They are the assumptions taken into consideration in the 4 year Somatuline forecast model
This study confirms what has been observed in the other pivotal phase 3 study (C2305) where pasireotide 40 had a better efficacy than Oct LAR 20 on GH and IGF1 (proportion of patients with a reduction of mean GH level to <2.5 µg/L and the normalization of IGF-1 to within normal limits (age and sex related) at 12 months) in medically naïve patients with active acromegaly . The results were elegantly presented in May 2012 by Novartis claiming that pasireotide LAR patients were 63% more likely to achieve full biochemical control than those on Sandostatin LAR, the current standard of care (but absolute values [pasireotide LAR(31%) vs Sandostatin LAR (19%)] were less impressive !!).
This PAOLA study is in a different study population, patients have active acromegaly but inadequately controlled on SSA ( not naïve); the control arm for this study keeping the uncontrolled patients as they are on LAR 30 or ATG 120. The primary endpoint is GH and IGF-1 levels at 24 weeks for pasireotide LAR 40 and 60 mg versus octreotide LAR 30 or lanreotide ATG 120. Based on Novartis announcement, it means pasireotide could control part of these inadequately controlled patients when they switch to pasireotide 40 or 60mg ( active arm). This is on line with what we are expecting from pasireotide, a slightly better efficacy than SSA 1st generation. No absolute numbers and thresholds for defining controlled acromegaly are disclosed so far.
Pasireotide was granted an orphan drug status in October 2009, for both Cushing’s disease(CD) and acromegaly. Our current approval assumption for acromegaly was April 2014 with pasireotide as a 2nd line after SSA 1st generation, assuming there is no delay due to the hyperglycemic deleterious effects that pasireotide has. A special warning for hyperglycemia will probably be “granted” to pasireotide. Most KOL remain reserved due to hyperglycemia-related side effects and tend to position pasireotide anyway as a second-line treatment, to be used after failure of existing SSA.
For Cushing disease, after priority review and fast-track and orphan drug designations, FDA has approved pasireotide for Cushing's disease patients for whom surgery has been unsuccessful or who are not surgical candidates but requested 3 postmarketing studies including a clinical trial to assess hyperglycemia management, a long-term prospective observational cohort study of patients with Cushing's disease treated with pasireotide, and focused safety monitoring for reports of serious hyperglycemia, acute liver injury, and adrenal insufficiency.
When we know that the unmet medical need for Cushing disease is more important than for acromegaly and that Cushing disease is generally a more severe condition than Acromegaly, it will be interesting to see how FDA will assess the benefit /risk ratio of pasireotide in acromegaly
At franchise level and as a follow up of the pasireotide war gaming (multidisciplinary session organized last October by the Endo Franchise and then shared with regions and countries for sensitization and implementation of the counteracting plan at country level) , the franchise will monitor closely the NOVARTIS strategic approach re- pasireotide in acromegaly and will adapt and fine tune the counteraction plan accordingly.

item.title: Takeda Q2 Earnings- Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment::- Having already flagged the recent disappointing news with orteronel (TAK-700), Takeda's earnings webcast focused on some of its more promising developments with its new first-in-class diabetes drug TAK-875, a GPR40 agonist and its mAb vedoluzimab for ulverative colitis and Crohn's disease.
Q1 2013/14 Financials
Net sales were up ¥12 billion or 3.0% from the same period last year to ¥410.3 billion. Operating income went down ¥14.9 billion or 23.8% to ¥47.7 billion and net income went down ¥58.5 billion or 66.8% to ¥29.1 billion.

In order to have a competitive operating model as a global company, Takeda has initiated cost cutting project named Summit. It was announced in May and the company is now in the process of discussing specific initiatives by cost category. The project it is claimed is advancing very smoothly. By the second quarter earnings report, management hope to be able to expand on the whole picture of the project and specific measures.

Vedoluzimab (UC & Crohn's)

Following on from the filing in Europe, a BLA was recently filed in the U.S. for MLN0002 vedolizumab as a treatment for ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. The product is a first-in-class novel gut-selective monoclonal antibody that targets α4β7 integrin on leukocytes involved in ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

Findings from GEMINI I trial for ulcerative colitis showed that vedolizumab met primary endpoints of improvement in clinical response at week six and clinical remission at week 52.

  • The six-week clinical response in vedolizumab arm was 47.1% compared to 25.5% in the placebo arm.
  • Remission rates at 52 weeks were 44.8% of patients receiving vedolizumab every four weeks and 41.8% of vedolizumab every eight weeks, it compared to 15.9% of patients who received placebo.

In GEMINI II for Crohn's disease, vedolizumab demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in the primary endpoint of clinical remission at week six and week 52.

  • Clinical remission at week six was seen in 14.5% of vedolizumab patients versus 6.8% of placebo;
  • Remission at week 52 was seen in 36.4% and 39% of patients on vedolizumab every four weeks and every eight weeks, respectively versus 21.6% of patients receiving placebo.

TAK-875, fasiglifam (diabetes).

Has displayed its new mechanism of action of stimulating insulin secretion dependent on glucose level.

Because it is glucose dependent, the risk of hypoglycemia is much lower than existing sulfonylurea drugs. And in Phase II clinical trials, the incidence of hypoglycemia for TAK-875 was 2% versus 19% for the sulfonylurea glimepiride. TAK-875 is currently in global Phase III trials. In addition to trials in comparison to placebo and glimepiride, head-to-head trials and concomitant use trials with DPP-4 inhibitor sitagliptin are also being undertaken.

In order to satisfy the U.S. FDA's requirements, a cardiovascular outcomes study is also underway. Projected timeline of the approval in Japan is fiscal 2015 and in the U.S. and the Europe, fiscal 2016.

Source: Takeda Q1 Earnings Release


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Botox Therapeutic Sales Benefit From New Indications
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan reported second quarter, double digit sales and earnings growth is in line with its long term growth aspirations and slightly above market consensus. Botox sales sales grew 11.8% year-to-date, 13.5% year-over-year in local currencies, with double-digit year-to-date growth seen in both the therapeutic and aesthetic categories.
Allergan claims to be gaining share in therapeutics as it builds out the chronic migraine and bladder indications, by contrast, in aesthetics it is experiencing some loss of share.

Since its last earnings call, Allergan has received several new approvals:-

  • Neurogenic overactive bladder - Singapore and Morocco plus public reimbursement in Australia
  • Overactive bladder - Hungary, Poland, New Zealand, India, Oman, and Chile.

U.S - the therapeutic business continues to grow strongly, driven by chronic migraine, the two bladder indications, and upper limb spasticity.

  • Chronic migraine has achieved a high level of reimbursement coverage, with 92% of commercial lives covered and 100% of Medicare lives.
  • The company is continuiuing to invest in deepening injector experience by local live programs and preceptorships in order to increase rates of adoption and productivity.
  • Additionally, it has created a dedicated practice management group to assist physicians with the organization ofa Botox clinic and improved patient flow.
  • Beyond working on increased physician capacity to handle patients, it claims to have also stepped up its efforts to educate patients about the availability of Botox by launching the first branded television campaign for Botox for chronic migraine. This started at the end of June. Since that date, a major increase in the number of website visits and views of what is called "Find a Headache Specialist".has occurred.
  • Since approval of neurogenic overactive bladder, over half of the universe of urologists and urogynecologists have been trained and Allergian is claiming that. user and patient satisfaction is high.
  • During 2013, sales in the urology channel, have almost doubled albeit off a small base in 2012. Reimbursement for overactive bladder is still a barrier.. As of June, 82% coverage of Medicare lives has been achieved and 42% of commercial lives. Denial rates for prior authorizations are falling steadily.

In the movement disorders area, Allergan claims to be both growing the market as well as maintaining high market share. With Ipsen's recent announcement to restructure its U.S. operations, Allergan expects to face less competitive pressure

Europe - Allergan noted that the market seems to be growing above mid-single-digits and that Botox is gaining share based on initial uptake in chronic migraine and in urology..

Allergan claims to have witnessed strong growth in Q2 in most of the principal markets of the world with the exception of Canada and Australia,

  • In Canada it has been drawing down inventory in the doctor's office after a combined promotion with JUVÉDERM in Q1. This has bee strategically timed to be just ahead of the launches of Xeomin and Dysport;
  • In Australia, Galderma's heavy price discounting of Azzalure has impacted Botox's sales growth..
  • Eslewhere, such as in Russia, Japan, China and most countries in East and South Asia Allergan claims to be enjoying strong growth.

Allergan claims that Xeomin's aesthetic share has stagnated at 5% for several months now with a significant part of the share stemming from free goods and samples. In Western Europe, Allergan believes that it has now been able to contain its market share loss to Azzalure and Bocouture.

When questioned about how he expected the international/US revenue mix to shake out, Pyott responded:-

"Clearly in the short swing, the biggest opportunity for migraine and bladder is the U.S. And part of that is just because of what you hear from all companies is the delay effects elsewhere in the world. So, even once you've got an approval in some country in the European Union, the time required to then get full access to patients across the European continent probably is about two to two and a half years. And when you look to Southern Europe, basically the Spanish Government has been saving money by just not getting around to issuing answers on what is the reimbursement price. So we're pleased that we've cracked those codes in Spain and Italy. But the point I'm making is it's a long swing effect in many of those markets.. So, net-net, what does that all mean? Assume that new Botox indications are just longer swing. They take time to come through. But they will come through".

Allergan estimates that revenues for the full-year will be between $6.05 & $6.2bn and that Botox sales will reach $1.94-$2bn.

Source: Allergan Q2 Earnings Release

item.title: Highlights of Sanofi Q2:13 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management reported a difficult quarter due to the residual impact of the patent cliff, charge related to Brazil, currency and commercial underperformance in certain business areas. Pharma sales were €6,714 million, a decrease of 7.1%, which reflected generic competition, and EU austerity measures. Sales in Emerging Markets totaled €2,669 million, a decrease of 2.3%. Sanofi expects to return to growth in H2:13.
Jevtana® sales were €54 million in the second quarter, reflecting lower sales in the U.S. due to a more competitive environment.
In Western Europe sales of the product were stable at €25 million. First-half sales of Jevtana® were €106 million (down 10.1%).

item.dc:creator: spoon

Gonax (degarelix 3M) is listed to be in Ph3/Japan meaning no change in its status. To be noted the slow sales progression of Eligard (+1%). Sales decreased in Japan and steadily expanded in Americas, EU and Asia. A selection of key strategic slides are provided below.
Astellas reported it will start business in Singapore from Oct 1st, 2013. In addition to sales affiliates throughout EU/The Middle and near East/Africa and the Americas, Astellas now owns 10 sales affiliates in the Asia/Oceania region.

item.title: Merz Acquires Swiss Dermatology Company
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The acquisition of Neocutis' cosmeceutical skin care products will consolidate Merz' market position in the field of aesthetic dermatology, and expand its business in the U.S.. Financial terms are not disclosed.
- Neocutis' products used as pre- and post-treatments to aesthetic procedures.
- In the U.S Merz offers a well-balanced range of products for minimally invasive treatments, including the dermal fillers Radiesse® and Belotero®, the neurotoxin Xeomin®, a product for the treatment of varicose veins, as well as products for the treatment of scars and fungal skin diseases. The U.S. is the main market for Neocutis.
- founded in February 2003 as a spin-off of the medical faculty of the Lausanne University Clinic, Switzerland.
- privately owned company with HQs in Pully (Switzerland)
- develops and distributes innovative products for aesthetic dermatology (anti-aging, pigmentation problems, sun protection).
Since the company entered the market in 2009, it has recorded strong annual growth. The anti-aging line is one of the products with the highest recorded turnover.
Source: Merz

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Astellas Japan Appoints New Senior VP of Global Oncology
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Claire Thom, Pharm.D., will replace Dr Wayne Klohs who recently retired.
Most recently Claire served as Senior VP Portfolio Management, Drug Development Management and Strategic Business Operations at Millennium, where she was responsible for the oncology portfolio management process.
Previously, she was responsible for the oversight and implementation of the global therapeutic area strategies for oncology, urology and gynecology franchises of Takeda Pharmaceutical Company in Japan.
She is a graduate of the University of Illinois at Chicago where she earned a bachelor's degree and Doctorate of Pharmacy.
Source: Astellas

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Botulinum Toxin Type A2 Has Entered Ph2/3 for Stroke Patients with Lower Limb Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The randomized, double-blind study will compare clinical efficacy of single IM injection of 300U of A2NTX and 300U of BOTOX®. PE will assess the change in modified Ashworth Scale of the ankle joint. More details on the Japanese toxin are provided below.

Feedback from the Neurology Franchise (S. Guillebaud and S. Om) has outlined the following:

As presented during a plenary session that took place in Hannover at the International Congress of Dystonia on the 11th of May 2013, this botulinum type A derived from a subtype A2 strain of Clostridium botulinum seems to have some advantages vs other toxins.

  • Stay at local site (Less spread to un-injected muscles than A1 (showed by grip power test / shown in animal studies that A2NTX is less diffusible than BOTOX® or other BoNT)
  • Less antigenicity
  • 2-fold efficacy (A2 requires less dose (50%) than botox to have same effect)
  • Safe
  • Less axonal transport to CNS
  • Storage at room temperature.(Still stable at 45°C for several month)
Manufactured by Kaketsuken (Japan)
Location/Contact: U. of Tokushima / Ryuji Kaji, Professor and Chairman, Department of Neurology, University of Tokushima
Recruitment: approx. 30 patients
Completion Date: November 2013
At WCN (September-Vienna), Ryuji Kaji will be a speaker for "The challenge of botulinum toxin for spasticity"
Ryuji Kaji is cited in the poster below (to be noted the association with Allergan).

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Foreign exchange negatively impacted BRIC-Mexico and Turkey revenue by 1% vs Q2:12. However CEO expects H2:13 to be stronger than H1:13 in emerging markets. He outlined that the new commercial structure will better position Pfizer, and provide greater financial transparency.

item.title: Key Messages from Lexicon Q2:13 Earnings
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Top-line results from Ph2 of telotristat etiprate for UC and LX1033 for IBS-d are expected around end of Q3:13 and Q4:13 respectively. Management reported that safety data from the Ph2 trial of LX4211 in T1DM allowed the study to advance into its expansion phase.
Presenters
Lexicon is "continuing to make progress on the partnership discussions and its objective remains to move into Ph3 with a partner this year for LX4211 (in T2DM)". ... "it is important to have someone with experience in the diabetes space and that is really our focus and our discussions".
Recruitment of LX1032 / Telotristat etiprate for carcinoid syndrome - Management reported that "We had a wave of sites come up. In Europe a little longer than in the US and we are very satisfied with the European participation that that has come onboard in the past quarter and so we are consistent right now in randomization with our projections to complete randomization in 2014".
Endpoints for LX1032 for UC - "The most important is the Mayo score which integrates patients symptoms, physician observation and colonoscopy results", endoscopy scores and bowel movement frequency (BMF).
Timelines for LX2761 - " ... currently in IND enabling studies and we anticipate filing an IND near mid year of next year".
Source: Lexicon Webcast

item.title: uniQure Strengthens Leadership Position in Gene Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In the last 3 weeks, the company reported to start the build-out of a production plant in the US to leverage AAV-manufacturing strenght, the start of Ph1 to test its GDNF in patients with Parkinson's disease, and a €45M commercialization agreement with Chiesi.
State-of-the-art 55,000 square foot in Lexington, Massachusetts for the production of commercial grade Adeno Associated Virus (AAV)-based gene therapy products to complement its current EMA-approved site in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
The Company expects the facility to be operational by early 2015.
uniQure’s aim is to administer recombinant AAV (adeno-associated virus) vector that carries the gene for GDNF to the brain.
Investigator initiated clinical trial in Parkinson’s disease, led by Dr. Krystof Bankiewicz MD, PhD, at UCSF, and Dr. John D. Heiss, MD, at the National Institute for Neurological Disorders and Stroke, part of the National Institutes of Health (NIH).
The study is a Phase I open-label dose escalation safety study that will include 24 patients divided over 4 cohorts. The first patient was dosed on May 20, and so far there have been no safety issues. The study is fully funded by the NIH.
Collaboration agreements with Chiesi Farmaceutici SpA for:
  • the commercialization of Glybera, the first gene therapy to receive regulatory approval in Europe
  • the co-development of a gene therapy for hemophilia B
In connection with this transaction, uniQure has received EUR 17 million (USD 21.8 million) in collaboration financing and EUR 14 million (USD 18 million) in equity financing from Chiesi.
Source: uniQure

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Acino's HY13 Results Driven by Strong Sales in Emerging Markets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The highlight in the first six months of 2013 was the launch of the rivastigmine transdermal system in Germany where it was one of the first generics to reach the market. Alongside the financial results, management indicated that partnering discussions for leuprorelin and goserelin are ongoing. From a clinical trial perspective, it was reported that the study of goserelin 1M is ongoing but 'delayed', and that trial for goserelin 3M will be starting after completion of the 1M study. EU approval for leuprorelin 3M is expected for Q3 16, and Q2 17 for goserelin 3M. A selection of key slides is provided below.
Strategy: Entry into new countries both BtC (Ukraine, Russia, etc.) and BtB (US, Japan, China, Brazil, etc.)
Acino Switzerland BtC product launches will accelerate (60 in 2013, 120 in 2014)
Mepha/Cephalon acquisition facilitates access to new markets in MENA, Africa, Latin America & Asia, and paved the way for launch of own product portfolio under the brand “Acino Switzerland”
Status product launches:  Launches of Clopacin® (clopidogrel besilate), Fentavera® (fentanyl patch), Metracin® (metoprolol succinate MUPS), Fuzocim® (alfuzosine-HCl); Doxacin® (doxazosin mesilate) and others are scheduled in several MENA & African markets  Several approvals obtained in Africa, for example oxycodone in Kenya; key strategic products submitted in South Africa  Asian launch of Clopacin®, approval of Fentavera® in South Korea  Latin America filings are under way; Clopacin® approved in Ecuador  CIS countries: 30 dossiers dispatched, first sales expected by end 2012 In addition, a high number of product submissions in BtC markets  47 already approved, additional 86 in registration  Total of 500+ submission projects running.
Increase BtC profitability
  • Renegotiate contract terms with local distribution partners
  • Decrease in country overhead cost as % of sales as a result of growing business
  • Price increases where possible
  • Launch of new higher margin products
  • Reduce payment terms / move to advance payments
Growin the BtB Segment
  • Optimize and foster existing (niche) portfolio
  • Launch new own developments (rivastigmine patch)
  • Identify Unique Selling Points and address them during development to create more value added products using advanced delivery systems
  • Selection of business partners with (brand) marketing approach, not lowest price strategy
  • Entering into licensing deals in markets like US, Japan, etc.
  • Differentiated country-specific pricing with one partner
TM BUSINESS
Opportunities
  • Differentiating features
  • Lead project Bayer fertility control patch
  • Strive for co-developments
  • Broaden and upgrade existing sites and equipment park

item.title: Valeant to Reduce Staff Numbers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a filing with the US SEC, the company has disclosed it expects to reduce staff numbers by 10-15% (approx. 2,700 jobs) once the acquisition of Bausch and Lomb is complete.
Management noted that:
  • Medicis Ops will be relocated to New Jersey from Scottsdale
  • Arizona Obagi business will be combined with Bausch & Lomb location in California
Valeant HQ stays in Laval, Quebec.
See PharmaWorld10463: Valeant Agrees to Acquire Baush & Lomb for $8.7 Billion
Source: Valeant

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Taipei-Based Company Claims to Develop and Manufacture a New 'Botox'
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a PR published in Focus Taiwan, Amaran Biotechnology Inc. reported to have started the construction of a plant located in the Hsinchu Biomedical Science Park to produce 'Botox'. Of note, Amaran has formed a strategic alliance with OBI Pharma, which is developing a botulinum toxin (currently in preclinical stage for muscle spasticity).
The article mentionned that the plant has received investment totaling $33.4M).
The plant will feature laboratories with a biological safety level of three, the second-highest on a scale of four, where 'Botox' can be worked with under the controls necessary to limit contamination of the work environment and the surrounding community.
Under a strategic alliance with OBI Pharma, the Hsinchu plant will also serve as a base manufacturer of breast cancer drug, OBI-822/821 (currently in Phase 3).
The company website indicates it is developing OBI-858, a botulinum toxin in PC development.
Pipeline
Please help us identifying the level of threat of this news in forwarding any relevant information you can gather on Amaran Biotechnology, its plant and the timelines (management claimed to be able to roll-out the new 'Botox' in 2020).

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ebastina remains the best selling product, despite its -17.5% decrease caused by lower prices and the arrival of generics in certain countries. Meanwhile, Eklira® is now the company's second best-selling product, contributing €38.7M. LAS41008, for psoriasis, along with Sativex® for alleviating oncological pain, are both undergoing ph3 with topline results to be read out in 2014. Key slides are provided below.

item.title: Pfizer to Separate Operations into Three Business Segments
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The units will include 2 'Innovative Business' segments and 1 'Value Business' segment. Each of the three segments will include developed markets and emerging markets.
  1. The Innovative business segments led by G Germano, will generally include products across multiple therapeutic areas that are expected to have market exclusivity beyond 2015. The therapeutic areas include Inflammation and Immunology, CV/Metabolic, Neuroscience and Pain, Rare Diseases and Women’s /Men’s Health.
  2. The Innovative business segment will include Vaccines, Oncology and Consumer Healthcare and will be led by Amy Schulman.
  3. The Value business segment, led by John Young, will include products that generate strong, consistent cash flow.
Management outlined that the changes will go into effect in January 2014 in countries that do not require a consultation with labor unions.
Source: Pfizer

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Perrigo to Buy Ireland's Elan for $8.6bn
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The deal ends a takeover saga in which Elan rejected three hostile bids. The offer represents a 10.5% premium to the Friday close. After closing, the combined company will be based in Ireland. Perrigo reported that they are "not going to get into the branded pharma business or biotech business... but looking at how best to monetize pipeline asset" (ELND005 neuropsychiatric program in Phase II studies).
Perrigo receive escalated royalties from Tysabri, which has high barriers to entry. Generated a 19% compound annual growth rate over the 2008 to 2012 period. Is well positioned for future growth and has further opportunities for growth at other indications, other geographies and for the treatment of other diseases. Is without a doubt one of the most important and efficacious treatments for people suffering from multiple sclerosis.
The transaction will give Perrigo access to a Ph2 central nervous system product that is approaching a key milestone.
Perrigo will receive $1.9bn in cash from the Elan balance sheet.
The company will have an opportunity to further enhance its international platform via Irish legal domicile.
Management anticipate this transaction will be accretive to adjusted earnings per share in 2014 and will create meaningful synergy opportunities. It expects to realize more than $150M annually in after tax operating expense and tax savings as a result of this combination.
Perrigo sells non-prescription products for conditions such as acid indigestion and nasal congestion, as well as generic drugs, nutritional supplements and animal treatments.
- TYSABRI
Elan's current portfolio includes royalties from Tysabri® (marketed and distibuted by Biogen Idec) along with a neuropsychiatric pipeline.
Tysabri® generated revenues of US$1.6 billion in 2012, and has been growing at a compound annual growth rate of 19%.
Further upside if approved for Secondary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (SPMS) - study completion expected in 2015 (readout).
- THERAVANCE
- AOP ORPHAN
Source: Elan; Perrigo

item.title: Prolor Has Started Registration Trial with Once-Weekly hGH for AGHD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The multi-center Ph3 will be recruiting approx. 189 participants (23 years to 70 years) in the US. PE wil assess change in trunk FM, expressed in kilograms measured with DXA, and safety.
Start date: June 2013 - Completion date: March / August 2015.
Secondary Outcome Measures:
  • Change in total FM, expressed in kilograms, measured with DXA, from baseline to 26 and 52 weeks [ Time Frame: 52 weeks ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Change in lean body mass, expressed in kilograms measured with DXA, from baseline to 26 and 52 weeks [ Time Frame: 52 weeks ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Change in trunk FM, expressed in kilograms measured with DXA, from baseline to 52 weeks [ Time Frame: 52 weeks ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Change in trunk FM, expressed as % change from baseline, measured with DXA, from baseline to 26 and 52 weeks [ Time Frame: 52 weeks ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: AbbVie Q2 Growth Driven by Humira
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On July 26th, Abbvie hosted its Q2 financial results. Revenue increased by 4.4% to $4.692 billion, driven primarily by strong sales of HUMIRA (+16%), and key products such as Synthroid, Creon, Zemplar and Duodopa. Global sales of Lupron were nearly $200M. Completion of enrollment in the HCV trial, ph3 initiation of the atrasentan programs, collaboration with Alvine Pharm. for celiac disease (in Ph2), and with BMS for multiple myeloma were stressed as being significant advancements in AbbVie's pipeline. The most detailed update of the Elagolix program in both endometriosis and UF was provided during Neurocrine Q2 the day before.
Neurocrine's management reported the following:
" ... The ph3-study is on track, with AbbVie anticipation of completing randomization this fall, and top-line data from the ph3 in Q1 of 2014.
I'm also pleased to note that about a week ago, our Daisy PETAL study, which was the so-called 901 study -- very successful ph2b study with patients -- was published electronically ahead of print publication in the Journal of and Pelvic Pain. That manuscript is available there for subscribers to that journal or for purchase. And the abstract is available, obviously, at no charge.
So that's a great piece of data to get out. And as you recall, the co-primary endpoints of dysmenorrhea and non-menstrual pelvic pain that were solidified in that trial are the ones that the FDA was very pleased with and that we're taking forward into the ph3 trial.
AbbVie also tells us their uterine fibroid (UF) program is on track. As you know, they're in the midst of the phase-IIb activities, and we look forward to additional updates from AbbVie as those studies move along ...".
  • Q2 13 sales represent $199M ($144M in the US; $55M international).
  • H1 13 sales represent $269M ($380M for the US; $111M international).
AbbVie management outlined that " ... Lupron continues to hold a leadership position and maintain a significant share of the market. For the full-year 2013, we expect Lupron sales to be roughly in line with 2012".
Source: Neurocrine; Abbvie

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Failure of Takeda's TAK-700 in Post-Chemo mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda has halted its ELM-PC 5 study due to futility for OS at interim analysis. I
Orteronel plus prednisone would likely not meet the primary endpoint of improved overall survival (OS) when compared to the control arm (HR 0.894, p=0.226).
- Advantage for orteronel plus prednisone for the secondary endpoint, radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS) over the control arm (HR 0.755, p=0.00029).
- No safety concerns.
Management reported that the decision to unblind the ELM-PC 5 study is not expected to impact other ongoing company-sponsored clinical trials with orteronel, including the ELM-PC 4 pivotal Ph3 study (C21004) comparing orteronel plus prednisone to placebo plus prednisone in patients with chemotherapy-naive mCRPC.
> About ELM-PC 5 (C21005) http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01193257?term=C21005&rank=1
> About ELM-PC 4 (C21004) http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01193244?term=c21004&rank=1

- Interim analysis not expected until 2014 (based on comments from Takeda and posted information on the study).

Analysts at JMP Securities expect interim data for Xtandi in PREVAIL in 3Q13, although Medivation has guided to YE13 (survival benefit has already been proven in the post-chemo setting).
Source: Takeda; JMP Securities

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Will Recent Events Impact GSK Business in China ?
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GSK has appointed one of its top European executives as the new head of operations in China. Herve Gisserot, senior vice president for Europe, will take over as general manager from Mark Reilly. During Q2 financial results, management reported that although ' ... we are likely to see some impact to our performance in China', ' ... the guidance remains unchanged for the full year of earnings per share growth of 3 to 4% and sales growth of around 1%".
It was made clear that the charges at this stage are primarily against individuals, who acted without corporate consent.
It seems there are currently no charges against GSK for economic damages (i.e. distorted drug pricing or similar).

item.title: Exelixis to Start Registration Trial with Cabozantinib in 2nd-line HCC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Advancing the cabozantinib franchise in pivotal trials for HCC is one of the company key priorities. The study is to assess the effect of the drug vs placebo on OS (as primary endpoint) in approx 760 patients with advanced HCC who have received prior sorafenib.
Start date: Aug 2013 - Completion date: October 2016
Secondary Outcome Measures
  • Progression-Free Survival (PFS) [ Time Frame: Up to 38 months ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ] Duration of PFS is defined as the time of randomization to the earlier of the following events: progressive disease or death due to any cause.
  • Objective Response Rate (ORR) [ Time Frame: Up to 38 months ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ] ORR is measured by radiologic assessment every 8 weeks after randomization until disease progression or discontinuation of study treatment. ORR is the proportion of subjects experiencing a confirmed complete response(CR) or confirmed partial response (PR).

Comments
The company has reported it has initiated CELESTIAL, with Ghassan K. Abou-Alfa, M.D., (Associate Attending at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York) as lead investigator. CELESTIAL is the fifth pivotal trial for cabozantinib overall, and the second phase 3 trial to initiate this year. It was designed with the input of leading oncologists and HCC experts. Additional details are provided below.
Locations: up to 200 sites globally in up to 30 countries.
Protocol: Patients will be randomized 2:1 to receive 60 mg of cabozantinib daily or placebo.
Exploratory endpoints include patient-reported outcomes, biomarkers, and safety.
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (64,3 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New NICE Guidance Supports Routine Use of SIRT
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The NICE guidance, released on 24th July 2013, confirmed that the scientific evidence of the safety and efficacy of SIRT for patients with HCC is now considered adequate, which means that eligible National Health Service (NHS) patients are now likely to have access to this treatment.This decision should improve access to Sirtex' SIR-Spheres microspheres.

National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence.
Selective internal radiation therapy for primary hepatocellular carcinoma (Interventional Procedure Guidance 460). London: NICE, July 2013.
Early stage R&D programs include radioprotector technology that seeks to protect healthy tissue from ionising radiation.
SIR-Spheres microspheres are a medical device used in interventional oncology to deliver Selective Internal Radiation Therapy (SIRT) to the liver.
SIR-Spheres microspheres were approved in Europe in 2002, and >500 patients have received this treatment in Britain.

Sirtex is investing $60 million over five years into five major Post Marketing Clinical Studies involving leading institutions and 2,000 patients.

They are designed to demonstrate SIR-Spheres microspheres efficacy as a first-line treatment with three of the studies focused on metastatic colorectal cancer and two studies focused on hepatocellular carcinoma.

This global clinical studies program is expected to underpin the longterm growth potential of Sirtex with clinical data from the first study expected to be released in late 2014 or early 2015 and the remainder released progressively over the following few years.

item.title: Roche Reports HY 2013 Results and Confirms FY Targets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pharma sales rose 6%. Performance was driven by US, Oncology, Tamiflu and Actemra. Company stressed that emerging markets remain strong. In the presentation, we have noted 3 drugs in development for prostate cancer (RG7450 Steap1 ADC in Ph1; PI3 Kinase/mTOR dual inhibitor Ph1b/2; RG7440 AKT inhibitor in Ph1b/2). The oral octreotide RG3806, currently in Ph3, is anticipated to be submitted in 2014. Interestingly, management did not comment on the drug. Of note, no question araised from the investors as well.
  • Severin Schwan, CEO Roche Group
  • Alan Hippe, Chief Financial and IT Officer
  • Daniel O'Day, COO Pharmaceuticals
  • Roland Diggelmann, COO Diagnostics
Interest focused on GA101 which beats Rituxan (MabThera) in a late-stage trial, prompting hopes it is a viable successor.
Antibody Drug Conjugates
Small Molecules

item.title: Lonza and Teva Discontinue Biosimilar JV
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The companies have decided to discontinue Teva-Lonza JV, which began in 2009.
- To continue its biologics strategy and create a balanced portfolio of biosimilars, biobetters and innovative biologics.
- To focus on core expertise in contract manufacturing and cell line development
- To cease investing in non-strategic areas
Source: Teva; Lonza

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Recordati Expands Business in Tunisia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Recordati has acquired Opalia Pharma for around €37M. The company ranks eighth in the Tunisian pharmaceutical market and is the third largest local pharmaceutical company.
Recordati is already generating significant and growing revenue from its export sales in the North African countries.
This acquisition represents a strategic platform to establish a direct presence in this area with the objective of extending coverage also to countries in Central Africa and in the Gulf states.
Recordati will gain access to branded generic drugs with leading products in dermatology, gastroenterology and respiratory.
Opalia manufactures most of its products in a modern, cGMP certified production facility specialized in liquid and semi-solid forms. The company employs 322 people and sales in 2013 are estimated to be of around TND 40 million (around EUR 18.5 million).
Source: Recordati

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New Study to Assess Xeomin in Children/Adolescents with CP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The purpose of this Ph3 study is to determine whether injections of the toxin into muscles of the leg(s) or of leg(s) and one arm are safe in treating children/adolescents long-term with spasticity due to cerebral palsy. PE will assess the occurrence of treatment emergent adverse events.
Est Enrollment: 360 (female or male subject of 2 to 17 years age)
Start date: July 2013 - Completion: Sept 2016.
Location: 16 countries listed

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Corcept Partners with Idis to Give Physicians Global Access to Korlym(R)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Korlym® (mifepristone) 300 mg Tablets now is available to patients outside of the U.S through an Idis Access Program.
The company has been offering Korlym in the United States since April 2012 as a once-daily oral treatment of hyperglycemia secondary to endogenous Cushing's syndrome in adult patients who have type 2 diabetes mellitus or glucose intolerance and have failed surgery or are not candidates for surgery.
Idis has 25 years experience partnering with pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies to create regulatory-compliant, ethical access to medicines for healthcare professionals and their patients with unmet medical needs.
Since 1987, Idis has developed and managed access to thousands of medicines from every therapeutic category, impacting the lives of hundreds of thousands of patients in countries around the world.
Idis leverages decades of experience, regulatory insight, and a thorough understanding of local and global requirements to create access to medicines at every stage of a product's lifecycle from pre-approval to market exit, and in times of unexpected production shortages.
The company's European headquarters are located in Weybridge, United Kingdom, and North American headquarters are located in Princeton, NJ.
www.idispharma.com.
Source: Corcept

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Positive PC Data Generated by Inovio's 'Universal' Cancer Vaccine
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:The engineered cancer vaccine targets human telomerase reverse transcriptase (hTERT). High hTERT levels have been observed in an estimated 85% of all human cancers while they are rarely seen in normal cells. Inovio already has a near-clinical-stage candidate for prostate cancer, INO-5150, in development.
Inovio's hTERT (human telomerase reverse transcriptase) DNA cancer vaccine administered with Inovio's CELLECTRA® adaptive electroporation delivery technology generated robust and broad immune responses, broke the immune system's tolerance to its self-antigens, induced T-cells with a tumor-killing function, and increased the rate of survival.
- Publication: These results appear in the American Association for Cancer Research journal, Cancer Immunology Research, in a paper entitled: "Highly optimized DNA vaccine targeting human telomerase reverse transcriptase stimulates potent antitumor immunity".
- Findings: http://ir.inovio.com/2013-07-24-Inovio-Pharmaceuticals-Potent-hTERT-DNA-Cancer-Vaccine-Shows-Potential-to-Reduce-Tumors-and-Prevent-Tumor-Recurrence.

item.title: Novartis and Roche Attendance at Annual Gathering on Nanomedicines (June 23-26 Basel)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The event is seen as a unique forum for creative scientists to propose new ideas and for established research organizations, industries and funding organizations to provide opportunities for further growth of this area. This year's focus topic was : "
- Nanotubes for Oral Dosage Forms? Dr. Carsten Timpe, Pharma Early Research and Development Formulation, Research NCE Basel, Senior Principal Scientist, F. Hoffmann-La Roche AG, Basel (CH).
Dr Andreas Fisch, Fellow Pharmaceutical Development Parenterals at Novartis presented "Pharmaceutical Development Stages of Parenteral Nanomedicine: from discovery to Clinical Ph1".
Dr. Bernd Riebesehl, Principal Fellow Novartis Pharma AG chaired the session titled: Pharmaceutical Development - Requirements to Get from Drug Candidate Selection to Market.
- Not yet Realized Nanoapplications For Transdermal Route Dr. Michael Horstmann, Acino AG, Aesch (CH).
- Targeted and Personalized Cancer Therapy via Tumor Stroma-Attacking Nanodrugs Dr. Neil P. Desai, Senior Vice President, Global Research & Development, Abraxis BioScience LLC, Los Angeles (USA).
- Glutathione PEGylated Liposomes: a Safe Way to Enhance Drug Delivery Across the Blood-brain Barrier Dr. Marco de Boer, Head of Research, to-BBB technologies BV, Leiden (NL).
- Critical Considerations in Development, Scale-up and Manufacturing of Injectable Nanomedicines Dr. Danny van Hoorn, Program Manager, OctoPlus NV, Leiden (NL).
- NBTXR3, a Real Nanotherapeutic in Phase I development for Patients with Soft Tissue Sarcoma Dr. Laurent Lévy, PhD, CEO of Nanobiotix,Paris (F).
Annual Gathering on Clinical Nanomedicine and Targeted Medicine (Basel June 23-26).
https://www.clinam.org/images/stories/pdf/conference.pdf

For patients affected by pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours (PNET).

item.title: Eckert & Ziegler Radiopharma to Join Octreopharm GmbH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Octreopharm, a private Chinese-German pharma development JV, has a peptide currently in PC development as a potential solution for the detection of neuroendocrine tumors using positron emission tomography (PET). Depending on the radionuclide it is coupled with, it could be used both in diagnosing (gallium-68) and treating (yttrium-90) such tumors. Phase 1 is expected to start towards the end of 2014.
In addition to Eckert & Ziegler AG, several Venture Capital Companies, a number of industry experts and Chinese investor Shaanxi Xinyida Investment Co. Ltd.
Octreopharm is on the lookout for collaborations with pharmaceutical companies which focus on products for personalized medicine and new therapeutic agents.
This move shows a growing interest in radioactively labeled pharmaceuticals for NETs.
Octreopharm's project, still at a very early stage of development, has attracted the interest of one of the world's largest providers of isotope technology for medical, scientific and industrial use.
Source: Eckert & Ziegler AG

item.title: Actavis Considering Selling Western EU Activities
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has mandated Rothschild to advise on the sale of units in Italy, Spain, France, Germany and the Netherlands.
- The units in question have annual sales of slightly over €300M and posted a slight loss. The planned sale comes because these activities haven't met a target of a 20% operating margin.
- To improve profitability after the acquisition of Warner Chilcott (See PharmaWorld10453: Actavis Acquires Warner Chilcott).
Source: the WSJ

item.title: Merz North America Reinforce Dermatology Business
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has acquired deoxyArbutin (skin-lightening agent) from Lasya Inc., and announced a collaboration with Foamix Ltd (to develop and commercialize an innovative medicated topical foam).
Merz North America's ambitions is to become a recognized leader in the treatment of movement disorders, and in aesthetics and dermatology.
Lasya, Incorporated, a 25 million dollar company, has offices in Cincinnati, OH and the Research Triangle Park, NC and is a research-based beauty care corporation that is committed to improving the lives of its customers as well as supporting the Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center. A portion of every sale goes to support medical research for children. The management team of Lasya, Incorporated has a combined total of over eighty years of skin science research and product development experience and together hold over 50 patents and patent applications.
Source: Merz NA

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: World’s First Toxin-free Treatment for Dynamic Wrinkles Approved in Canada
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Myoscience's iovera˚ has received regulatory approval in Canada. The company presented the EU launch of the treatment at the IMCAS in Paris (Jan-Feb 2013), and AMWC in Monaco (April 2013).
In his clinic in Paris, France, Dr. Patrick Trevidic says: “I know from experience that there are patients who have hesitations about using botulinum toxin. They still want to treat their wrinkles : iovera˚ for these patients is a more comfortable option because it injects nothing into the body. .. Best of all the results are seen immediately which is very exciting.”

Dr Yannis Alexandrides is one of the first physicians in the UK to be trained in and offer the new iovera toxin-free wrinkle treatment.

The treatment is based upon myoscience’s platformtechnology, Focused Cold Therapy ™. It works by using the body’s natural response to cold to temporarily relax the facial muscles that cause wrinkles.
The device delivers a precise cold dose to induce only 2nd Degree Wallerian Degeneration (2DWD).
Characteristics: simple, intuitive, IP protected, single patient use tips and reusable hand piece.
Source: Myoscience

Comments
Myoscience has reported that the iovera* treatment is now available from the Vancouver Cosmetic Medicine and Dermatology Clinic, Doctors Alastair and Jean Carruthers and Doctor Shannon Humphrey.
Testimonies
Doctor Jean Carruthers feels iovera˚ will be an important new tool for doctors that want to offer patients options, "We are all familiar with the safety and efficacy of cosmetic neuromodulation using neurotoxins. The iovera˚ technology is a totally new approach to reducing wrinkles by treating nerves with cold. After some months, the nerves recover and retreatment may be desired."
Doctor Shannon Humphrey is enthusiastic to be one of the first to offer the iovera˚ treatment, "iovera provides us with a new alternative to treat forehead wrinkles in a natural way that provides immediate results, something we feel many patients will find appealing."
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (8,3 KB)

Clinical development indications include pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma (ongoing resgistration study in the U.S under SPA / PE for efficacy achieved), neuroblastoma and carcinoid.

item.title: UCB's Shanghai Offices Visited by Chinese Authorities
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company reported that officials were also investigating a "number of other drug companies with operations in the country". The officials were from the State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC), and were seeking information on compliance.
China is increasingly important for big drugmakers, which rely on growth in emerging markets to offset slower sales in Western markets.
IMS Health, which tracks pharmaceutical industry trends, expects China to overtake Japan as the world's second-biggest drugs market behind the United States by 2016.
Source: Thomson One

item.title: IND for Genmab's HuMax(R)-TF-ADC Submitted to FDA
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Patient recruitment in clinical trial is expected to begin this year. A maximum of 78 patients with cancer of the ovary, cervix, endometrium, bladder, prostate, head & neck, esophagus or lung that have failed or are not eligible for standard treatments will be enrolled in the study.
HuMax-TF-ADC is an antibody-drug conjugate (ADC) composed of a human antibody against tissue factor (TF) conjugated to the cytotoxic drug monomethyl auristatin E (MMAE).
HuMax-TF-ADC is being developed for the treatment of solid cancers. TF is an attractive tumor target because of its high expression in a broad range of solid cancers. After binding to TF, HuMax-TF-ADC enters the tumor cells where the cytotoxic agent is specifically released, leading to cell death.
HuMax-TF-ADC was demonstrated to have potent anti-tumor activity in in vivo studies in mouse models in which a diverse panel of patient-derived tumors was assessed. HuMax?TF?ADC was shown to have an acceptable safety profile in non-clinical safety studies.
Genmab is developing HuMax-TF-ADC using Seattle Genetics' ADC technology under an agreement between the companies.
Seattle Genetics may elect to co-develop HuMax-TF-ADC with Genmab at the end of Phase I clinical development.
Source: Genmab

item.title: Novartis Reports Solid Set of Numbers for Q2/H1 2013
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Participants from Novartis
Harry Kirsh, CFO, David Epstein, Pharma, Kevin Buehler, Jeff George, Sandoz, Andrin Oswald, George Gun, Animal Health, Brian McNamara, OTC, and Tim Wright, Head of Development.
Dynamic in China
Filing of LCI699 is planned in 2016 for Cushing. The drug is a new aldosterone synthase inhibitor. Novartis gained access to this programme through the purchase of Speedel AG in 2008. (see ongoing trial @ http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT01331239).
China compliance : " ... Now in terms of compliance obviously we have spent a lot of time and money training from a compliance standpoint and this has been a particular area of focus over the last 24 months. As always we say this all the time that we have thousands of employees and whenever no matter how much training you do there could always be areas of bad behavior. As soon as we find that bad behavior we root it out and we act on it and we would not be any different in China than we would be in any part of the world so I'm confident that as long as the Markets in China continue to grow like they're growing we're going to continue to see growth. Maybe not 25% every quarter but my expectation is we'll be ahead of market".
Countries where Sandoz have experienced a main pricing pressure : " ... In terms of specific countries where we see price erosion I would say it's really year specific in Europe, depends on who takes price cuts. We saw 10% price cut in Switzerland this year. Spain has been hit hard which has gone to a tendering system so that's caused massive double digit price erosion in that market and other years we've seen it in Italy and France and elsewhere. Two other markets that I say where price erosion is a bit higher would be Australia and Canada both impacted by higher Constitution and higher gross to net spreads in terms of price erosion".
D Vasella Contract: " ... I would like Dan to continue his mentoring programs which have been very impact full for a lot of our junior people around the world. You ran the Company for a lot of years, got a lot of good leadership, knowledge and ability and our people get a lot out of it so I've asked him to continue to do that but beyond that obviously, there would not be any involvement because as you read from the Press Release you will not be attending the Board meetings nor getting the Board minutes".
Source: Novartis Webcast and Q2:13 Presentation

item.title: Strong Results of J&J Pharma Business in 2Q:13
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: WW Pharma sales of $7.0 billion for the second quarter represented an increase of 11.7% versus the prior year ($6.3 billion). By product category, Immunology sales (+17.6%), Infectious Diseases (+23.9%), Oncology (+53.2%), and Neurosciences (+0.4%). Zytiga continues strong growth to $395M (from $232M for Q2:12), fueled by December approval of chemo naïve indication (45% of the drug sales), and country rollouts. Business practices in China were reported by management as being "run in a highly compliant manner , with very active compliance program in place".
Key Messages
ZYTIGA Business
In the quarters ZYTIGA achieved operational sales growth of 70% with U.S. sales growing 54% due to very strong market growth of over 20% and increased market share in the combined metastatic castrate resistant prostate cancer market. ZYTIGA has captured over 30% of that market and is up approximately 3.5 points sequentially.
Operational sales outside the U.S. grew 85.2% versus second quarter 2012 and on a sequential basis ZYTIGA was up over 20%. ZYTIGA is approved in more than 80 countries.
Positionning of Zytiga and Aragon's ARN-509
Management reported that " ... We think it’s a great complement to our portfolio. If you look at the great job frankly that our team has been able to do with ZYTIGA, in the launch, regarding the clinical – I should backup. Actually the actual approval of the compound, the ongoing clinical development, very impressive, the commercial penetration that we’ve seen as well as the care programs for patients, we think it represents a significant capability." " ... And now when you complement that with the Aragon compound it will certainly enable us to leverage all of those skills onto a next phase. We think that there could be potentially complementary utilization of both compounds together. And again, as another example of us continuing to really make a difference for patients and for our business in this very exciting oncology area".
Source: J&J Webcast

item.title: Intarcia Has Started Registration Trials of its GLP-1 6/12-Month Implant
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ITCA 650 is a continuous subcutaneous delivery of exenatide in Intarcia's DUROS® delivery device (technology validated for the delivery of leuprolide as Viadur®). The four Ph3 trials (detailed below) will be recruiting approx. 3,000 participants. In 2011, Intarcia selected Quintiles to develop the implant WW. Commercialization partner(s) with significant diabetes expertise is/are sought.
ITCA 650 Characteristics/Description
Technology
http://www.intarcia.com/products-technology/intarcia-platform-technology.html
DUROS® delivery device is a matchstick-size, miniature osmotic pump that is inserted subcutaneously to provide continuous and consistent drug therapy.
Intellectual Property
Patent Protected through 2027.
Trials Details
NCT01455896 - A Study to Evaluate Cardiovascular Outcomes in Patients With Type 2 Diabetes Treated With ITCA 650
ITCA 650 vs placebo; PE will assess CV death, nonfatal MI, nonfatal stroke and unstable angina. Est. completion date: July 2018.
NCT01455857 - A Study to evaluate ITCA 650 for the Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes
ITCA 650 (2 doses) superiority vs placebo; PE will assess change in HbA1c. Est. completion date: July 2014.
NCT01455870- A Study to Evaluate ITCA 650 Compared to Sitagliptin as Add-on Therapy for the Type 2 Diabetes
Comparison of ITCA 650 to Sitagliptin as add-on therapy to Metformin; PE will assess change in HbA1c between Week 52 and Day 0. Est. completion date: July 2014.
NCT01785771 - A Study to Evaluate ITCA 650 for the Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes in Patients with High Baseline HbAc
PE will assess change in HbA1c between Week 39 and Day 0. Est. completion date: September 2014.
