item.title: China Market Primacy for Novartis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an interview with China Daily, Joe Jimenez (CEO) reported that the Chinese market presents unique challenges. He outlined that China importance is impossible to overlook, and added that Novartis is investing a planned $1 billion to construct a new Shanghai R&D center.
Strategic Importance for Novartis
China's role is to provide top-line growth in helping Novartis see returns on R&D investments made in its pipeline.
China Biosimilar Market
Novartis is considering deeper involvement in biosimilars, particularly in China. Imminent patent expiries for costly oncology biotech drugs are creating an opportunity for more modestly-priced biosimilars.
Latest Reference in Traction CI
See Oncology9064: Afinitor (everolimus) Launched in China.
Source: GBI

item.title: Ph3 Trial to Assess Merz' Xeomin in Bilateral Blepharospasm (BEB)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new registration trial which will serve to collect efficacy and safety data of two different doses of the drug in subjects suffering from Bilateral Blephorasm (BEB) who are BTX treatment-naïve. PE will assess change from baseline in Jankovic rating scale severity subscore determined at V4 (Week 6). This study also will substantiate the existing efficacy and safety database for the indication BEB.
Sponsor: Merz Pharm GmbH
BTX treatment-naïve subjects are defined as those who have not received BTX treatment within the last 12 months for the treatment of BEB. This definition aims to avoid bias by comparison of treatment effects in the subject's assessments.

Subjects to receive one injection with Xeomin (NT 201) or placebo at baseline of the placebo-controlled first cycle. Thereafter, all subjects entering the Open-Label Extension Period (OLEX) to receive a second injection of NT 201 (second injection cycle).

n=60

Start date: Aug. 2013 - Completion date: Oct. 2015 / March 2016
Location: Malaysia; India; Sri Lanka; Greece; USA.

item.title: Allergan Launches New Dermal Filler Tailored for the Lips
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Juvéderm® VOLBELLA® with lidocaine lasts up to 12 months in the lips with a single treatment (Eccleston D. Clin, Cosmet & Investig Derma, 2012; 5:1-6). Launched during IMCAS in Paris, the new filler is not only designed for restoring lost lip volume, but also for defining lip contours, treating oral commissures, smoothing fine vertical lines around the lips, and plumping up the marionette lines.
Allergan dedicated the second part of its symposium to Juvéderm® VOLBELLA®, highlighting six main characteristics/advantages:
  • Vycross technology HA 15 mg/ml
  • Specifically designed for lips and perioral
  • Extremely soft and easy to mold
  • Less swelling compared to other lip treatments (Allergan Data on File)
  • Reduced edema potential
  • Significantly increased longevity (12 months)
Poster Presentation

The Juvéderm® VOLBELLA® with Lidocaine study was designed as a real world study to collect efficacy and safety data for volume enhancement and/or correction of asymmetry of the lips in normal subjects requesting aesthetic improvement.

item.title: Registration Trial of Sativex for Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrial.gov is listing a new Phase 3 which is designed to evaluate efficacy and tolerability of Sativex in children (8 to 18 years) with spasticity due to Cerebral Palsy or Traumatic Central Nervous System Injury and have not responded adequately to their existing anti-spasticity medications. PE will assess change from baseline to the end of 12 weeks treatment in mean spasticity 0-10 NRS score.
Sponsor: GW Pharm.
Design: A 12 week randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled,parallel group study followed by a 24-week open-label extension phase.
N= 72
Start date: Sept 2013 / Completion date(s): Dec 2015 / Dec 2016
Location: UK

item.title: The Acromegaly Therapy Area Landscape (2)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: You will find attached an update version of the competitive landscape in acromegaly. We encourage you to contribute to our internal knowledge by evaluating some of the "Key Intelligence Questions" included in the document.
However, no matter what competitive information / soft intelligence you have, please do keep us informed on any key developments in your countries
This slide kit has been created in close collaboration with Scientific Intelligence and the Endocrinology Franchise. Next update is due in Q4:13.
We hope that you will find it a useful tool.

Comments
re: The Acromegaly Therapy Area Landscape (2)
Please see below from J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2013 Aug 22. [Epub ahead of print] Findings show that the octreotide implant maintained reduced blood levels of GH and IGF-1 with continuous octreotide release over 6 months, which was well tolerated.

Efficacy and Safety of an Octreotide Implant in the Treatment of Patients with Acromegaly.

Chieffo C, Cook D, Xiang Q, Frohman LA.

Source

1 Endo Health Solutions, Inc., Clinical Research & Development, Malvern PA, USA;

Abstract

Context:Acromegaly is caused by excessive GH secretion and IGF-1 overproduction. The goals of treatment are to reduce GH and IGF-1 values to normal and relieve associated symptoms.Objective:To demonstrate that octreotide implant (84 mg) is safe and efficacious in patients with acromegaly who were responsive to prior monthly octreotide LAR injections.Design:Phase 3, open-label study. Before treatment, subjects received a stable monthly dose of octreotide LAR injections (10 to 40 mg) for ≥3 months. Randomization was in a 3:1 ratio to either 6-month octreotide implant or monthly octreotide LAR injections.Setting:This was a multicenter, international study conducted in private or institutional practices.Subjects:Enrollment included 163 subjects (aged ≥18 years) with acromegaly.Main Outcome Measure:To evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of the octreotide implant during 24 weeks of treatment.Results:After 24 weeks, the success rate of the implant for maintenance of IGF-1 and GH levels was 86% (95% CI: 80.3%) compared to 84% (95% CI: 73.8%) for octreotide LAR. Serum octreotide concentrations after implant insertion increased within 8 days and peaked between day 14 and 28. Overall safety of the octreotide implant and octreotide LAR were similar. Diarrhea and headache were more frequent with the implant, while cholecystitis and hypertension were more frequent with octreotide LAR.Conclusions:In this pivotal phase 3 study, the octreotide implant maintained reduced blood levels of GH and IGF-1 with continuous octreotide release over 6 months, which was well tolerated.

  1. Acromegaly_Therapy Area Landscape_Final Version July 2013.ppt  (1,1 MB)

item.title: First Patient Treated in a Study of Bellicum's BPX-201 and AP1903 for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Phase I dose escalation trial in patients with metastatic castrate resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) was designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability and clinical outcomes of BPX-201 and AP1903, which incorporate Bellicum's second generation DeCIDe™ immunotherapy technology.
BPX-201 contains the patient’s own matured dendritic cells engineered with the DeCIDe “on switch,” and trained to target prostate cancer cells.
The small molecule drug AP1903 is administered the day after the modified cells have been infused into the patient, activating the “on switch” in the injected cells and marshaling the body’s T cells to attack the cancer.
By waiting until the modified dendritic cells have migrated to nearby lymph nodes before activation, a more potent and durable antigen-specific T cell immune response may result.
Please see http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01823978?term=BPX-201&rank=1
Source: Bellicum Pharm

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Research projects from 5 biopharm companies comprise the 2013 first half of The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research (MJFF) Partnering Program, and are presented directly to industry groups who may wish to invest in further development of the project. Below is the list of the selected drugs.
- Ceregene's clinical research on a gene delivery approach to neurotrophic factors.
- MediGenesis's GDNF.
- NeuroPhage's NPT002 that targets alpha-synuclein.
- Cynapsus' APL-130277, a thin film strip that dissolves under the toungue.
- NeuroDerm's research on continuous administration of levodoppa and carbidopa through a "pump-patch".

item.title: re: GSK Investigating Botox Marketing Practices in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
GSK Investigating Botox Marketing Practices in China 
Comment: Allegations claimed that GSK sales staff used improper tactics to market Botox in China.  ...
Comments :
According to Chinese officials, a probe in Changsha, Shanghai and Zhengzhou found that GSK tried to establish new sales channels and increase drug prices in China by directly bribing GVT officials, pharmaceutical industry associations, hospitals and doctors. GSK staff also reportedly used fake receipts in unspecified tax law violations.
In response to the news, GSK said it is "willing to cooperate with the authorities in this inquiry,". The company noted that it continually monitors its businesses to ensure they meet the company’s compliance procedures. "We have done this in China and found no evidence of bribery or corruption of doctors or government officials," the company said, adding "however, if evidence of such activity whereby sales staff used improper tactics to market Botox (onabotulinumtoxinA), is provided we will act swiftly on it."
Back in June, GlaxoSmithKline said it found no evidence of wrongdoing after concluding aprobe into allegations that the company's sales staff in China were involved in widespread bribery of doctors to prescribe drugs, between 2004 and 2010. Earlier this week, the drugmaker confirmed that it is also investigating claims that sales staff used improper tactics to market Botox (onabotulinumtoxinA) in China.
According to a Credit Suisse Analyst in a note published in 2012, China accounted for less than 3 percent of GlaxoSmithKline’s global sales, so the immediate impact of the latest news was unlikely to be that significant. However, Credit Suisse said the accusations could not be ignored, adding "emerging markets are seen as important for future growth and the China market is going to be one of the biggest markets in the world, and you have to grow in line with the market."
China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) also recently launched a probe into production costs and prices charged at 60 foreign and Chinese pharmaceutical companies, including GSK.
Source : abstracted from a news on FirstWorldPharma published July 12th.

item.title: Bladder Cancer Drug ImmuCyst Available in 2014
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alliance Pharma expects bladder cancer drug ImmuCyst, manufactured by Sanofi SA's vaccines unit, to become available in the second half of 2014.

Production of ImmuCyst was suspended in mid-2012 after mould was found in Sanofi Pasteur's 100-year-old manufacturing plant in Toronto, Canada.

Alliance Pharma, which acquires, markets and distributes pharmaceutical products, said that turnover in the six months ended June 30 rose 4 percent to 22.8 million pounds ($34.07 million).

item.title: re: Three Different Dosage of Xeomin Tested in Spasticity of the Leg(s) in Cerebral Palsy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Three Different Dosage of Xeomin Tested in Spasticity of the Leg(s) in Cerebral Palsy 
Comment; The Phase 3 study is currently recruitng approx. 300 participants (2 to 17 years old) in Estonia. PE will measure change from baseline (Day 1) in the Ashworth Scale (AS) score of plantar flexors at Day 29 of the 1st injection cycle, and Investigator's Global Impression of Change of Plantar Flexor Spasticity Scale (GICS-PF) at Day 29 of the 1st injection cycle.  ...
Design comparable to our study design with a co-primary endpoint between Ashworth and Physician global assessment to satisfy at minimum their US PMR and PMC. There are many more countries included (USA, CZ, D, F., South Africa, Mexico, Australia, Romania, Poland, Turkey etc..). They are using quite a high top dose as compared to Botox for instance. Patients having a re-treatment interval of 12 to 16 weeks could be enrolled in an OL study to receive 4 treatment cycles.

item.title: Three Different Dosage of Xeomin Tested in Spasticity of the Leg(s) in Cerebral Palsy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment; The Phase 3 study is currently recruitng approx. 300 participants (2 to 17 years old) in Estonia. PE will measure change from baseline (Day 1) in the Ashworth Scale (AS) score of plantar flexors at Day 29 of the 1st injection cycle, and Investigator's Global Impression of Change of Plantar Flexor Spasticity Scale (GICS-PF) at Day 29 of the 1st injection cycle.
Trial DetailsNCT01893411
Startd date: June 2013 - Completion: April 2015 / August 2016
Dosage: 16U; 12U; 4U per kg body weight

Comments
Design comparable to our study design with a co-primary endpoint between Ashworth and Physician global assessment to satisfy at minimum their US PMR and PMC. There are many more countries included (USA, CZ, D, F., South Africa, Mexico, Australia, Romania, Poland, Turkey etc..). They are using quite a high top dose as compared to Botox for instance. Patients having a re-treatment interval of 12 to 16 weeks could be enrolled in an OL study to receive 4 treatment cycles.

item.title: Roche Stops Diabetes Drug Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Roche will halt development of aleglitazar partly due to its undesired side effects (affecting organs such as their kidneys and hearts),
Strategic Rationale
As it went into the 7,000-patient late-stage study of aleglitazar, Roche took steps to reduce the possibility that its product might have the same problems as other medicines in the class. It particular, it conducted a renal safety study to ensure its product was free of the kidney problems that undermined AstraZeneca's.

Drugs like aleglitazar are designed to turn on two protein receptors known as PPARs, one that regulates glucose and another lipids. These dual PPAR drugs have long fascinated researchers as a potential way to help diabetics address multiple targets linked to heart disease.
Source: Thomson One

item.title: AstraZeneca Enters Oncology Drug Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In collaboration with the U. of Cambridge and Cancer Research UK, AstraZeneca will investigate tumour mutations and experimental drugs for prostate, pancreatic and other cancers. The pharma company aims to advance its work in the area of personalized healthcare. One of the three projects will test the effectiveness of olaparib and AZD2014 (TOR kinase inhibitor) in high-risk prostate cancer patients.
Strategic Rationale for AZ
- to move its UK-based global R&D centre and corporate HQs to the Cambridge Biomedical Campus by 2016.
Source: First Word

item.title: GSK Investigating Botox Marketing Practices in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allegations claimed that GSK sales staff used improper tactics to market Botox in China.
The WSJ reported that in the so-called Vasily programme, sales staff discussed rewarding doctors for prescribing Botox with cash payments, educational credits and other incentives.
Source: BioCentury

Comments
This is an usual practice in China. Are Botox in aesthetic and therapeutic marketed with the same brand name in China ? if yes, it will be interesting to get information about how could Allergan and GSK distinguish therapeutic and aesthetic Botox's sales in hospitals?
Agree with Brice, particularly since aesthetic and therapeutic indications are on the same label.
Comments :
According to Chinese officials, a probe in Changsha, Shanghai and Zhengzhou found that GSK tried to establish new sales channels and increase drug prices in China by directly bribing GVT officials, pharmaceutical industry associations, hospitals and doctors. GSK staff also reportedly used fake receipts in unspecified tax law violations.
In response to the news, GSK said it is "willing to cooperate with the authorities in this inquiry,". The company noted that it continually monitors its businesses to ensure they meet the company’s compliance procedures. "We have done this in China and found no evidence of bribery or corruption of doctors or government officials," the company said, adding "however, if evidence of such activity whereby sales staff used improper tactics to market Botox (onabotulinumtoxinA), is provided we will act swiftly on it."
Back in June, GlaxoSmithKline said it found no evidence of wrongdoing after concluding aprobe into allegations that the company's sales staff in China were involved in widespread bribery of doctors to prescribe drugs, between 2004 and 2010. Earlier this week, the drugmaker confirmed that it is also investigating claims that sales staff used improper tactics to market Botox (onabotulinumtoxinA) in China.
According to a Credit Suisse Analyst in a note published in 2012, China accounted for less than 3 percent of GlaxoSmithKline’s global sales, so the immediate impact of the latest news was unlikely to be that significant. However, Credit Suisse said the accusations could not be ignored, adding "emerging markets are seen as important for future growth and the China market is going to be one of the biggest markets in the world, and you have to grow in line with the market."
China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) also recently launched a probe into production costs and prices charged at 60 foreign and Chinese pharmaceutical companies, including GSK.
Source : abstracted from a news on FirstWorldPharma published July 12th.

Perhaps Astellas' long term goal is to get different indications for Xtandi, and stop promoting Eligard ?

item.title: Afinitor (everolimus) Launched in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA) has approved the launch of Afinitor for renal cell carcinoma (RCC), for patients who fail to respond to either Sunitinib or Sorafenib.
Dr. Guo Jun, Renal Cancer and Melanoma Department Director at Beijing Cancer Hospital, pointed out that surgery is currently the dominant renal cancer treatment because although it can be detected with abdominal ultrasonography, it does not respond to radiotherapy, chemotherapy or hormonotherapy. He added that advances in biology and immunology may lead to renal cancer treatment breakthroughs.
Source: GBI

The assessment is line with IQWiG's April assessment.
Astellas and J&J will now negotiate prices for Zytiga with Germany's Statutory Health Insurance Funds Association (GKV-Spitzenverband).

The product already has been registered in 23 EU country, and launched in Spain, where GP Pharm has its own oncology sales force.
GP Pharm's lack of EU wide commercial presence may involve the search of a partner for the launch and distribution of Lutrate.

  • In parallel, national approval procedures are expected to be submitted in France, Switzerland and Norway. (source: http://www.gp-pharm.com/news.php?noticia=67).

item.title: Grant to Help Accelerate Industrial Process Specific to Nanodrugs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BioAlliance Pharma received €4.3 million from bpifrance (ex OSEO) to accelerate the industrial development of Livatag® (doxorubucin nanoparticle in ongoing Ph3 for primary liver cancer). Of note in the company's pipeline, Irinotecan TransDrug(TM) in early development for rare digestive cancer.
According to its BD section, BioAlliance is seeking partners to license-out Livatag®:
  • reformulated doxorubicin
  • has just passed its second Data Safety Monitoring Board (DSMB) assessment.
  • At Ph2, an OS benefit of 17 months was shown in 28 patients, although serious respiratory side effects meant the trial was stopped early.
  • The new iv administration route approved for the Ph3 trial is so far proving safe.
  • The next safety datapoint will be the third DSMB meeting in November 2013.
  • Preliminary Ph3 RELIVE data are due in H116.
- HQ: Paris, France.
- founded in 1997 and today has currently 50 employees.
- listed on Eurolist Paris (now NYSE Euronext) in 2005 and has raised €87m since IPO.
- dedicated to cancer and supportive care treatment.
- identifies and develops innovative products for orphan oncology and specialty markets.
- marketed product: Loramyc/Oravig, a mucoadhesive gingival tablet for the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis in adults.
- pipeline product portfolio includes Sitavir/Sitavig for the treatment of recurrent labial herpes in immunocompetent patients and Fentanyl Lauriad for the treatment chronic cancer pain.
- orphan oncology products portfolio includes Livatag for liver cancer is in Ph3 clinical stage; Validive which is in Ph2 clinical stage and AMEP for invasive melanoma, which is in Ph1.
Source: Edison; BioAlliance Pharma

item.title: Comparison of Two Botulinum Toxins for Masseter Hypertropy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The findings of the the 24-week double-blind randomized split-face study show that both BTX-A and BTX-B are effective. BTX-B at a dose ratio of 1:70 has a comparable efficacy but a shorter duration of action than BTX-A.
This is a non-industry sponsored study.
Dermatology. 2013 Jun 14. [Epub ahead of print]

RimabotulinumtoxinB versus OnabotulinumtoxinA in the Treatment of Masseter Hypertrophy: A 24-Week Double-Blind Randomized Split-Face Study.

Lee DH, Jin SP, Cho S, Feneran A, Youn CS, Won CH, Park GH, Kim BW, An J, Chang SE, Lee MW.

Department of Dermatology, Seoul National University College of Medicine, Institute of Human-Environment Interface Biology, Seoul National University, Seoul, Korea.

Background: Masseter hypertrophy can be ameliorated by botulinum toxin.

Objective: To compare the efficacy and safety of RimabotulinumtoxinB (BTX-B) and OnabotulinumtoxinA (BTX-A) in the treatment of masseter hypertrophy.

Methods: Sixteen women with bilateral masseter hypertrophy received single injections of BTX-A or BTX-B at a dose ratio of 1:50 or 1:70 in a 24-week double-blind randomized split-face study.

Results: Both BTX-A and BTX-B produced significant improvements in masseter hypertrophy. The maximum volume reduction, as determined by computed tomography scanning, at week 12 was comparable between BTX-A and BTX-B at a dose ratio of 1:70 (15.6 and 14.2%, respectively). At week 24, only masseters treated with BTX-A maintained a significant volume reduction. Investigator ratings and patient satisfaction scores paralleled objective computed tomography measurements.

Conclusion: Both BTX-A and BTX-B are effective in the treatment of masseter hypertrophy. BTX-B, at a dose ratio of 1:70, has a comparable efficacy but a shorter duration of action than BTX-A.


Comments
This indication has been widely used by Korean doctors. It seems that Allergan has organised an ad board to discuss on this indication.
As previously discussed we shall be moving quickly in dscussing and potentially designing a trial for the use of Dysport in this condition which is of high interest in the Asian population.

Is masseter hypertrophy considered as a medical indication ? according to publication, 75% of patients with bruxism have masseter hypertrophy. The prevalence of Bruxism is estimated at 5-8%.

Samsung Securities estimates it at KRW47b (vs KRW75b for the Chinese toxin market), taking 62% of the total facial injections market.
The 2 fillers should receive sales authorization in 3Q, starting sales in 4Q.
Huadong Medicine Ningbo is a Chinese domestic player that focuses on the distribution of plasma derivatives, vaccines and other drugs.

Indication: Correction of facial wrinkles and folds
Dosage/Adm.: mid dermis (Classic); deep dermis (Volume)
Shelf Life: 24 months
Restylane by Galderma Pharma and Juvederm by Allergan.

item.title: New Appointment at Merz North America
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Greg Besase has been appointed VP, dermatology. He joined Merz in December 2012 as Director of Marketing, Dermatology and has served as the interim head of the U.S. Dermatology Business Unit since February 2013.
  • Onmel™ prescription medicine used to treat fungal infections of the toenails.
  • Naftin® to treat interdigital tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and tinea corporis caused by the organism Trichophyton rubrum.
  • Aluvea® for strenthening nails.
Professional - Prior to joining Merz, Greg worked for Stiefel, a GSK Company, for nine years. Greg held several positions with Stiefel including the Head of US Dermatology Marketing, Global Commercial Lead, Sr. Product Manager (US), and District Sales Trainer.
Prior to Stiefel, he worked for ITS Technologies, Inc. as a Regional Manager and later as a Business Development & Territory Manager.
Prior to ITS Technologies, Inc., Greg also held sales & marketing management roles with Advanced Programming Resources, Inc. and AIM Executive, Inc. Greg brings over 19 years of sales and marketing experience to his role as head of Merz’s Dermatology business unit.
Education - Greg earned his Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration from the University of Toledo in Toledo, Ohio. He is based in Merz’s North American headquarters in Greensboro, North Carolina.
Source: Merz

item.title: Priority Review Given to Roche's Alternative to Rituxan in the US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last week EU regulators cleared 2 biosimilar versions of Remicade, which represents a risk for Roche as all three of its top selling drugs (Avastin; Herceptin; and Rituxan/MabThera) are monoclonal antibody biologics. Together they generated 2012 sales of approx. $3.8 bilion in EU (10% of total sales). The company hopes GA-101 will help fend off cheaper competition for Rituxan, which loses patent protection in Europe later this year.
- FDA has accepted the company's BLA and granted Priority Review for GA101 in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
- currently being investigated in a large clinical program, including multiple head-to-head Phase III studies versus rituximab in indolent non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (NHL) and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
President Obama did authorize the FDA to approve biosimilars in the country when he signed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) in 2010.
However, the act itself was subject to a court case regarding its constitutionality and it was only in mid-2012 when a Supreme Court judgment ruled in favor of the act, thereby clearing the pathway for biosimilar approvals in country.
As of February 2013, no applications for biosimilar approvals were received by the FDA, and even though reports suggest that preparations to do so may already be underway at some firms, we can expect the U.S. to continue lagging Europe in the approval process.
The more time it takes for biosimilars to enter the U.S. market, the longer Roche’s drugs will dominate the market.
Source: Trefis; Roche

The ADT Competitive Area Landscape 
Comment: As part of CI ongoing commitment to the 'Therapy Area Landscape' service, you will find attached an overview of the Decapeptyl(R) competitive landscape, with the strategy of the key players, and a detailed profile of their product candidates.  ...
Regarding Zytiga intelligence in Ireland suggests that there are 4 centres in Ireland talking part in clinical trials. We can confirm only Cork University Hospital and Tallaght Hospital, Dublin at this time.
At present, Cork University Hospital are also testing the effectiveness of Zytiga on women with breast cancer. There is thought to be a good rationale for using Zytiga against advanced breast cancer since this can be androgen driven as well as estrogen driven and Zytiga cuts off the supplies of both androgens and estrogens reducing their levels to almost zero.

item.title: Medicis and Mentor Sign Five-Year Aesthetic Collaboration
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Both companies have formed a collaboration to enter certain of their non-reimbursed products into a combined physician loyalty program, called the M2VP (Medicis-Mentor Valued Partner) program. Interesting take from analysts @ Barclays reports that, "the collaboration suggests that J&J/Mentor is not close to commercializing its own botulinum toxin ... While the partnership represents a competitive challenge that Allergan would need to cope, it would be a silver lining if implies that the company’s flagship Botox franchise won’t face a new competitive entrant in the near future".
What Does the Program Offer ?
Territory: U.S-based for now, but could be expanded.
The program will :
- extend the offerings of Medicis' recently launched MVP Program to include the MENTOR(R) line breast implant products.
- offer numerous incentives that reward utilization of various products across the Mentor and Medicis portfolios.
- ...
Allergan’s loyalty program
- provides discounts for achieving certain volume levels.
Testimony
Dr. Tracy Hankins, a board certified plastic surgeon in Nevada, "I have utilized products from both companies for years and now I can earn valuable rebates and rewards in one easy to understand loyalty program."
Source: Valeant; Barclays

item.title: Daewoong on Track to Export Care Tropin to Russia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Care Tropin pen syringe export has expanded to about 10 countries in just 2 years after its launch, the company reported.
Design & Advantages
It has the reset button for easy dose adjustment and was designed for safe self-injection.
This easy-to-use syringe can find applications in bio-medicines such as growth hormone or insulin which needs to be self-injected over the long-term.
Countries
Currently, Daewoong is exporting the Care Tropin pen syringe to 7 countries, including Indonesia, Vietnam, Iran, and completed the utility model right registration of the syringe in Taiwan and China in April and December, 2012, respectively.

item.title: Enrollment of Neurocrine' NBI-98854 for Tardive Dyskenesia is Complete
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The final subject will randomize this week. Topline data from the placebo-controlled portion of the Ph2b trial is expected in approximately ten weeks.
The design of this twelve-week Ph2b study is a randomized, parallel, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of 120 subjects with moderate to severe tardive dyskinesia and underlying schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
VMAT2 is a protein concentrated in the human brain that is primarily responsible for re-packaging and transporting monoamines (dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin, and histamine) in pre-synaptic neurons.
NBI-98854 may also be useful in other disorders such as Huntington's chorea, schizophrenia, and Tourette's syndrome.
Source: Neurocrine

item.title: Pfizer and Amgen Interested in Acquering Biocad > $1 Billion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Any company acquiring Biocad will gain access expertise in the Russian market as well as experience delivering biologic products from the clinic to the market. The company is the leading player in terms of monoclonal antibody drug development.
Foreign investment in the Russian biosimilar market still in its infancy.
HQ: St. Petesburg
Competitive Advantages over domestic players: utilisation of bacterial and mammalian based cell culture techniques.
Pipeline: focused on biosimilar and next-in-class monoclonal anitbodies (the company is known to develop biosimilar versions of Roche's Avastin, Herceptin and Rituxan).
Offices: China; India; Brazil (focus on expanding its commercial footprint in Southeast Asia, and Latin America).
Value: approx $2.1 billion.
Local expertise critical for success.
No firm regulatory framework for the approval of biosimilars.
Interchangeability of products for originator brands occurs freely once a biosimilar is launched.
Trials for new biosimilars are now required.
Roche is the leading provider of onco products to the Russian market (source: Credit Suisse).
AstraZeneca, Novartis, Novo Nordisk and Sanofi hae all invested in the construction of new domestic manufacturing sites since 2010.
Source: FirstWord

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Onyx Still Considering Selling Itself
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: After the rejection of the Amgen offer (approx. $10 billion), Onyx is "actively exploring" a merger partner. Management said Amgen's cash offer of $120 a share, which represents a premium of about 38% to the company's Friday closing price, "significantly undervalued" its prospects.
- Amgen has been looking for new ways to boost its product pipeline as sales for its flagship anemia drugs Aranesp and Epogen have been in a decline for years because of usage restrictions and safety concerns.
- Acquisition would have bolstered Amgen’s oncology pipeline.
Onyx sells Nexavar, a treatment for liver and kidney cancer, as well as colon cancer drug Stivarga in partnership with Bayer AG .
Last July, Onyx launched sales of blood cancer drug Krypolis for multiple myeloma after failure of at least 2 therapies. (sales of $64mn in FY12 are expected to grow to over $265mn in FY13 and reach nearly $485mn by FY14. Sales in 2016 are forecast to be nearly $975mn).
Large pharmaceutical companies have increasingly been looking to acquire smaller biotech firms to gain access to new drugs, often cancer drugs which can command high prices, as they face significant revenue losses stemming from expired patents.

item.title: Positive Opinion Granted in EU to Dendreon's PROVENGE®
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The CHMP will make a final recommendation to the European Commission (EC) within the coming months on the marketing authorization application for PROVENGE® in the EU. A regulatory decision is anticipated from the EC in H2 2013.
Treatment of asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic metastatic (non-visceral) castrate resistant prostate cancer in male adults in whom chemotherapy is not yet clinically indicated.
John H. Johnson said, "This recommendation represents a significant milestone for Dendreon as we advance the global market opportunity for PROVENGE®. We are finalizing our plans for a capital-efficient launch in Europe, including evaluating our partnering options ...".
Source: Dendreon

item.title: Celltrion and Hospira to Sell First Copies of J&J's Remicade
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The European Commission should give the two companies approval to market their versions, called Remsima and Inflectra, for the same medical conditions for which Remicade is marketed. The EMA’s recommendations are the final stage before the European Commission, the European Union’s executive arm, approves or rejects a drug for sale to patients in the 27-nation region.
The decision clears the way for biosimilar versions of other monoclonal antibodies, which account for some of the world’s best-selling medicines.
Same as Remicade: RA; UC; ankylosing spondylitis, CD, psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.
- Remsima will be more than 30% cheaper than the original drug, according to Kim Hyoung Ki (senior VP and CFO at Celltrion).
Source: Bloomberg

Comments
European Commission approved Inflectra (infliximab), making the product the first biosimilar monoclonal antibody therapy authorised in the EU.
Savings Coming from Three Countries
Hospira suggested that the launch of biosimilar monoclonal antibody products in Europe is expected to deliver savings of up to 20.4 billion euros ($27 billion) by 2020, with the greatest savings coming from France, Germany and the UK.
Approvals in the US & Japan
At the time of the CHMP's recommendation, Celltrion said it was planning to seek approval of Inflectra in Japan later this year, while an application in the US is possible in 2015.
On Feb.16th Hospira announced additional launches of Inflectra, the 1st biosimilar mAb, in major EU markets (Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Spain and Sweden). The drug has already been launched in CEE, and some smaller Western European markets due to earlier patent expiry, and has already been prescribed to treat patients in all its licensed indications.
The drug covers several indications, and is indicated for the treatment of RA, psoriatric arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, adult and ped IBD (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis), and plaque psoriasis.
Europe - With the launch of the product in these new markets, Inflectra is now available in 24 EU countries
USA - Hospira's partner, Celltrion, has also submitted an application to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for biosimilar infliximab.
Mundipharma is launching its biosimilar Remsima in Germany, Italy, Britain, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, following expiry of relevant Remicade patents. Hospira is to sell its product Inflectra in markets including Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Spain and Sweden. Another test for biosimilars is looming in the United States, where a FDA advisory committee will decide on March 17 whether to recommend Celltrion's biosimilar version of Remicade.
Copies of Remicade have been on sale for several months in some smaller European markets, such as Norway, but the move into major economies is a big step forward for products that could disrupt the multibillion-dollar biotechnology industry.

Jorgen Jahnsen, professor of medicine and gastroenterology at the University of Oslo, said that in Norway the use of biosimilar infliximab had already enabled the healthcare system to make considerable savings.
source: thomsonOne

item.title: Intelligence Review From ENDO 2013
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Additional data from the extension study of Phase 3 Pasireotide LAR in acromegaly confirmed suppression of GH (<2.5µg/L) and IGF-1 was maintained over 25 months and Pasireotide LAR was found to hold promise as a treatment option for patients with acromegaly inadequately controlled with octreotide LAR.
The Endocrine Society (ENDO) congress was held at the Moscone Conference Center in San Francisco (June 2013). The congress was attended by a Consultant who provided Ipsen with the below overview.
Octreolin Intelligence Gathered
1. Two medical representatives confirmed that data from the phase 3 study of Octreolin in Acromegaly will be released at the end of 2013. FDA will review the data to decide whether a trial will be necessary in the USA. The lack of participation by the US in the phase 3 trial of Octreolin in acromegaly remains unclear. One US KOL believes the reason for the delay was due to financial concerns by the company. The general consensus by the majority of KOLs was that the FDA will not approve Octreolin unless it has been tested in the US.
2. The representatives at the Genentech booth stressed that the company has a successful endocrinology franchise which Roche promised to build on when acquiring the company 2 years ago. Octreolin will be a way of expanding Roche’s oncology franchise whilst also building on Genentech’s existing endocrinology franchise
Long Acting Octreotide from DongKook
An Observational, Comparative Trial In Patients With Active Acromegaly Receiving A New Long-Acting Octreotide Formulation who Were Previously Treated With The Original Octreotide Formulation (Sandostatin Lar) - Author: Dr. Wilson Gallardo, Neuroendocrinology Unit, (Unidad De Neuroendocrinología), Guillermo Almenara-Irigoyen National Hospital, Lima, Peru
The new long-acting octreotide formulation is a generic monthly depot from DongKook (Korea). The author stated that the generic formulation had not been properly evaluated and noted that high levels of octreotide were detected during the first week which steadily decreased to no detectable levels by week 4.
See Endocrinology7384: SMNE Rejects DongKook's Octreotide LAR for Acromegaly.
Poster (MON-4393) described an observational comparative trial in patients with active acromegaly receiving a new long acting octreotide formulation previously treated with Sandostatin LAR. The study was undertaken in Peru where the drug has been introduced in the market. The results showed that of the 18 patients enrolled, 77.8% (n=14) had normalised IGF-1 values following Sandostatin LAR. However following treatment with new long acting octreotide, only 38% (n=7) of patients had normalised IGF-1. The clinical course of patients did not improve with the new long acting octreotide, uncontrolled patients showed greater evidence of disease activity. Overall 44.4% of patients (n=8) receiving new octreotide agent experienced adverse events which is twice the amount observed with Sandostatin LAR (22% n=4).
Novartis Summary
Novartis had a notable presence at the meeting, the focus being on the introduction of Signifor (pasireotide) as a new treatment for Cushing’s Disease, both at the booth and also at an evening symposium entitled “Cushing’s Disease: When Surgery Fails” where three keynote speakers discussed the problems in diagnosis of Cushing’s Syndrome, radiation treatment and advances in medical therapy.
  • A phase III study evaluating Pasireotide LAR in Cushing’s Disease has just started with patient recruitment. The study finish date is estimated at 2016.
  • Intelligence gained from the Novartis medical representatives would not confirm either way whether the technology from Camurus would be used for pasireotide.
Key messages from the symposium:
  • Lynette Nieman, MD (NICHD, NIH) described the plethora of signs and symptoms of Cushing’s disease and the caveats associated with current tests used for diagnosis of Cushing’s disease (UFC, salivary cortisol, dexamethasone suppression test).
  • John Suh, MD (Cleveland Clinic) described the various radiation modalities used for treating pituitary adenomas, Cushing’s Disease and Nelson’s syndrome.
  • Stephan Petersenn, MD (ENDOC Center for Endocrine Tumours, Germany) presented a summary of the key advances in medical management of Cushing’s Disease. These included: Metyrapone and LC1699 (inhibitor of 11β-Hydroxylase) where a proof of concept study was presented at ENEA 2012; carbegoline; pasireotide (data from phase 3 registration trial published in N Engl J Med 2012; 366 914-924) and Mifepristone (RU-486) a progesterone antagonist with glucocorticoid receptor antagonist activity which is licensed to control hyperglycaemia in Cushing’s syndrome in the US.
  • Pasireotide: always follow up with biochemical tests to exclude conditions such as adrenal insufficiency. If patients do not show any improvement after 1-2 months of pasireotide treatment, then discontinue as probable non responders.
  • Mifepristone: disadvantage- there is no biochemical marker to monitor efficacy of drug. Rely on clinical symptoms
  • See PDF for slide booklet provided by NVS - attached
Pasireotide Posters Overview - Acromegaly
Poster SUN-88 was entitled “Inhibition of GH and IGF-1 is maintained with Pasireotide LAR and octreotide LAR in Patients with Acromegaly: 12 month Extension Phase of a double-blind, multicenter, randomised Phase III study”, presented by M. Sheppard (UK). full poster can be viewed at http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=d6067
In a randomised, 12 month core study, 358 medically naïve pts with acromegaly were randomised 1:1 to PAS LAR 40mg/28 days or OCT LAR 20mg/28 days. At month 12, 120 pts continued on their randomised therapy in an extension phase and were evaluated in this analysis.
The second featured poster SUN-89 was entitled: “Pasireotide LAR and Octreotide LAR Normalize Prolactin Levels in Patients with Acromegaly and Hyperprolactinemia: Results from a randomised, double-blind, 12-month, Phase III study” Colao A et al. Full poster can be viewed at
Results below:
A key poster SUN 95 entitled: “Improvement of Biochemical Control in Patients with Acromegaly Switched from Octreotide LAR to Pasireotide LAR: Crossover Extension to a double-blind, multicenter, randomised, Phase III study”, by Freda P et al, suggested that pasireotide LAR holds promise as a treatment option for patients with acromegaly inadequately controlled with octreotide LAR. Of the 81 patients inadequately controlled with octreotide LAR who switched to pasireotide LAR, 14 (17.3%) had biochemical control 12 months after crossover. Of the 38 patients inadequately controlled with pasireotide LAR who switched to octreotide LAR, none had biochemical control 12 months after crossover. The full poster can be accessed on http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=dffab
Pasireotide Poster Review- Cushing’s Disease
“Evaluation of Late-night Salivary Cortisol during 12 months of Pasireotide Treatment in patients with Cushing’s Disease”, Biller BMK et al. Full poster can be viewed at http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.aspx?doc=49ff9
“Improvements in the Clinical Signs and symptoms of Cushing’s Disease following 12 month’s treatment with Pasireotide are not restricted to patients who achieve UFC Control”, Pivonello R etal. Full poster can be viewed at http://novartis.medicalcongressposters.com/Default.asox?doc=354b2

item.title: DCVax-Direct Progresses in Ph1/2 Trial for All Solid Tumor Cancers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Northwest Biotherapeutics has announced that its 60-patient Ph1/2 clinical trial of DCVax-Direct for all inoperable solid tumor cancers has been initiated at the U. of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas. Other sites in the US and UK to follow. PE will assess number of patients with AEs.
DCVax-Direct offers a potential new treatment option for the many clinical situations in which patients' tumors are considered inoperable either because of the location or type of cancer, or because of the spread of multiple tumors.
A large number of patients with lung, colon, pancreatic, liver, ovarian, melanoma, head and neck, and other cancers such as sarcomas face this situation today, and it carries a bleak prognosis.
http://www.nwbio.com/product_candidates_platforms.php
PI: Dr. Vivek Subbiah, MD (Assistant Professor in the Department of Investigational Cancer Therapeutics, Division of Cancer Medicine) programs),
Recruitment: groups or “cohorts” of patients with numerous different types of cancers, including pancreatic, colon, liver, melanoma, and various other cancers
Design: In the Ph1 stage, the trial will test various dose levels of DCVax-Direct.
The trial will then proceed directly into the Ph2 stage to test the efficacy of the DCVax-Direct treatment.
The primary endpoint for measurement of efficacy will be tumor regression (i.e., shrinkage or elimination). As is standard with Ph1/2, this trial will not be blinded. Accordingly, it is anticipated that early results of the trial may be emerging throughout the remainder of 2013.
The Company also previously received clearance from the FDA for a 612-patient Ph3 trial in prostate cancer, and clearance from the FDA for Ph1/2 trials in multiple other cancers. The Company also conducted a Ph1/2 trial with DCVax for metastatic ovarian cancer together with the University of Pennsylvania.
Source: Northwest Biotherapeutics

item.title: New Data Confirms miR-34 is an Important Potential Target for Variety of Cancers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The data are published in Molecular Therapy and reveals a novel mechanism through which miR-34 exerts its tumor suppressor function in cancers. Mirna is currently conducting a Ph1 of MRX34, a miR-34-based therapy and the first microRNA mimic to advance into a human clinical trial.
The data published in the paper entitled: “TP53-independent function of miR-34a via HDAC1 and p21CIP1/WAF1” demonstrate that the tumor suppressive activity of miR-34 is the same in p53-positive and p53-negative cancer cells.
The study further revealed the existence of a p53-independent pathway by which miR-34 induces the expression of p21, a potent tumor suppressor inhibiting uncontrolled cellular proliferation. The endogenous level of p21 was shown to be critical for maximal miR-34 activity.
See Oncology8944: Mirna is First to Advance MicroRNA into the Clinic for Cancer. - The Ph1 focuses on patients with unresectable primary liver cancer or metastatic cancer with liver involvement.
Source: Mirna

item.title: PeptiDream and Pfizer Mutually End Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: PeptiDream has reported that it and Pfizer mutually terminated a 2010 deal (which objectives was to discover macrocyclic peptides to link to the pharma's CovX-Bodies).
PeptiDream retains rights to compounds discovered under the deal, inclusing macrocyclic peptides the company reported are "standalones", and sait it plans to "take them forward and potentially partnered them".
Pfizer acquired CoVx Pharm in 2007 for the CovX Body technology, which linked peptides to a single antibody as a scaffold to allow half-life extension and bioavailability.

item.title: SMNE Rejects DongKook's Octreotide LAR for Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to H. Dumont (Endocrinology Franchise) we have got some strategic feedback on DongKook's Octreotide LAR. In a letter sent by the Mexican National Endocrinology Society (SMNE- Sociedad Mexicana de Nutricion y Endocrinologia) to its members, it was outlined the "very bad quality" of the drug, a reduced efficacy, frequent AEs, and significant differences in the formulation (vs Sandostalin LAR). The last paragraph concluded the rejection of the generic for "patient good's". Additional details are provided below.
(Full letter attached)
On Oct. 13 2012, Dr Jose Athie and Dr Nelson de Franco representatives from Novartis Oncology presented the recently approved Octreotide LAR from DongKook. Representatives from the SMNE, Dr Francisco Velazquez as ell as Dr Wilson Gallardo, investigator of the Peruvian study, attended the meeting.
The objective was to discuss the recently approval of the drug by COFEPRIS (Comisión Federal para la Protección contra Riesgos Sanitarios).
Dr Gallardo presented the preliminary results on 18 patients (10 males + 8 females) - (see attached) Number of reported SEs is higher with DongKook's octreotide LAR (erythematous dermatitis, abdominal pain, vomiting and 1 case of severe bronchspasm).
It was reported that the DongKook's formulation is
More importantly, according to analysis done by Novartis .
  • Peru - see Endocrinology6946: Dongkook Registers Octreotide In Peru.
  • Chili - the product is registered.
  • Mexico - approved in 2012; already available in some public hospitals (although doctors are 'not happy').
  • .

item.title: First Patient Enrolled in Enzalutamide Global Ph2 for Breast Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medivation is conducting this study under its agreement with Astellas. The results from the Ph 1 study in breast cancer will be presented at an upcoming scientific conference.
Design: open label, single-arm, multicenter trial
Recruitment: approximately 80 patients with AR-positive, TNBC
Location: United States, Canada and Europe.
PE: clinical benefit rate, defined as the proportion of patients with a best response of complete response, partial response or stable disease at ≥ 16 weeks.
Protocol: All patients will receive enzalutamide at a dose of 160 mg to be taken orally once daily.

item.title: Lexicon Presents Diabetes Data at ADA
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Key presentations include the PC data on LX2761 designed to reduce glucose absorption from GI tract, and the reduction of blood pressure and weight loss of LX4211.
Oral presentation titled “LX2761, an SGLT1 Inhibitor Restricted to the Intestine, Improves Glycemic Control in Mice.”
  • LX2761 resulted in no urinary glucose excretion in mice while showing delayed intestinal glucose absorption and increased postprandial GLP-1 levels in mice, both alone and synergistically with the DPP-4 inhibitor sitagliptin. Notably, blood glucose excursions after an oral glucose challenge were still decreased 15 hours after oral LX2761 administration. Finally, LX2761 improved glycemic control in STZ-diabetic mice and in the KKAy mouse model of type 2 diabetes, as measured by reductions in hemoglobin A1c and oral glucose tolerance test results.
Oral presentation titled “LX4211, a Dual Inhibitor of Sodium Glucose Transporters SGLT1 and SGLT2, Reduces Blood Pressure in Patients with Type 2 Diabetes.”
  • LX4211 lowers blood pressure to a greater extent in those patients who are in the greatest need of treatment, that is, those patients with hypertension. Furthermore, patients with normal blood pressure showed little or no change on LX4211treatment, a promising finding in regard to future development of LX4211.

item.title: Ingram to Lead Allergan's Global Commercial Operations
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has named Douglas Ingram as President of the company. He will report directly to D. Pyott and be responsible for a broad portfolio of pharmaceutical, consumer and medical device products. The company is facing the LEVADEX complete response letter (approval likely to be deferred until Q4 13), the DARPin set-back in Ph2 and now the forthcoming generic impact on RESTASIS for dry eye (#2 drug in the portfolio).

Allergan expects sales of $850M to $890M for the drug in 2013.

Served as Executive VP and President EU, Africa, and Middle-East. In this role he was responsible for Allergan's regional pharma and medical device operations, with a focus on strategic planning, sales and marketing, development and general management.
Before joining Allergan in 1996 he was an attorney with Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher from 1998, practicing in the area of complex commercial litigation.
Graduated magna cum laude with a Bachelor of Science degree from Arizona State U. in 1985.
Source: Allergan

item.title: ASCO NET Intelligence - Part Two
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Long term survival data from patients on the PROMID study showed no OS benefit (not a pre-specified endpoint) and the Pasireotide LAR vs Octreotide LAR in patients with Metastatic NETs with disease related symptoms inadequately controlled by SSAs did not meet its endpoint - symptom control at 6 months.
Although some interesting sessions, from the data presented at ASCO, we can say that nothing was practice changing with regards to NET.
The key takeaways are as follows:
  • Octreotide is still SOC for NETs
We are awaiting RADIANT 4 and S0518 study results to asses the role of everolimus and bevacizumab in NET (this study is closed and we are awaiting data).
  • Temsirolimus/bevacizumab data are encouraging in PNETs

- Awaiting CALGB80701 and biomarker analysis

  • Pasireotide use in NET is unclear and a need for ‘cleaner data’ is required
  • PRRT is becoming more exciting in the US

- With both of these drugs, a call out for targeting tumor receptor types and downstream signaling pathways is needed

Abby B. Siegel detailed a number of relevant posters, providing us with a nice summary of the data. Below are the captured highlights of her talk.
Abby began by providing us with a summary of the recent Phase II data in NET highlighting that for asymptomatic, low tumor burden patients, watchful waiting or octreotide is appropriate and octreotide is also considered with clinically symptomatic or progressive disease with other options including hepatic regional therapy, surgery, everolimus or cytoxic therapy.
Next she discussed Rudolf Arnold poster covering long term survival data from patients on the PROMID study (whether the antiproliferative response in patients with low (≤ 10%) hepatic tumor load has an affect on overall survival). Patients included in the PROMID trial were followed until January 2013 at least once a year. This study showed no OS benefit although, survival was not a pre-specified endpoint and cross over was allowed. OS in the placebo arm was 7 years, providing us with a benchmark.
Results of the study: 41 of 85 patients died until January 2013. 19 in the octreotide and 22 in the placebo arm. Median OS for all 85 patients was 85 months, “not reached” in the O arm and 84 months in the P arm (p=0.59, HR=0.85 [CI 0.46; 1.56]).
Moving onto PNETs, Abby described Everolimus and Sunitinib data which resulted in the respective approvals
The next study, Hobday et al, asked the important question of could a doublet of MTOR inhibitor (TEM) and anti-angiogenic (BEV) improve outcomes in PNET?
Co-primary endpoints were RR, 6 month PFS and was a multicenter, single arm phase II study. Inclusion criteria included progression within 7 months by RECIST (investigator assessed) and scans Q 8 weeks. 11 patients remain on the trial. The single agent activity of BEV in PNET is being explored in an additional cohort of 25pts on this trial.
PFS was similar to the approved agents but the RR was incredible at 41%
Waterfall plot of best responders
She then theorized it would be good to combine the approved agents for PNETs but they showed toxicity in phase I studies. On the other hand, Tem + Bev phase I results were promising (with the PFS is similar to the single agents). Therefore, the Tem + Bev is interesting and we need further data to understand effects in PNET with this combination. Especially since we have seen unexpected tox with these agents in phase II studies such as TORAVA in RCC patients
Wrapping up, she defined the next steps in PNET as
  • A need for predictive biomarkers to select pts, mentioning FGF 4R and P-AKT both which are being investigated at Anderson
  • Results of the Everolimus + Octerotide +/- Bev in PNET to understand MTOR inhibitors + Bev
  • Define the role of alkylating agents in PNET: capecitabine, TMZ and streptozosin
Moving on to Pasireotide,
Poster One: Pasireotide LAR vs Octreotide LAR in pts with Metastatic NETs with disease related symptoms inadequately controlled by SSAs. The study was stopped early because it demonstrated futility in symptom control and the results presented are based on 110 pts (216 were planned) before study termination
The study was negative for the primary endpoint —symptom control at 6 months. Although, there was a trend towards improved disease control (secondary endpoint — OR 1.96, p=0.09) and an unplanned analysis suggested a PFS benefit for Pasireotide.
Study schema found below:
Overview of the Baseline Characteristics - favouring the OCT LAR arm
Results show a 5 months longer PFS for Pts on the Pas arm
Although this was a negative trial in terms of symptom control at 6 months, there was an effect on tumor shrinkage and PFS. Dr. Wolin and colleagues also suggested that the dose of pasireotide may be too low and therefore they have started a phase I trial at 120mg/ 4 weeks to see if this may be the case. Also, Novartis has a large Ph3 trial to further investigate its anti-tumour effects in NET patients.
Next, she discussed Horsch and colleagues poster, looking at PRRT for Neuroendocrine Neoplasms — A Multi-intuitional Registry study with Prospective Follow up.
  • Germany PRRT Registry
  • A multi-institutional, prospective and board reviewed registry study for patients treated with peptide receptor radionuclide therapy. 450 patients were included and followed for a mean of 24.4 months.
  • Patients were treated with Lutetium-177 (54%), Yttrium-90 (17%) or both radionuclides (29%).
  • Primary neuroendocrine neoplasms were derived of pancreas (38%), small bowel 30%), unknown primary (19%), lung (4%) and colorectum (3,5%)
  • Most neuroendocrine neoplasms were well differentiated with a proliferation rate below 20% in 54% and were pretreated by 1 or more therapies in 73%.
  • Median OS from time of treatment: 59 months (95% CI: 49-68)
  • There was a suggestion that 177LU was more effective than 90 Y
  • Grade 3-4 tox = 3% with 2 patients having AML
Everolimus in combination with octreotide LAR as the first-line treatment for advanced neuroendocrine tumors: A phase II trial of the I.T.M.O. (Italian Trials in Medical Oncology) group.
The study aimed to assess efficacy and safety of everolimus in combination with octreotide long-acting repeatable (LAR) in patients with well differentiated NETs of gastroenteropancreatic and of lung origin.
Results
  • The ORR, calculated on the ITT population, was 20.0% (95% CI 8.9-31.1): 2 patients (4%) had a complete response (CR), 8 (16%) a partial response (PR).
  • Thirty-six patients (72%) achieved stable disease (SD).
  • All CR and all PR as well as 91.7% of SD had a duration ≥ 6 months.
  • Clinical benefit (CR+PR+SD) was 92%.
  • At a median follow-up of 277 days, the median time to progression (TTP) was 16.3 months (95% CI 10.7-20.1).
  • § Overall survival could not be assessed
  • Treatment-related adverse events (AEs) were mostly of grade 1 or 2; the only grade 4 AE was mucositis in 1 patient, while grade 3 AEs included skin rash in 1 case, stomatitis in 4 cases (8%) and diarrhea in 11 cases (22%).
Dosing patterns for octreotide LAR in neuroendocrine tumor (NET) patients: NCCN NET outcomes database.
Among patients (pts) with neuroendocrine histology, 10 mg — 30 mg of octreotide-LAR administered intramuscularly every 4 weeks is FDA-approved for the long term treatment of severe diarrhea and flushing episodes associated with metastatic carcinoid tumors and pancreatic VIPomas.
In clinical practice, higher doses and/or more frequent administration is often prescribed for pts who experience refractory symptoms (e.g., flushing and/or diarrhea) on the maximal labeled dose.
sVEGFR2 and circulating tumor cells to predict for the efficacy of pazopanib in neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): PAZONET subgroup analysis.
Phase II, single arm, non randomised multi-centre clinical trial
Conclusions:
  • The updated results confirm the efficacy of PAZ as a sequencing treatment of pts with progressive NETS particular in those with pancreatic primary tumors
  • The combo with SSA + PAZ seems to be synergistic
  • sVEGF2 and baseline CTC are promising predictive biomarkers for PAZ in NETs
  • VEGF-A varies along time but it was not associated with clinical outcomes
Long-term survival and clinical efficacy in patients with advanced pancreatic and small bowel metastatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEP-NET) after I.V. 90Y DOTATATE. — this study was not presented at ASCO. See abstract below:
Background: Current therapeutic options for patients with progressive metastatic gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumour/neoplasm (GEP-NET/NEN) are limited. Treatment with SST analogues is method of choice, due to good symptoms control. [DOTA0, D-Phe1,Tyr3]octreotate[DOTATATE] has a higher affinity for SST2 receptors and thus is able to achieve longer disease control.
The aim of this study was to evaluate long term radiological and clinical therapeutic effect of 90Y-DOTATATE in patients with progressive somatostatin receptor—positive small bowel and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour/neoplasm (GEP-NET/NEN).The primary end point was assessing OS and PFS in long term follow-up.
Methods: 67 patients progressing after treatment with SST analogues were inlcuded in the study. The mean treatment activity was 3.8GBq. The mean interval between therapies was 7 weeks (range 6 -9 weeks). Patients were treated up to mean a cumulative activity of 11.2 GBq. Due to pure beta emission (90Y) internal dosimetry was evaluated.
Results: Median overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS) are shown in the Table. In univariate analysis Ki-67 (p=0.048) was the only significant factor influencing OS in pancreatic tumors. That was not confirmed in multivariate analysis. In small bowel tumors we defined three factors influencing survival in univariate analysis. These were: female gender (p=0.023), performance status at the beginning of therapy (p=0.031) and presence of liver metastases (p=0.026). Female gender (HR=0.30, 95% CI 0.11-0.81; p=0.018) was confirmed as positive prognostic factor in multivariate analysis. Factos influencing PFS were also assessed and will be presented as well.
Conclusions: 90Y DOTATATE PRRT is effective in long term outcome (OS and PFS) in patient with advances progressive pancreatic and small bowel GEP-NET. This therapy is relatively safe as initial systemic therapy and after previous treatment with chemotherapy or somatostatine analogues as well.

item.title: re: Australia's Health Minister Defends Deferred Reimbursement Decisions Against Zytiga
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Australia's Health Minister Defends Deferred Reimbursement Decisions Against Zytiga 
Comment: Zytiga was recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) in March 2012, but Janssen-Cilag (subsidiary of J&J) declined the listing in order to seek a higher price for the drug, resubmitting to the PBAC in July 2012, and then again in November 2012, with the PBAC on both occasions recommending the drug for a listing on a cost-minimisation basis with cabazitaxel. Janssen-Cilag has now accepted the November 2012 decision.  ...
This is the Sponsor's comments (JJ) on the Public Summary Document:
Janssen-Cilag is pleased with various aspects of the PBAC’s November 2012 recommendation.
Janssen-Cilag disagrees with the PBAC recommendation that the listing of abiraterone should be based partially on the basis of cost-minimisation with cabazitaxel. In addition, it is Janssen-Cilag’s view that the PBAC’s estimate of the total cost of treatment with G-CSF for patients experiencing febrile neutropenia when on cabazitaxel of less than $500 over 6 treatment cycles is a significant underestimate and is not reflective of drug costs, nor the costs of treating febrile neutropenia as an inpatient over a course of treatment.
Despite these concerns related to the recommendation by the PBAC, Janssen-Cilag believes that additional submissions would delay patient access. Janssen-Cilag is committed to listing abiraterone on the PBS as soon as possible and are moving forward with the listing of abiraterone.
The reimbursement is for the post-chemo setting only. Zytiga is not yet approved for pre-chemo in Australia. Abiraterone is still not listed (no price yet). This will usually take place 2 to 4 months afterwards
Commen : Zytiga Listed on Australia's PBS August Additions
Australia's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) has released the latest round of price reductions under the Expanded and Accelerated Price Disclosure (EAPD) scheme, which took effect from 1 August 2013. According to its Minister of Health, the price cuts are described as meaning that patients would pay around AUD20 million (USD17.9 million) less per year. The 492 drugs face 25% price cuts on average (with for instance Sanofi's Plavix – facing the greatest loss of market value with 43.7% cut or Simvastatin dealing with the second-largest reduction of 44.66%.
The PBS has also released the list of august additions, most prominently including US Johnson & Johnson's prostate cancer drug Zytiga (abiraterone) under following restrictions :
Indication : Castration resistant metastatic carcinoma of the prostate

The required clinical criteria are :

1/ The treatment must be in combination with prednisone or prednisolone

2/ The treatment must not be used in combination with chemotherapy

3/ Patient must have failed treatment with docetaxel due to resistance or intolerance

4/ Patient must have a WHO performance status of 2 or less,

5/ Patient must not receive PBS-subsidised abiraterone if progressive disease develops while on abiraterone.

Source : Global Insight - Aug 1st

item.title: ASCO Data Review Covering Prostate Cancer - Part One
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: There was no real practice changing data but interesting data was presented nevertheless. J&J hit back heavily on the AFFIRM data, VENICE was a negative trial and AZ’s SARD, AZD3514 is no longer in development.
Below is a review of the key highlights from the relevant education sessions, oral abstracts and posters.
During Dr. Sartor’s talk, he reviewed two phase III trials: TRAPEZE and VENICE, a small assessment of F-18 PET and a small retrospective post-hoc analysis of corticosteroid use in COU-301. Only TRAPEZE and VENICE are described below followed by Robert Montgomery’s review of the Effect of corticosteroid (CS) use at baseline (CUB) on overall survival (OS) in patients (pts) receiving abiraterone acetate (AA).
TRAPEZE trial is a four arm study in mCRPC with a complex primary endpoint - bony clinical progression free survival composite withg OS and SREs as secondary endpoints.
OS data with ZA comparison and with Sr89 comparison was not very exciting. However, the SRE free interval attracted some discussion. The median survival time for those treated with ZA was 18.1 months as compared with 13.1 months for those who were treated without ZA. Clinical progression free survival with Sr89 comparison-the median survival time for those treated with Sr89 was 9.8 months as compared with 8.8 months for those treated without Sr89.
So what did we learn from TRAPEZE: there was no OS benefit and the clinical progression free survival and clinical benefit may not equate and the multivariate analysis is incomplete. However, Zoledronate improved the SREs. The learnings from TRAPEZE implied that SSE reduction cannot be used to conclude that zoledronate or denosumab add benefit when used with agents that influence SSEs.
Moving on to VENICE:
This was a negative trial, the overall survival did not show significant difference in placebo and aflibercept. Aflibercept is also associated with a higher risk of dose reductions and treatment terminating AEs in this population. As an aside, both Bev and Sunitinib also failed to prolong OS and had higher AE rates than controls. The implication: using anti-VEGF strategy is questionable and it is now known that docetaxel/prednisone is not easy to beat.
In response to the AFFIRM data, J&J had a poster review on Effect of corticosteroid (CS) use at baseline (CUB) on overall survival (OS) in patients (pts) receiving abiraterone acetate (AA) — Presented by Robert B. Montgomery. Robert commenced his discussion by outlining the use of CS in prostate cancer alongside the benefits and disadvantages
Focusing first on the AFFIRM trial - almost 30% of the patients entering the study were already on CS, with this group having worse prognostic features. AFFIRM data shows that CS leads to progression of PC and concluded that baseline use of CS increases the risk of death
Whereas, COU-AA-301 characterised the progression effect of CS on AR with 1,195 patients randomized by 2:1. The primary endpoint was Overall Survival, while TTPP, rPFS, and PSA response were secondary end points. It was a positive study that led to the approval of AA by FDA in post-docetaxel setting. This table shows the comparison between baseline characteristics of patients who were on steroids with those who were not on steroids. It was found that patients who were on steroids were more likely to have poor prognostic features except for liver metastases.
Patients who were not on steroids and who were treated with AA and P had a median time to death of 17.3 months as compared with 12.7 months of those who were treated with only P. Patients who were on steroids and were treated with AA and P had a median time to death of 13.4 months as compared with a median of 9.3 months for patients who were treated only with P. Patients who were not on steroids had a 3 months greater median time to PSA progression as compared with those who were on steroids.
All these factors of the study were evaluated using the univariate cox model. The relevant factors were again run through a multivariate cox model with a stepwise selection procedure. Limited factors were used in the model to optimize it.
Reference to another presentation was given that showed all the relevant factors. The baseline CS use had a hazard ratio of approximately 1.5 for those who were on steroid use.
Table was shown with relevant features that had prognostic significance which made the model work. It was found that CS was not a key contributor to the model.
The following slide depicts the comparisons/differences of AFFIRM and COU-AA-301. Limitations of the studies were also shared - It was not known that for how long the patients were on steroids prior to study entry. Unknown prognostic factors were not accounted for.
Conclusions are as follows:
Moving on to Enzalutamide - Matthew Raymond Smith, presented a poster on the Efficacy and safety of enzalutamide (ENZA) mono-therapy in hormone-naive prostate cancer (HNPC)
The presentation discusses the efficacy and safety of ENZA mono-therapy over androgen deprivation therapy. He started by walking us through the unmet needs stating that there remains an unmet need for a therapy that has high efficacy but no side effects.
Enzalutamide was evaluated as mono-therapy in a Phase 2 open label single arm efficacy study in patients with hormone naïve prostate cancer. The study involved patients with histologically confirmed prostate cancer for which ADT is indicated. All patients were treated with enzalutamide 160 mg for 24 weeks. The primary endpoint of the trial was PSA response.
After screening, the patients were enrolled and all patients were treated with ENZA mono-therapy. The primary efficacy analysis was performed at 25 weeks. Patients who had clinical benefits at 25 weeks were continued for treatment until progression or toxicity. A 30 day safety follow up was done after the last dose. The study enrolled 67 subjects with median age 73 years. The median duration of PC diagnosis was one year.
ENZA mono-therapy resulted in marked PSA declines in all patients. The maximum PSA decline was >80% in all 67 patients. Median PSA decrease was 99.6%. 62 of the 67 subjects achieved primary endpoint of more than 80% PSA decline.
Similar PSA decline at 25 weeks were observed; with PSA decline generally consistent between metastatic and non-metastatic disease.
16 patients were evaluated for objective response, 3 demonstrated complete response with RECIST criteria while 5 demonstrated partial response. The proportion of patients with complete and partial response was 50%.
16 patients were evaluated for objective response, 3 demonstrated complete response with RECIST criteria while 5 demonstrated partial response. The proportion of patients with complete and partial response was 50%.
One or more adverse events were reported in 89.6% of patients. All of the common treatment emergent AE were either Grade 1 or 2. During the poster sessions, Doctors were discussing the amount of fatigue their patients are experiencing highlighting that in some cases, it is not as placebo like as one first thought
Treatment with ADT reduces bone mineral densities, no significant change was observed in bone mass density in patients treated with ENZA. The estimated decline in bone mineral densities is 35% in first year. The other metabolic changes post treatments with ENZA increase in fat body mass, triglycerides and total cholesterol. In summary, ENZA mono-therapy achieved a high PSA response rate and marked PSA decline. Measurable disease response rate was 50%. As opposed to castration, ENZA mono-therapy was associated with stable bone mineral density.
Finally, data on AZD3514 - A First-in-Human Study of the Oral Selective Androgen Receptor Down-Regulating Drug (SARD) AZD3514 in Patients With CRPC Presented by Aurelius Gabriel Omlin.
The preclinical data of AZD3514 were presented at the AACR 2012. Discussing the two results, one on AR expression in LNCap cells 24 hours after the treatment with AZD3514 and the inhibition of PSA (AR regulated function) and TMPRS52 mRNA in LNCaP cells, after treatment with AZD3514 .
The primary objective of these studies was to evaluate the safety and tolerability of AZD3514 when given orally to patients with CRPC. Following is the study design and objectives
A total of seven cohorts were enrolled in this study, exploring various dosages
With regards primary end-points the trials demonstrated very few grade 3 and no grade 4 toxicities. Although, tolerability with AZD3514 was problematic
None of the adverse events met the DLT definition criterion. Continuous dosing (for 12 weeks) was a problem with 41% of the patients.
Nausea was closely related to dosage. Despite nausea and vomiting related problems the pharmacokinetics the trial demonstrated good results in dose proportional increase in plasma concentration
Based on pre-clinical models, the maximum activity of AZD3514 to down regulate AR was associated with minimal plasma concentration achieved at steady state and exposure of above IC50 for more than 18 hours. This was however, not achievable on this trial.
Despite the insufficient exposure to achieve IC50 coverage for 18 hours, decrease in PSA level of more than 50% was demonstrated in several patients. Only 2 of the 23 patients with soft tissue patients have demonstrated RECIST. At 1000mg OD dosage the patient showed 40% reduction on lymph nodes and maximum PSA decline of 39%. At 500mg once daily has bone metastases only and demonstrated PSA decline of 62%
Analyzing a change in circulating tumor cells (CTC), 7 of the 22 patients demonstrated CTC cells conversions (unfavorable to favorable) from >5 to <5.
Reasons for discontinuation include disease progression, adverse event, and clinical progression.
An extra cohort was studied, which included 6 patients received AZD3514 in combination with Abiraterone. The mandatory pre and post treatment biopsies were conducted but the level of antitumor activity was unsatisfactory.
In conclusion, AZD3514 when given orally to patients in CRPC was considered safe however, demonstrated poor tolerability due to nausea and vomiting and insufficient drug exposure to down regulate AR. AZD3514 has inferior anti-tumor activity compared to Abiraterone and enzalutamide. Thus, the development of the compound by AstraZencea as a selective androgen receptor down-regulator in mCRPC has been terminated. However, targeting AR is an important target in CRPC.

item.title: FIM for AstraZeneca's AZD8186 for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This is a Ph1, open-label, multicentre study of the drug administered orally in patients with advanced castrate-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), squamous non-small cell lung cancer (sqNSCLC), triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) and known PTEN-deficient advanced solid malignancies. AZD8186 is a novel highly selective inhibitor of the PIK3CB/PIK3C Disoforms.

Part A, dose escalation, and Part B, expansion cohort(s) at the intended therapeutic dose(s).

PE will assess safety and tolerability in terms of adverse events, serious adverse events (including death) and safety measures: ECG, physical examination, pulse, blood pressure, weight and laboratory variables.
Recruitment: approx. 48
Completion dates: Dec 2014 / March 2015
Location: Canada (PI: Lillian Sui, MD Princess Hospital)
Source: clinicaltrials.gov
