item.title: Australia's Health Minister Defends Deferred Reimbursement Decisions Against Zytiga
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Zytiga was recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) in March 2012, but Janssen-Cilag (subsidiary of J&J) declined the listing in order to seek a higher price for the drug, resubmitting to the PBAC in July 2012, and then again in November 2012, with the PBAC on both occasions recommending the drug for a listing on a cost-minimisation basis with cabazitaxel. Janssen-Cilag has now accepted the November 2012 decision.
Australia's health minister Tanya Plibersek's statement reiterates the PBAC's independence from government interference, stating: "The Australian Government does not interfere in the decision-making process of the independent expert PBAC."
Source: IHS / Global Insight

Comments
This is the Sponsor's comments (JJ) on the Public Summary Document:
Janssen-Cilag is pleased with various aspects of the PBAC’s November 2012 recommendation.
Janssen-Cilag disagrees with the PBAC recommendation that the listing of abiraterone should be based partially on the basis of cost-minimisation with cabazitaxel. In addition, it is Janssen-Cilag’s view that the PBAC’s estimate of the total cost of treatment with G-CSF for patients experiencing febrile neutropenia when on cabazitaxel of less than $500 over 6 treatment cycles is a significant underestimate and is not reflective of drug costs, nor the costs of treating febrile neutropenia as an inpatient over a course of treatment.
Despite these concerns related to the recommendation by the PBAC, Janssen-Cilag believes that additional submissions would delay patient access. Janssen-Cilag is committed to listing abiraterone on the PBS as soon as possible and are moving forward with the listing of abiraterone.
The reimbursement is for the post-chemo setting only. Zytiga is not yet approved for pre-chemo in Australia. Abiraterone is still not listed (no price yet). This will usually take place 2 to 4 months afterwards
Commen : Zytiga Listed on Australia's PBS August Additions
Australia's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) has released the latest round of price reductions under the Expanded and Accelerated Price Disclosure (EAPD) scheme, which took effect from 1 August 2013. According to its Minister of Health, the price cuts are described as meaning that patients would pay around AUD20 million (USD17.9 million) less per year. The 492 drugs face 25% price cuts on average (with for instance Sanofi's Plavix – facing the greatest loss of market value with 43.7% cut or Simvastatin dealing with the second-largest reduction of 44.66%.
The PBS has also released the list of august additions, most prominently including US Johnson & Johnson's prostate cancer drug Zytiga (abiraterone) under following restrictions :
Indication : Castration resistant metastatic carcinoma of the prostate

The required clinical criteria are :

1/ The treatment must be in combination with prednisone or prednisolone

2/ The treatment must not be used in combination with chemotherapy

3/ Patient must have failed treatment with docetaxel due to resistance or intolerance

4/ Patient must have a WHO performance status of 2 or less,

5/ Patient must not receive PBS-subsidised abiraterone if progressive disease develops while on abiraterone.

item.title: Enzalutamide (XTANDI™) Gets Green Light in EU for Post-Chemo mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The EU authorisation is based on results from the Ph3 AFFIRM study. The next significant catalyst coming up for Medivation is the release of interim data for XTANDI™ in chemotherapy-naïve prostate cancer patients (end of Sept. 2013).
Analysts at Aegis Capital expect rapid market penetration for enzalutamide in EU, thanks to the extensive compassionate use patient program that Astellas has been implementing there.
Upon receiving marketing authorisation in Europe, Astellas will provide Medivation with a $15 million milestone payment, as reflected in Astellas’ current fiscal year (from 1st April 2013 to 31st March 2014) financial forecast.
Sources: Aegis Capital; Astellas/Medivation

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Update for the GLP-1 Drug Class Presented at ADA Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Eli Lilly presented first detailed data from its Ph3 program of once-weekly diraglutide, indcluding data from the AWARD-1 (vs Byetta), AWARD-3 (vs metformin), and AWARD-5 (vs sitagliptin) studies. While details of Lilly's device have not been disclosed, it is understood that it will be launched with a ready-to-use formulation that does not require preparation by the patient and uses a thin 29 gauge needle.
Results of the AWARD-6 (vs Victoza) are due to report around the end of 2013 or early 2014.
To date, none of the available or development stage once-weekly GLP-1 agonists have been able to demonstrate non-inferior efficacy to Victoza. It seems dulaglutide could be the first product to achieve this target and as such it represents a competitive threat to Novo Nordisk (Victoza), AstraZeneca (Bydureon) and GlaxoSmithKline (albiglutide).
Source: Deutsche Bank Report

item.title: Findings from an Overactive Bladder Survey Conducted in Women by Allergan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The survey was conducted by Allergan and endored by the Women's Health Foundation. Key messages are provided below
Prevalence and burden of OAB in the US
Approx. 39 million Americans have OAB [] and 40% of all women in the United States live with OAB symptoms ().
Period
Between April 12th and April 23rd, 2013 among 1,045 nationally representative American women ages 45 and older and an oversample to 528 American women ages 50+, using an email invitation and an online survey (sent by Kelton).
Key Messages
27% of women surveyed noted that they would immediately call their doctor to schedule an appointment if they were experiencing symptoms of OAB (such as urine leakage or the frequent urge to go to the bathroom).
When women do talk to their physicians about OAB, they may receive a prescription for pills to manage their symptoms. In one study, the majority of patients (73.5 percent), however, stopped taking their pills within one year due to side effects and/or lack of results ().
BOTOX® Approved Indication
- to treat overactive bladder symptoms, such as a strong need to urinate with leakage, urgency and frequency in adults when another type of medication (anticholinergic) does not work well enough or cannot be taken.
Source: Allergan

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Prana's Parkinson's Drug Shows Disease-Modifying Capability
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At MDS2013 Prana presented data which indicates PBT434 shows significantly DMD capability in multiple animal models of Parkinson, with potential utility in a range of movement disorders.
MOA: prevent alpha synuclein from aggretating and also prevents the toxic consequences of iron combining wit dopamine.
Status: first clinical trials planned in 2015.
"PBT434, a novel 8-hydroxyquinazolinone, preserves nigro-striatal circuitry, improves motor performance and inhibits alpha synuclein accumulation in animal models of Parkinson’s disease by modulation of iron homeostasis".

item.title: Dr Reddy Reports Injectable Segment as a Key Growth Driver for the US Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company pipeline efforts in injectables focus on complex generics and oncology. Long acting injectables are potential opportunities in the longer term – earliest patent expiries are for Sandostatin and Lupron formulations in CY2017.
Long acting injectables are a key opportunity over the next 5 years and OctoPlus acquisition should help Dr Reddy to be among the early generic entrants.
The company has 7 known filings in this segment that include Copaxone and Angiomax.
These filings along with the success in Fondaparinux (anti-coagulant launched in July 2011) provide comfort on the opportunities being targeted in the injectable segment. In March 2013, Dr Reddy received approval for generic version of Zometa and Reclast (launched in April 2013).
The company has not disclosed the number of pending injectable filings in the US.
Injectable approvals in the US
Filings in the US
Source: Kotak Institutional Equities Research; Dr Reddy

item.title: Prana Presents New Benchmark Test to Assess HD Patients in Trials
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The poster presented at MDS in Sydney details HD-PROP, a test which is aimed at asking trial participants 3 questions in relation to their HD at the start of the trial (What problem is most bothersome? In what way is this problem bothersome? How severe is this problem?).
“The Huntington‘s Disease patient-reported outcome of problems: feasibility and applicability in clinical research (HD-PROP)”
- aims to overcome some of the challenges associated with assessing clinically relevant outcomes in HD where progressive motor, cognitive and psychiatric symptoms can interfere with comprehension of lengthy patient self-report questionnaires and communication of responses
- created by clinical investigators involved in Prana’s Phase 2 clinical trial of PBT2 known as the REACH2HD Study. This 109 patient trial is fully recruited and nearing completion.
Quoting Pf Ira Shoulson: “Patient-reported outcomes are an important area of focus for the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and along with clinical measures provide a more complete understanding of the relevance as well as safety and effectiveness of potential treatments.”
Full poster attached @1
  1. Huntington disease patient-reported outcomes Poster.pdf  (500 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Safinamide Ph3 Results Presented at MDS2013
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Results presented showed that in the SETTLE study safinamide has been shown to improve motor fluctuations (ON and OFF time) by 2 hours/day without any worsening in troublesome dyskinesia. These new results indicate that the above benefit is accompanied by a clinically important improvement in motor symptoms without worsening of other ADL or dopaminergic complications.
Background: The SETTLE study established the clinically and statistically significant benefit of safinamide 50-100 mg/day on motor fluctuations without any increase in troublesome dyskinesia in patients who were stabilized on optimized doses of levodopa and other dopaminergic treatments. Statistically significant differences from placebo add-on were noted on motor symptoms (UPDRSIII).
Objective: To determine the clinical relevance of the significant benefits of safinamide on motor symptoms (UPDRSIII) by determination of responder rates.
Methods: The SETTLE Study enrolled 552 PD fluctuating patients who were on stable, optimized, doses of L-dopa and other PD medications in 23 countries. Analyses were performed to determine the proportion of patients who improved by at least 20% or 30% in motor symptoms (UPDRSIII). Additionally, analyses were performed to determine the proportion of patients who improved by at least 20% or 30% with no worsening in activities of daily living (UPDRSII) and complication of dopaminergic treatment (UPDRSIV) in the ITT population.
Results: Statistically significantly higher proportion of patients on safinamide improved by 20% (p=0.0062) and 30% (p=0.0267) in UPDRSIII. Analysis to determine the proportion of patients who improved by 20% (p<0.05) and 30% (p<0.05) without worsening in UPDRSII and UPDRSIV also demonstrated significant benefit of safinamide compared to placebo add-on.
Source: Newron

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New VP of Marketing Commercial Strategy and Operations at Lexicon
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: John Northcott will develop the commercial functions for Lexicon and lead the commercialization of Lexicon’s products, with initial focus on telotristat etiprate for carcinoid syndrome.
Has held commercial roles in both U.S. and Global marketing for Avastin® with Genentech and the Roche Group
In addition, Mr. Northcott has experience in a variety of therapeutic areas from previous commercial positions at other pharmaceutical companies including Merck and Pfizer.
Source: Lexicon

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Astellas Looking to Sell its Dermatology Assets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas' dermatology portfolio which includes Protopic (eczema drug) could be worth between $500M and $1 billion. Astellas is discussing breaking up the business and selling the pieces to different parties.
- US patent for Protopic is set to expire next year.
- Astellas' business model as recently presented is to maintain and expand franchises in urology/transplantation, develop oncology franchise and improve R&D productivity with optimization of resource allocation.
Source: ThomsonOne

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Belgium based, private company presented at ENDO2013 preclinical PK and efficacy data of its oral small-molecule NK3 receptor antagonist program. ESN364, the lead candidate issued from this program, is scheduled for FIM in 4Q:13 (endometriosis and polycystic ovary syndrome). Of note, the company is actively seeking partner for ESN282 (inflammatory diseases such as ulcerative colitis).
The study provides the first demonstration that the oral administration of ESN314 decreases the plasma levels of Lutenizing Hormone (LH), but not Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) in non-rodent models. This selective reduction of plasma LH offers a more refined modulation of the HPG axis than the existing GnRH antagonist therapies.
Source: Euroscreen

Comments
Euroscreen has announced initiation of the Phase I clinical trial for ESN364. The main study objective is the assessment of the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of ESN364 in healthy male and female volunteers.
In addition, hormone levels will also be monitored as biomarkers of on-target activity.
Recruitment: Approximately 64 healthy subjects will participate in the study.
Timelines and Next Steps: Successful completion of this European Phase I clinical trial will enable the initiation of Proof-Of-Concept Phase II studies of ESN364 in patients suffering from sex-hormone related disorders such as Endometriosis, Poly-Cystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS), Uterine Fibroids, and possibly other related diseases. Phase II studies are projected to start in Q4, 2014.
Following "fully-consistent Ph1 results", the company now plans to start 2 Ph2 trials (3-month dosing, 72 patients) for uterine fibroids and Poly Cystic Ovarian Syndrome in January 2015. Company claims the results obtained give a strong competitive advantage compared to GnRH ligand products to provide a superior product with regard to both safety and efficacy for a large scope of indications such as UF, PCOS and Endometriosis in the treatment of Women’s Health.
Study Results
The Ph1 trial enrolled 64 healthy subjects (40 male and 24 female).
Safety was evaluated by means of intensive ECG and vital signs monitoring as well as via the necessary clinical laboratory assessments throughout the entire study (up to 21 days of daily dosing and up to 84 days of follow-up in female volunteers).
No clinically relevant changes were observed in the clinical lab parameters, ECG and/or vital signs. The reported adverse events were mild-to-moderate in intensity, reversible and of limited duration and non-significant in relation to ESN364 treatment based upon comparison to the placebo group.
Euroscreen has initiated two POC trials in UF (Uterine fibroids) and PCOS (Polycystic ovary syndrome). The launch of these trials builds upon the efficacy data established in Ph1 wherein ESN364 lowered plasma levels of estrogen and progesterone as a result of its selective effect on pulsatile LH secretion. The demonstrated selective modulation of gonadotropins mitigates the risk of the induction of menopausal-like adverse events, such as loss of bone mineral density and the induction of hot flashes. Thus, in contrast to the existing GnRH products, the non-castrating drug profile of ESN364 presents an opportunity for chronic dosing without any need for add-back therapy for the chronic treatment of Women’s Health Disorders.
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (35,4 KB)

item.title: Prosensa to Raise $60M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company amended its IPO and now plans to sell 5 million shares at $11-13. Prosensa is one of three companies vying to gain the 1st approved drug fro Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
- Drisapersen (PRO051) is in Ph3 testing
- Data expected 4Q:13
See Neurology4669: GSK Acquires Prosensa's DMD Drug for Up to €460M.
Source: Biocentury; Prosensa

item.title: Positive Results of Versartis' hGH for PGHD Presented at ENDO 2013
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company presented the first results from its ped Ph1b/2a trials in a poster presented by G. M. Bright (VP, Medical Affairs).
“A Phase 1b/2a Study of a New Long-acting Growth Hormone (VRS-317) in Pre-pubertal Children with Growth Hormone Deficiency (GHD)”
  • a single dose of VRS-317 was very well tolerated in children with GHD.
  • the drug levels and IGF-I responses increase in intensity and duration with increasing dose.
Bright stated that: “These results confirm and extend the VRS-317 results recently published on adult GHD patients and allow VRS-317 to be optimized for up to once-monthly dosing.
The company’s first double-blind, placebo-controlled, single ascending dose study of VRS-317 in growth hormone deficient adults was published ahead of print in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism (JCEM) on April 12, 2013 [doi:10.1210/jc.2013-1437] and was published in final print in the June issue of JCEM [J Clin Endocrinol Metab, June 2013, 98(6):2595–2603] (see attached @1).
Source: Versartis

item.title: Apireo Announces Start of Further Ph1 in Healthy Volunteers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On June 18th, the company reported the start of a further Ph1 designed to confirm the superior side effect profile of Somatoprim vs octreotide.
In this randomized in- patient cross-over study, healthy volunteers will be treated with single administrations of the highest approved dose of octreotide as well as different doses of Somatoprim.
The effect of each treatment on safety and tolerability parameters as well as the side effect profile will be tested.
Results are expected by the fourth quarter of 2013.
Source: Aspireo

item.title: AstraZeneca Increases Proximity to Bioscience Clusters
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As announced at its Investor Day, AstraZeneca is picking Cambridge site as global research centre, and HQs. R&D centre in Alderley Park will be shut down.
Location: Cambridge Biomedical Campus
Staff: around 2000 by 2016.
Objective: to focus research at 3 centres: UK, US, and Sweden.
The site will bring together its small molecule nand biologics R&D activity.
The facility will become its main site for oncology research, and will also focus on cardiovascular and meatbolic diseases, respiratory, inflammation and autoimmune diseases, and conditions of the CNS.
Source: AstraZeneca

item.title: Strategy Behind J&J's Acquisition of Aragon
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Aragon acquisition is seen as a strategic complement to Zytiga franchise (patent expires in 2016/US). Under the control of J&J, the ARN-509 Ph3 planning is to begin shortly (after 3Q:13), and could investigate 1st-and 2nd-line metastatic and non-metastatic CRPC, ass well as Ph2-type trials assessing ARN-509/Zytiga combination therapy.
- Extend J&J's prostate cancer franchise
- Gain access to a potential best-in-class treatment
- To spinn off other assets
Patent: 2028/2027 in the U.S./EU at the earliest
MOA: similar than Medivation's Xtandi.
Efficacy: SE profile: ARN-509 could prove to be more potent than Xtandi with a more favorable side-effect profile (no seizures seen to date). ARN-509 could have a place in the 2nd-line setting in patients who progress after treatment with Zytiga, but importantly, could replace Xtandi as a 1st-line therapy.
Source: Leerink Swann

item.title: RaQualia to Raise $35M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last year, RaQualia reported it was restructuring to focus on 4 compounds in development for gastrointestinal diseases (please see below). The Company believes that it is critical to continue to strengthen its ability to attract potential licensees based on its business strategy, in order to establish optimal licensing arrangements for its development compounds.
There are four main objectives for this fundraising:
  • planning and initiating a Phase II clinical trial for our 5-HT4 Partial Agonist (RQ-10),
  • planning and initiating an early clinical trial for our 5-HT2B Antagonist (RQ-00310941) and Motilin Receptor Agonist (RQ-00201894),
  • investment in R&D activities for the continuous discovery and creation of new development candidates, and
  • new capital expenditures for research equipment with a view towards enhancing the productivity of R&D systems following the realization of a leaner organizational structure and more efficient deployment of working capital associated therewith
5-HT4 Partial Agonist (RQ-00000010) - A First-in-Human (FIH) study of the compound was initiated in the U.K. in May 2012. A single ascending dose study, multiple ascending dose study, and study to investigate the effects of food, gender and age were completed in October. The Company is currently analyzing the data and preparing a final report.
Source: RaQualia

item.title: J&J Acquires Aragon for >$1 Billion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: J&J announced a definitive agreement to acquire Aragon, a company developing ARN-509 (an androgen receptor antagonist similar to enzalutamide). This acquisition, expected to close in 3Q 2013, is seen as a strategic importance for J&J's Zytiga likely to lose market share to Medivation's drug over the course of the coming month and years.
The deal does not include development of Aragon's treatment for breast cancer, which will be spun off into a separate company called Seragon Pharmaceuticals ahead of the deal and will be run by Aragon's chief executive officer.
J&J will make an upfront cash payment of $650mm, plus additional contingent payments of up to $350mm based on reaching predetermined milestones.
Prior to closing, Aragon will transfer all assets other than its androgen receptor antagonist program to a newly formed company, which Aragon will spin off.
J&J will not have an ownership stake in the new company nor retain any rights to these products or programs.
Analysts believe Medivation still has a high probability of success in ongoing litigation against UCLA and Aragon.
  • In February 2011, Medivation filed suit against the University of California and Aragon alleging that the university breached a 2005 deal with Medivation when it granted Aragon rights to ARN-509, which Medivation said is based on technology similar to its prostate cancer drug Xtandi enzalutamide. Under the 2005 deal, Medivation has rights to the university's small molecule androgen receptor antagonists, including Xtandi. The court ruled Medivation has exclusive rights to a specific series of compounds identified by a chemical structure that does not include ARN-509, which is in Phase II testing for castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC).
Even if ARN-509 is ruled the property of Aragon, they believe that J&J will have to conduct head-to-head trials against XTANDI™ just to get ARN-509 onto the market.
Source: ThomsonOne; Aegis

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Takeda and Sanofi to Cooperate in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The objective of this cooperation is to expand Takeda's drug sales in China.
Takeda CEO reported that because emerging markets represent approx. 70% of global drug market growth, his company must develop long-term localized strategies.

In April 2013 Takeda and Sanofi agreed to co-promote alogliptin (submitted for marketing authorization in China for type 2 diabetes).

  • Per the agreement, Takeda will grant the exclusive Chinese rights for the drug to Sanofi. (commercial terms not cisclosed).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Russia to Support Hi-Tech Production of Pharmaceuticals
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Vladimir Putin has signed a "list of instructions" according to which the Russian government, along with the national business associations, has been tasked with "providing an enabling environment for domestic manufacturers of drugs", by preparing measures that include additional measures to support hi-tech production of pharmaceutical substances for the creation of drugs, including those listed on the list vital and essential drugs (ZHNVLP).
These are to be prepared by 1 September. Furthermore, the "list" also includes the development of proposals for introducing additional preferences within the public procurement system for goods manufactured on the territory of the country.
The "list of instructions" reflects Russia's ongoing objective of boosting the domestic pharmaceutical industry and enabling innovativeness within the industry. It is also in line with the objective of increasing the volume of domestic production of medicines on the ZHNVLP list to 90% by 2018.
Additionally, the preparation of measures for further preference within the public procurement system for goods manufactured in the country also reflects the government's ongoing support for domestic manufacturers.
There is a 15% price preference given to Russian and Belarusian produced goods within public tenders, with the Russian Ministry of Economic Development and Ministry of Industry and Trade also having previously introduced a proposal according to which foreign medicines would be barred from participating in tenders for state purchases if there are two or more domestically produced alternatives.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Interim Data Further Supports Safety of Novo Nordisk's Victoza®
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The observed relative risks of both pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer for Victoza® were similar to, or numerically lower than, that of the comparators in each cohort, as previously communicated.
The results of the study were presented as part of a complete overview of available Victoza® safety data, including non-clinical and clinical data as well as data from post-marketing commitments that together reconfirmed the safety profile of Victoza®.
Data were presented at a scientific workshop in the U.S arranged by the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) and the National Cancer Institute (NCI).
Objectives: regulators, academic and scientific experts as well as representatives from the pharmaceutical industry came together to discuss suspected mechanisms linking pancreatitis, diabetes and pancreatic cancer.
Mads Krogsgaard Thomsen, executive vice president and chief science officer of Novo Nordisk presented interim data from an ongoing prospective, matched cohort epidemiological study comparing Victoza® with 4 other widely used anti-diabetic drug classes in each cohort.
The study comprised >100,000 patient years of treatment, with between 14,000 and 19,000 patients on Victoza® and comparator treatment in each cohort.
Source: Novo Nordisk

item.title: re: Cosmo to Present its Methylene Blue MMX® for Colon Diagnosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Cosmo to Present its Methylene Blue MMX® for Colon Diagnosis 
Comment: Methylene Blue MMX® (for the diagnosis of lesions, polyps and adenomas in the colon) will be presented to approx. 500 specialists from around the world during the International Meeting for Advanced Gastroenterology Endoscopy at Humanitas Hospital in Milano/Italy. The Methylene blue-MMX® tablet, currently assessed in Ph2, is an oral colon-release formulation in form of coated tablets, containing methylene blue. The company expects market entry end 2013.  ...
On June 14th, the FDA reported that the design and planned analysis of the Ph3 study proposed by Cosmo adequately address the objectives necessary to support a regulatory submission for the marketing authorization of the product. Cosmo is now completing the preparations for the clinical trial, expected to complete latest Q1:14.
EU Status
EMA has previously approved the access to the centralized procedure for the future Marketing Authorization.
Ph3 Locations
The trial will be conducted in major North American and European hospitals.
Source: Cosmo

item.title: First and Only Medicine for IBS-C Approved in EU
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Almirall and Ironwood announced the launch of Constella® (linaclotide 290mcg capsules once daily), the first approved prescription therapy in a new class of treatments for adults suffering from moderate to severe IBS-C in Europe.
Constella® is now available in Germany, the UK and Nordic countries, and is expected to be launched in several other European countries in 2013.
Prior to the approval of Constella®, IBS-C treatment options consisted mainly of therapies for individual symptoms such as antispasmodics or unlicensed antidepressants for pain and laxatives for constipation.

item.title: Advanced Accelerator Applications (AAA) Reports Completion of €4.8M Capital Increase
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The financing will help the expansion plans and finance trials of Radio Metabolic Therapy and diagnostic products, including Lutathera®, currently in ph3 for the diagnosis and treatment of Gastro-Entero-Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumours (GEP-NETs). This is the 1st tranche of financing that AAA is raising from the 10M new shares that the Company issued on March 8th, 2013.
Status
- Lutathera® has orphan drug status and has already been used in thousands of patients by specialist clinicians with significant results.
- Market approvals in the US and EU expected in 2017.
Sites of the Ph3 trials
- 50 hospitals in EU (located in Italy, France, Germany, Portugal, Spain, Belgium and UK) and in the US (California, Iowa, Massachusetts, Florida, New York, Texas, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Louisiana and North Carolina).
Business Development
- Lutathera® was acquired in June 2010 following AAA’s purchase of BioSynthema, a MNM research company based in St. Louis, Missouri, US.
- Privately owned company registered in Bourg en Bresse, France.
- AAA owns 100% of its subsidiaries in Italy, Switzerland, Spain and USA.
- Focus on molecular imaging and personalized medicine for the treatment of diseases including cancer.
- EU leader in the production and commercialization of PET (Positron Emission Tomography) and SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) products, with 16 production and R&D facilities in France, Italy, Switzerland, Spain, Portugal, Israel and the US.
Source: AAT

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Major Opportunity for GW Pharm's Sativex
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A new decree proposed by the French minister of health Marisol Touraine allows the French National Agency for Drug Safety (ANSM) to grant marketing authorisation to pharmaceutical treatments based on cannabinoids and cannabis derivates. The decree was published on the French Official Gazette on 7 June.
The decree allows for manufacturing operations, transportation, import, export, possession, supply, sale, purchase, or use of these specialty treatments.
The decree opens the doors for marketing authorisation of cannabis-based medicines.
The drug has been already launched internatinally and has been added to the reimbursement list of some European Union countries.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: POC Trial of Auris Medical's NMDA Antagonist for Tinnitus To Approach Completion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Last month, the company presented key safety outcomes at the TRI Tinnitus Conference. They also showed high acceptance of intratympanic injections by th epatients. AM-101 clinical programme comprises a total of 3 double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trials, of which 2 have been completed.
- In the first trial, a Phase I/II study involving 24 patients, the safety of a single dose administration of AM-101 was demonstrated in a dose escalation up to 0.81 mg/mL. It also revealed minimal systemic exposure from the treatment. These results have been published previously (Mühlmeier et al., 2012).
- At the TRI Tinnitus Conference, key safety outcomes from the second study, a Phase IIb clinical trial, were presented for the first time. The study enrolled a total of 248 patients who were treated 3 times over 3 consecutive days either with AM-101 at 0.27 or 0.81 mg/mL or placebo. Study participants were monitored over 90 days. The primary safety endpoint was the occurrence of clinically relevant hearing deterioration from baseline to Day 30, defined as increase in the pure tone hearing threshold ≥15 dB in any two contiguous test frequencies.
April 16, 2013 - Auris Medical AG raised CHF47.1m (US$50.7m) in series C financing round. The finance was provided by Sofinnova Ventures, Inc. and Sofinnova Partners SAS. In conjunction with the funding, Jim Healy, general partner at Sofinnova Ventures, and Antoine Papiernik, managing partner at Sofinnova Partners, joined Auris’s board of directors.
The company intends to use the proceeds to advance its two clinical projects, AM-101 for the treatment of acute tinnitus and AM-111 for the treatment of acute inner ear hearing loss, through Phase III studies and market launch.
  • Founded in April 2003 in Switzerland.
  • H/Q: Basel, Switzerland
  • Auris Medical is also working with a network of specialised partners, including some of the world's leading scientists in the area of inner ear disorders.
Source: Auris Medical AG

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Autifony's Lead Product Enters FIM for Hearing Loss and Tinnitus
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AUT00063, novel first-in-class Kv3 potassium channel modulator, targets auditory processing in the brain. To fund the programme to POC, Autifony announced that Pfizer Venture Investments has invested £5M. The company intents to find a partner at the end of the Phase II.
  • Design: RCT
  • Location: UK
  • Objective: to assess the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of orally administered single and multiple dose regimens of the drug.
  • Recruitment: approx 60 (young and elderly volunteers).
  • Completion date: Q1 2014.
  • UK-based company formed in 2011 as a spin-out from GlaxoSmithKline by Charles Large and Giuseppe Alvaro, previously Directors in GSK's Neuroscience Centre of Excellence for Drug Discovery.
  • Privately funded by leading venture capital investors.
  • Head office is at the Imperial College Incubator in London.
  • The company works closely with hearing research experts at University College London’s Ear Institute, Yale University, and other academic collaborators around the world to progress its pioneering research.
Tinnitus Research Initiative Conference (May 2013)
  • “AUT3, a Kv3.1 positive modulator, suppresses chronic noise-induced tinnitus in a rat model” (Turner et al.).
ARO Annual Meeting (February 2013)
  • “Pharmacological activators and inhibitors of Kv3.1 potassium currents“ (Brown et al.).
  • “Impact of Kv3 Channel Modulator AUT3 on In Vivo Auditory Processing in Mice“ (Hesse et al.).
Source: Autifony Therapeutics

item.title: re: CEE Countries Affected by Parallel Exports
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
CEE Countries Affected by Parallel Exports 
Comment: Reports of increased levels of parallel exports of expensive pharmaceuticals from countries in the Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) region have become more frequent recently. Although in previous years the spotlight has been on Slovakia, where legal changes have been introduced to counteract the adverse consequences of parallel exports of drugs on the population, currently it is Slovakia's neighbours – the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Poland – where the problem is becoming more serious.  ...
The issue of cross-border trade has been given a high priority by the national health authorities in EE.
In PL, the local association is urging all players of the pharmaceutical value chain to notify relevant authorities if shortages of drugs occur. In parallel, the pharmaceutical inspectorate puts up a list of drugs which are threatened by shortages and imposes wholesalers to report the exports of drugs from the list. The inspectorate can forbid exports of drug(s) from the list.
in RO, which surprisingly is not quoted in the above paper, export can represent up to 40% of some therapeutic classes. The local association is proposing a new pricing methodology to address that issue.
Finally in HU, on 10 May 2013, the Government submitted a Bill to Parliament which contains provisions to restrict parallel trade of medicines subject to certain conditions. Article 95 of the Bill provides that the competent authority may prohibit the export of a medicine through wholesale trade for up to one year if there is a risk to patient supply due to excessive export of the medicine if (i) there is no other medicine available with a similar therapeutic effect; or (ii) terminating the import of the medicine to Hungary would cause disturbances in medicine supply. A fine of up to HUF 500 million (approximately €1.7 million) may be imposed by the HA in case of infringement.
P.Belnat


Add a Comment on this Article

View thread PharmaWorld10480: CEE Countries Affected by Parallel Exports

item.title: CEE Countries Affected by Parallel Exports
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Reports of increased levels of parallel exports of expensive pharmaceuticals from countries in the Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) region have become more frequent recently. Although in previous years the spotlight has been on Slovakia, where legal changes have been introduced to counteract the adverse consequences of parallel exports of drugs on the population, currently it is Slovakia's neighbours – the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Poland – where the problem is becoming more serious.

Scale of parallel exports in Poland underestimated

In a major report in Polish newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, it is reported that the scale of parallel exports of drugs from Poland is underestimated, with the country's chief pharmaceutical inspector, Zofia Ulz, estimating that as much as 30% of the whole market by value may be subject to parallel exports. IMS Health is reported as estimating that drugs with a value of as much as PLN3 billion (USD931.246 million) are parallel exported each year, and although most of this is exported legally, around one-third is not. In comparison, the value of the parallel export market in 2010 was estimated at around just PLN800 million.

Price of some innovative drugs 59% lower than European average

Ulz is reported as stating that the medicines that are parallel-exported are often expensive, innovative ones with no equivalents on the market, and among the therapeutic areas represented are oncology, cardiology, and asthma, while there is a particularly bad problem with parallel exports of insulin. Ulz is reported as stating that the average price of the most commonly parallel-exported medicines is as much as 59% lower than the European average, which is the reason behind the phenomenon. Another cause is the fixed margins applied for pharmacies and wholesalers as part of the Reimbursement Act from the beginning of 2012, which has meant that wholesalers and pharmacists have sought other means to boost their income. It is reported that pharmacies lost in the region of PLN1 billion of their income because of the introduction of fixed margins. In the case of pharmacies, there are legal issues, because they are only able to sell directly to patients through retail, and to sell medicines abroad for them is in breach of the law.
The source describes how some pharmacy owners will order extra amounts of medicines in addition to their main order, which they then sell to wholesalers who sell them abroad – despite the fact that they are not allowed to sell the medicines to wholesalers – but they are able to do this in a way that makes it appear entirely legal. Additionally, a similar thing is reported to be happening in Polish hospitals, with orders placed for more than required, and the additional medicines being sold abroad illegally.

Czech hospitals reportedly involved in export "fraud"

In the Czech Republic, a similar situation is occurring in the hospital market, with the already well-known phenomenon of the disappearance of a proportion of the medicines used in specialised treatment centres – including centres for oncology, multiple sclerosis, and cardiology – which are where most of the use of innovative drugs in the Czech Republic is concentrated. As Czech news agency ČTK reports, on the basis of an article in Czech newspaper Lidové noviny, a hospital may order a large amount of medicines, agreeing a discount on them with the wholesaler, but it does not take all the medicines, retaining only one-tenth of them, then invoicing the health insurance fund for the regular price, while the wholesaler sells the rest abroad at a big profit. This is reported to affect cancer, multiple sclerosis, and rheumatoid arthritis drugs.
Officially, the value of parallel exports of medicines from the Czech Republic is around CZK0.5 billion (USD25.759 million), although experts suggest that billions of koruna worth of drugs are being parallel exported. Recently, a legislative change was introduced in the country under which pharmacy operators have been obliged to inform the State Institute for Drug Control whether they are ordering medicines for retail sale or for export; however, as the source reports, this measure has been proven to be ineffective in the face of the very lucrative nature of parallel exports of such medicines.

Hungarian legal change planned to combat parallel exports

In Hungary, among the drugs most affected by parallel exports are anticoagulants and medicines to treat multiple sclerosis and various cancers. As Hungarian medical news provider Weborvos reports, under a proposal for a legal change, it is suggested that parallel exports should only be allowed when the needs of the Hungarian market are catered for. Weborvos comments that the increasingly low prices of medicines resulting from the blind-bid tenders for off-patent medicines are contributing to an increase in parallel export activity, as well as the ever lower profit margins of wholesalers.
Another reason for the lack of certain medicines on the Hungarian market, according to the National Institute for Quality and Organisational Development in Healthcare and Medicines and the National Institute of Pharmacy, quoted by the source, is that wholesalers with a smaller market share are having problems obtaining certain medicines from manufacturers.

Outlook and implications

Other CEE countries are clearly looking at the case of Slovakia and considering their own response. Indeed, in Poland, there are already plans in the pipeline for legal changes that would bring in a sort of "early warning" system for shortages of the kind that has been introduced in Slovakia. Increased monitoring and inspection of pharmacies and wholesalers is also planned. It would seem that in Hungary, a similar plan is being proposed.
In all three countries under discussion, there have been changes in the pricing and reimbursement of pharmaceuticals that are sure to have resulted in the reduction in the prices of many off-patent and some patented drugs, on account of the use of jumbo reference-pricing groups. Thus, while solving one problem – that of the high prices of medicines – a new one is created in the form of parallel exports. Controlling and restricting parallel exports is a potentially contentious area too, as was discovered by the Greek authorities, where the situation with parallel exports has been especially difficult, and where the European Commission intervened when the Greek authorities were judged to be imposing excessive restrictions on the free movement of goods.
In the case of Poland and the Czech Republic, Germany is the main market for parallel-exported drugs. Pharmaceutical companies will be hoping that the governments of these countries can do something to reduce it, as it is damaging to the integrity of their prices in higher price, higher income markets.
Source: Global Insight

Comments
The issue of cross-border trade has been given a high priority by the national health authorities in EE.
In PL, the local association is urging all players of the pharmaceutical value chain to notify relevant authorities if shortages of drugs occur. In parallel, the pharmaceutical inspectorate puts up a list of drugs which are threatened by shortages and imposes wholesalers to report the exports of drugs from the list. The inspectorate can forbid exports of drug(s) from the list.
in RO, which surprisingly is not quoted in the above paper, export can represent up to 40% of some therapeutic classes. The local association is proposing a new pricing methodology to address that issue.
Finally in HU, on 10 May 2013, the Government submitted a Bill to Parliament which contains provisions to restrict parallel trade of medicines subject to certain conditions. Article 95 of the Bill provides that the competent authority may prohibit the export of a medicine through wholesale trade for up to one year if there is a risk to patient supply due to excessive export of the medicine if (i) there is no other medicine available with a similar therapeutic effect; or (ii) terminating the import of the medicine to Hungary would cause disturbances in medicine supply. A fine of up to HUF 500 million (approximately €1.7 million) may be imposed by the HA in case of infringement.
P.Belnat

item.dc:creator: spoon

Not disclosed.
Expand oncology business in the country.

item.title: FIM to Evaluate Everolimus with TheraSpere for Advanced NETs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The phase 1 is to find the highest tolerable dose of the combination of everolimus with TheraSphere that can be given to patients with advanced NETs that have spread to the liver. The safety of everolimus and TheraSphere will also be studied.

TheraSphere is a medical device containing a radioactive material called yttrium-90 (Y-90).
Tiny glass beads called microspheres are filled with Y-90 and then injected through an artery directly into the liver. This allows a large dose of radiation to be given directly to the tumor, which may lower the risk of side effects from the radiation to other parts of the body and/or to healthy liver tissue.
The radiation from TheraSphere stays in the body and begins to lose its effect within 12 days. The glass microspheres will stay in the body from that point on. The radiation will eventually decay (go away). By the time a participant leaves the hospital, the amount of radiation outside of the body will be low enough to not be a threat to others.
Recruitment: approx 22
Start date: Nov 2013 - Completion date: Nov 2017
Location: USA (1)PI: Nageshwara V. Dasari, MBBS

item.title: Pfizer's Strategy on New Drug Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ian Reed (CEO) has told Wall St. Cheat Sheet he would like to develop JVs with other drugmakers in order to expand into international markets, share costs, risks, and commercial benefits.
Management cited vaccines, oncology and neurodegenrative business as areas in which partnership would be useful.
  • Pfizer has already partnered with J&J to develop a new Alzheimer drug (http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/13/us-alzheimers-johnsonjohnson-idUSBRE91C0SX20130213).
Reed believes that getting better scientists on the board of directors will help the company continue to make a new generation of innovative treatments in the coming years.
Source: First Word

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Onco/Uro Surveys Look at Provenge Xtandi and Capesaris
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Wedbush conducted the survey of 31 medical oncologists and 20 urologists to monitor the dynamics of the prostate cancer markets. Finding show a flat future use of Provenge, urologists looking to drive more use of Xtandi in months ahead, and awareness on Capesaris. More details are provided below.
Dendreon's Provenge
Percentage of surveyed oncologists and urologists who have used Provenge has increased to 68% and 70%, respectively, from 55% for each group in September 2012.
Among those not using Provenge, difficulty of use is listed as the most important reason why, surpassing reimbursement difficulties, which was the most important reason listed in September 2012.
o Lack of appropriate patients has also diminished significantly as a reason for not using Provenge.
Provenge use is DOWN to a median of 15% (from 20% in September) of prostate cancer patients treated by surveyed physicians. This corresponds to the prior survey’s prediction of estimated future Provenge use in 15% of patients.
Similarly, surveyed physicians predict 15% of patients will be treated with Provenge 6 months from now.
J&J' Xtandi
A majority of surveyed physicians have used Xtandi, with 74% and 55% of surveyed oncologists and urologists, respectively, reporting use.
Among those using Xtandi, 71% of use is reportedly in patients who have progressed after chemotherapy, with 29% reporting (off-label) use in chemotherapy-naïve patients (26% of oncologists, 36% of urologists).
In comparison with main competitor Zytiga, 41% of all surveyed doctors use Xtandi as often or more often than Zytiga (12% more often, 29% as often). Urologists were more likely to prescribe Xtandi “more often” than Zytiga, with 18% stating as such, compared to 9% of oncologists. However, 53% of all surveyed physicians use Zytiga more often, breaking down to 61% of oncologists and 36% of urologists.
Nearly 2/3 of all surveyed physicians (65%) prescribe Xtandi on-label, after chemotherapy, with 79% stating they prescribe it after Zytiga.
GTx' Capesaris
Awareness of Capesaris, GTXI’s Phase II selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) was similar to our September 2012 survey, at 69% of all surveyed physicians from the recent survey compared to 77% from September 2012, and of those, the 75% awareness level currently displayed by surveyed urologists was the same as the prior survey’s level.
There was an increase in enthusiasm as measured by “definitely would prescribe” responses from urologists, based on potential attributes Capesaris could show in clinical trials (reducing free testosterone, PSA, hot flashes and changes in bone density and blood lipid levels). The “definitely would prescribe” percentage in urologists increased to 35-45% from 15-20% in September in the current survey.
Capesaris holds its position as a potential early therapy with majorities of surveyed physicians stating that, if approved, they would prescribe it before other branded products--Zytiga, Xtandi and Provenge. These answers support the idea that Capesaris could find an early position in the sequence of prostate cancer treatments.
Positive data from GTXI’s Phase II studies of Capesaris expected in H2:13, showing an acceptably low rate of VTEs, and better control of testosterone, especially free testosterone, which appears to have a disproportionate effect on PSA.
Positive pivotal data for enobosarm from the Phase III studies (POWER 1 and POWER 2) in the cancer-related muscle-wasting setting expected in Q3:13. At ASCO, GTXI management noted that the drop-out rate for its pivotal POWER 1 and POWER 2 Phase III trials was lower than the expected 30% rate, likely increasing the statistical powering of the study.
Because of positive expectations for the POWER 1 and 2 studies, we are lowering our discount rate that we apply to enobosarm revenues from 35% to 25%, resulting in our increased price target.
Full Reports available on demand to Brigitte Deschamps

item.title: J&J CEO Sees Opportunities in Chinese Middle-Class Expansion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A. Gorsky has declared the company will attach greater importance to China amid middle-class expansion that could soon reach 800 million people, bringing with it huge demand for HC products.
Gorsky added that approx 9% of China's population is >65, a number that is expected to hit 25% in 20-30 years. Seniors require 5-7 times more health products that people in younger age groups.
He emphasized that Chinese urbanization will impact HC demands, as people seek disease treatments that were unavailable to them in rural settings.
Source: GBI

item.title: re: Phase I/II Study of RAD001 in Combination With Temozolomide in Patients With Advanced Pancreatic NET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Phase I/II Study of RAD001 in Combination With Temozolomide in Patients With Advanced Pancreatic NET 
Comment: This research study will test the safety of RAD001 in combination with temozolomide.  ...

A total of 43 patients were enrolled, including 7 in cohort 1 and 36 in cohort 2. Treatment was associated with known toxicities of each drug; no synergistic toxicities were observed. Among 40 evaluable patients, 16 (40%) experienced a partial response. The median progression-free survival duration was 15.4 months. Median overall survival was not reached.

In Conclusion

Temozolomide and everolimus can be safely administered together in patients with advanced pancreatic NET, and the combination is associated with encouraging antitumor activity.

Future studies evaluating the efficacy of combination therapy compared to treatment with either agent alone are warranted.

Cancer. 2013 Jun 3. doi: 10.1002/cncr.28142. [Epub ahead of print]

item.title: New Senior VP Oncology and CMO Has Joined Mirna Therapeutics
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr Sinil Kim will be responsible for managing and directing the clinical development of MRX34, the first MicroRNA to enter a clinical trial in cancer. Prior to joining Mirna, he was Senior Director at Pfizer, and previously Director of Clinical Oncology at BMS.
Mirna filed its first IND in Q1 2013 and is currently conducting a Phase I Clinical Trial in patients with unresectable primary liver cancer or metastatic cancer with liver involvement (see Oncology8944: Mirna is First to Advance MicroRNA into the Clinic for Cancer).
Professional activity - Prior to joining Mirna Therapeutics, Dr. Kim was most recently a Senior Director at Pfizer Inc. in San Diego, CA, where he served as the Global Clinical Lead for Inlyta® (axitinib) and Torisel® (temsirolimus) programs.
Previously, Dr. Kim served as Director of Clinical Oncology at Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, where he worked on the clinical development of Erbitux® (cetuximab).
Dr. Kim was cofounder of DepoTech in San Diego, CA, where he invented several liposomal drug products, including DepoCyt® (cytarabine liposome injection), DepoDur® (morphine sulfate extended-release liposome injection) and Exparel® (bupivacaine liposome injectable suspension).
Education - A board certified medical oncologist, Dr. Kim obtained both his Bachelor of Science and medical degrees from the University of Washington in Seattle. His residency in internal medicine and post-doctoral fellowship in hematology/oncology were served, respectively, at the University of California, Irvine, and the University of California, San Diego.
Source: Mirna Therapeutics

It is indicated that the 1st study is expected to complete in a short period of time with a 2nd to begin before the end of the year.

item.title: re: Exenatide Evaluated as Treatment for Parkinson's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Exenatide Evaluated as Treatment for Parkinson's Disease 
Comment: The U. College (London) has started a PhII RCT to make an initial evaluation of possible benefits of the drug among approx 40 patients with moderate symptoms of PD.  ...
Results show that exenatide was well tolerated, although weight loss was common and l-dopa dose failures occurred in a single patient. Single-blinded rating of the exenatide group suggested clinically relevant improvements in PD across motor and cognitive measures compared with the control group. Exenatide-treated patients had a mean improvement at 12 months on the MDS-UPDRS of 2.7 points, compared with mean decline of 2.2 points in control patients (P = 0.037).
In conclusion, these results demonstrate a potential cost-efficient approach through which preliminary clinical data of possible biological effects are obtainable, prior to undertaking the major investment required for double-blind trials of a potential disease-modifying drug in PD. Trial registration.

As previously disclosed, the company is continuing into the expansion phase of the trial which is placebo controlled. Analysts at Wedbush believe T1DM to provide an additional $790M in revenues. Management continues to anticipate a partnership announcement for LX4211 before the onset of the Ph3 in H2 13. Currently, discussions are ongoing with multiple companies.
Lexicon anticipates data release in Q4 2013.

item.title: Biogen Idec Highlighted Three Pillars of Growth at Jefferies 2013 H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The first of the three pillars concerns the company's core products such as industry-leading MS Franchise (Avonex; Tysabri; Tecfidera;Fampyra) and Rituxan (standard of care for NHL and CLL). The second one is linked to new potential product launches such as Alprolix (rFIXFc), Eloctate (rFVIIIFc) and Plegridy (Interferon C), and the third one focuses more on an innovative pipeline to sustain long-term value creation.
AVONEX - maintaining a leading position in 1st-line MS use, and gaining share within the injectable class.
TYSABRI - with a solid growth trajectory driven by powerful efficacy; in development for SPMS (a large portion of the MS market) for which there is no effective therapies; ASCEND data readout expected in 2015.
TECFIDERA - approved by the FDA May 27,2013; providing a strong oral option for MS treatment. EC approval expected 2H 2013 (Germany first EU country).
- ALPROLIX - BLA submission accepted by the FDA (March 2013).
- ELOCTATE - BLA submission accepted by the FDA (May 2013).
- PLEGRIDY - FDA filing announced last month.

item.title: Janssen to Start Ph2 of Abiraterone with Different Steroids
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The study will assess safety/clinical benefit of abiraterone and prednisone or abiraterone and dexamethasone in prostate cancer patients. PE will evaluate Number of participants experiencing neither hypokalemia nor hypertension treatment-emergent adverse events up to Week 24.
In addition the impact of the study drug on quality of life and pain will be evaluated.

The study will also collect data on subsequent treatment of patients after they come off the study drug (up to a maximum of 5 years after the study starts).

By analyzing blood samples, the study aims to identify if some markers could help to understand if the treatment with abiraterone is effective and also help to understand if patients can become resistant.

Recruitment: n=144

Start date: MAy 2013 - Competion Dates May 2018 / November 2014

Location: Belgium

Source: clinicaltrials.gov

item.title: PROLOR Initiates Global Ph3 with hGH-CTP for AGHD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph3 RCT will evaluate the efficacy/safety of hGH-CTP injected weekly in adults with GHD. PE will assess change in truncal fat mass from baseline to 6 months after initiation of treatment. Importantly, the company has announced that it will be able to submit sooner than previously anticipated. Information on the regulary route is provided below.
Following regulatory review of the hGH-CTP Phase II data, PROLOR obtained clearance to use a pivotal Phase III trial design that includes a six-month assessment of efficacy and safety, followed by a subsequent six-month period of safety assessment. PROLOR's previous estimate and guidance had noted that a 12-month period of subsequent safety assessment might be required. This reduction of six months in the length of the required safety assessment and resulting reduction in the overall trial duration may enable PROLOR to submit an application for hGH-CTP marketing approval sooner than previously anticipated, subject to successful completion of the Phase III trial.
In the U.S., the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has confirmed that the regulatory pathway for hGH-CTP is via a Biologics License Application (BLA), which would be submitted subject to the successful completion of the Phase III trial. The BLA pathway provides the manufacturer with 12 years of data exclusivity in the U.S., starting at the time of FDA approval.
US; EU; Israel

item.title: Chelsea Therapeutics May Represent an Attractive Acquisition Target
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysts at Wedbush believe Chelsea Therapeutics to be an attractive acquisition target if Northera is approved. The company may likely need additional cash resources to complete an additional Ph3 trial and potentially launch Northera in 2014.
MOA/Indication: Pro-drug of norepinephrine for neurogenic orthostatic hypertension (NOH), an acute drop in blood pressure which can result in dizziness and injuries due to falls.
The condition is associated with patients having movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease.
Est. Timelines: resubmission of the Northera NDA in late Q2/early Q3 2013, potential approval around year-end 2013/early 2014 and potential launch in mid-2014.
The company ended Q1 with about $25.1 million in cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments.

item.title: Key Messages from Medivation Management at Jefferies H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pat Machado, Chief Business and Financial Officer, started his presentation reporting the recent approval of XTANDI in Canada. He outlined that more substantial growth opportunities to come lie in the earlier patient populations (pre-chemo setting). Management reported it is "anxiously awaiting the PREVAIL data this year as the gateway to expanding development of the drug further upstream".
Design: metastatic second and third line patients; 1700 patient study, which the company fully accrued in May 2012.
If the PREVAIL readout is positive, Xtandi will be the only oral agent with a proven OS benefit in second and third line patients (other drugs with survival benefit demonstrated in that population is Taxotere and Provenge).
>98% coverage on both the Medicare and the private pay side since the launch of the drug.
>19,000 bottles of Xtandi written by > 2800 individual prescribers and >400 institutions.
In the US, Medivation share profits on a 50-50 basis. In Q113, U.S net sales of Xtandi reached $75M ($37.7M for Medivation).
Zytiga plus prednisone; Jevtana; Provenge.
Composition patents in the US runs until 2027 and in EU/Japan till 2026.

item.title: Michael J. Fox Foundation Awards $1M to NeuroDerm
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: For the second time, NeuroDerm was awarded a $1M grant by the Foundation in order to support the upcoming Ph2 trial of ND0612, the company's patch for Parkinson's disease.
- The drug is a proprietary levodopa/carbidopa liquid formula for continuous administration through a sc delivery patch, that would maintain constant levodopa plasma concentrations.
In human trials, the drug has been shown to be safe and tolerable for the FIM.
  • Plasma levels of LD increased linearly with the ND0612 dose.
Neuroderm reformulates and/or co-formulates well established drugs to enable new routes of administration that achieve a better, or a new, clinical effect.
The company focuses on CNS diseases and its leading products include novel dermal delivery for the treatment of Parkinson ’s disease, ADD/ADHD and other CNS disorders and diseases.
Source: NeuroDerm

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a recent report from Canaccord, analysts have estimated that the company's drug discovery and development cannabinoid platform will yield additional promising drug candidate (i;e for ulcerative colitis and type 2 diabetes).
- Compounds for type 2 diabetes (GWP42004), and UC (GWP42003) are currently in Phase 2 development.
  • Phase 2 dose-ranging trial of GWP42004 expected to start H2/13
  • 1st POC data in UC due early 2014
- Earlier-stage cannabinoid compounds include epilepsy, schizophrenia and glioma.
Sativex is currently in a US Phase 3 program for cancer pain with top-line results from two Phase 3 trials due in 2014.
The company is currently in communications with FDA around US approval requirements for Sativex in MS spasticity.

item.title: Norgine's MOVIPREP Launched in Japan for Bowel Cleansing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In 2008 Norgine licensed MOVIPREP Japanese rights to Ajinimoto. For this market, a new flavour was developed in order to meet the tastes and preference of the patients.
- MOVIPREP is now the 1st Norgine's product onto the Japanese market.
- With MOVIPREP, Ajinimoto has been adding a new choice for patients in addition to NIFLEC®:
  • launched in 1992, is an orally-available gastrointestinal lavage solution.
  • widely used in pretreatment for colonoscopic examination as well as in pretreatment for colon surgery.
  • excellent cleansing effect on the digestive system and furthermore does not require diet restrictions which are usually necessary until the day before examination.
Bowel preparation prior to colonoscopy and colon surgery
Reduced dosage and volume
MOVIPREP was included onto Japan's National Health Insurance drug price standard list on May 31 2013.

item.title: Addex Completes Restructuring and Announces Product Strategy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr.Bharatt Chowrira has stepped down with immediate effect from his position as CEO of the Addex Group. The Board has asked Tim Dyer, co-founder and CFO, to head the Addex Group's plan to further reduce operating costs and seek investment, grants and partners to advance its pipeline and technology platform assets.
In the interim, an operational subcommittee of the Board, headed by André J. Mueller, Chairman of Addex, will directly supervise the Addex Group.
Continuation of:
- ADX71149 partnership with Janssen Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ADX71149, an mGluR2 positive allosteric modulator (PAM) jointly developed with Janssen, is currently in Phase 2 clinical development for schizophrenia and anxious depression and funded entirely by Janssen.
- Dipraglurant, an mGluR5 negative allosteric modulator will also continue to be investigated for use in Parkinson’s disease in collaboration with The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson’s Research.

XTANDI™ was approved in the U.S. for the same indication in August 2012, which covers the patient population treated in the Phase 3 AFFIRM study, and that the drug is currently in front of the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for approval in this indication as well.

item.title: Positive Opinion for BioPartners' Once-Weekly Somatropin Granted by EMA for Growth Hormone Deficiciency
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The CHMP's recommendation is now referred to the European Commission (EC), which grants approval for the EU, Norway and Iceland. The EC decision is anticipated in the middle of the third quarter of 2013. The drug is in joint development with LG Life Sciences.
On August 8th, the European Commission granted a marketing authorisation to Somatropin Biopartners in the EU, Norway and Iceland.
Somatropin Biopartners allows for a once-weekly injection instead of the currently available therapies that require once-daily injections of growth hormone. Poor adherence and noncompliance have been identified as a major cause of suboptimal efficacy of current growth hormone replacement therapy in children as well as adults.
Source: Biopartners
Treatment of growth hormone deficiency (GHD) in paediatric and adult patients.

Somatropin Biopartners

Somatropin Biopartners contains recombinant human growth hormone as the active ingredient in an innovative formulation based on sterile microparticular powder, to be reconstituted as a suspension in medium chain triglycerides prior to injection.
In Ph3 comparative trials in children and adults, respectively, which were conducted as part of a joint development programme with LG Life Sciences Ltd., Somatropin Biopartners proved to be safe and effective, showing sustained growth in children and beneficial effects on body composition in adults.
Source: Biopartners

Management indicated it will accelerate its strategic business development in the country, expand plans for production facility and in biopharmaceuticals. The company is also to explore further growth opportunities through external acquisitions and partnerships, such as in the area of Traditional Chinese Medicines (TCM).

- Mucosolvan® ampoules (Respiratory Disease), Micardis® (Hypertension), Spiriva® (COPD), Sifrol® (Parkinson’s Disease) and Actilyse (lytic treatment for stroke).
In addition, the company is actively introducing :
- Pradaxa® – the first new oral anticoagulant for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation for over 50 years – approved by China’s SFDA in February 2013.
- Trajenta®, for patients with Type 2 diabetes, DPP-4 inhibitor class of drugs jointly promoted by Boehringer Ingelheim and Eli Lilly -approved by the SFDA in March 2013.

item.title: Filler Toxin Combination for Lower Face Hemifacial Spasm (LFHS)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The treatment of LFHS with periorbital injections of higher doses of botulinum toxin can create disfiguring and indesirable weakness in the lower face (LF) during active facial movements. The use of asymmetric hyaluronidate filler injections to the LF provides a refinement allowing for a lowered neurotoxin dose. The filler creates a ballasting effect and involuntary facial movement. The conventional filler effect also further reduces asymmetric nasolabial folds and marionette lines.
Fifteen of 18 patients with LF spasms found the filler toxin in combination an improvement over neurotoxin alone.
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (31,3 KB)

item.title: ECE Intelligence Part III - Pfizer Symposium - Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : The Pfizer satellite symposium focused on changes in acromegaly management during the last decade and on the efficacy and safety of pegvisomant in the “real life”. Results of ongoing observational studies were analyzed as AcroBEL, "UK Acromegaly Register", "German Acromegaly Register", “Spanish Acromegaly Registry"(REA), ACROSTUDY, German Pegvisomant Observational Study (GPOS)..
Then the expert debate between AJ van der Lely and J Jorgensen was interrupted in an unexpected but spectacular manner. An attendee, who was actually S Neggers, gave his own conclusions. Then, playing a role game, M Buchfelder et N Moller from the audience took successively the discussion lead. They challenged the major points of the pegvisomant positioning in an assertive and convincing manner.

item.title: Amgen and Astellas Form JV for Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Amgen Astellas BioPharma KK, expected to be operating Oct. 1st, will co-develop and sell 5 drugs currently in Amgen's pipeline (please see details below), with the 1st commercial launch in Japan potentially occuring in 2016 (at the earliest). Of note AMG145 for cholesterol shows promise as a successor to Lipitor for high cholesterol, and AMG785 as a viable product alongside anti-inflammatory Celecox in the orthopedic space. These additions should enhance Astellas' mid/long-term pipeline and drive earnings together with Xtandi, Vesicare and mirabegron.
  • Led and staffed by employees of both companies (and new hires)
  • Astellas will conduct distribution/sales, while promotion and development will be done jointly by the JV and Astellas (each bearing 50% of the development and promotional costs).
  • Astellas will pay a royalty to Amgen based on sales and Amgen will supply the products, while profits will be split. Amgen will make the JV a wholly-owned subsidiary in 2020, but Astellas will still have selling rights thereafter.
  • No lump-sum or milestone payments will be made, so we see limited impact on F3/14
AMG-145 - human monoclonal antibody that inhibits Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9 (PCSK9). It is being investigated as a treatment for hyperlipidemia.
The drug shows promise as a successor to Lipitor for high cholesterol.
AMG-785 (romosozumab) - humanized monoclonal antibody that inhibits the action of sclerostin. It is being developed in collaboration with UCB for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.
AMG-102 (rilotumumab) - human monoclonal antibody that inhibits the action of hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor. investigated for gastric cancer. (see Oncology8297: 1st Data Demonstrating A Potential Treatment Biomarker For Gastric Cancer).
AMG-103 (blinatomumab) - anti-CD19 x anti-CD3 (BiTE®) bispecific antibody investigated for ALL; NHL.
AMG-337 - small molecule inhibitor of MET, investigated for gastric cancer.
From Amgen; ThomsonOne

item.title: Peptidomimetics Identified as Novel Class of Drugs for Advanced Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a new study available online at Nature Communications a team of researchers at UT Southwestern Medical Center found that they could disrupt androgen receptor signaling using a novel class of drugs called peptidomimetics.
The peptidomimetic agents block the activity of the androgen receptor even in the presence of androgen by attacking the protein in a different spot from where the androgen binds.
The researchers tested their drug in mouse and human tissue models. The novel drug proved non-toxic and prevented androgen receptor signaling in cancer cells.
Further testing is needed before a drug could move to Phase 1 clinical trials that involve human participants.

Nature Communications 4, 1923 doi:10.1038/ncomms2912

  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (66,3 KB)

item.title: Sanofi Presentation at Bank of America Merrill Lynch H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Paul Chew (Senior VP, Chief Medical Offcier, Chief Scientific Officer, US) outlined growth platforms grew by +8.6% in Q1:13 (the emerging markets being the largest in term of sales). Management also reported that the company is less focused on coporate directed R&D, and is taking advantage of regional hubs. Although the global MS market is still dominated by ABCRE (Avonex, Betaseron, Copaxone, Rebif, Extavia) he anticipates Aubagio to be almost half the market by 2019.
P. Chew indicated that Sanofi has:
- a hub in Boston, with Genzyme, Pasteur and pharma in one location in Cambridge, very closed to Harvard, close to MIT.
- academic alliances with Harvard, MIT, Caltech, Hopkins and other areas as well because " ... we know that not all of the innovation will come from within the four walls of Sanofi".
He added that " ... So we need to ensure that success going forward with an efficient global R&D organization around the hub model. We have the hubs in Germany, France and Boston leveraging the economies of scale in the collocation there ... "
" ... focusing on the high-value products. Not quantity, but quality. And working with new models of external innovation and acquisitions, externalization through, for example, Regeneron and Genzyme, but by no means the only ones".
The global MS market is still dominated by ABCRE (Avonex, Betaseron, Copaxone, Rebif, Extavia).
Management expects " ... the landscape to look quite different in seven years because right now the ABCRE injectables are going to be declining as we have the availability of oral therapies, including Aubagio, anticipated to be almost half the market by 2019".

item.title: Valeant Agrees to Acquire Baush & Lomb for $8.7 Billion
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Acquiring Bausch and Lomb could contribute meaningful progress relative to two of Valeant’s high-profile strategic objectives: 1) becoming a Top-15 global pharma company, and 2) expanding its ophthalmology footprint. Valeant has identified Ophthalmology as one of its three priority categories. With respect to scale, a Bausch & Lomb transaction could expand Valeant’s revenues by ~50% to exceed $8 billion in F2014 and grow its ophthalmology revenues approximately 10-fold. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter.
Valeant will pay aggregate consideration of $8.7 billion in cash, of which approximately $4.5 billion will go to an investor group led by Warburg Pincus and approximately $4.2 billion will be used to repay Bausch + Lomb's outstanding debt. Valeant expects to achieve at least $800 million in annual cost savings by end of 2014. Bausch + Lomb’s expects to have revenues of approximately $3.3 billion and adjusted EBITDA in 2013 of approximately $720 million.
The transaction is expected to be immediately accretive to Valeant's cash earnings per share. Assuming the transaction occurred on January 1, 2013 and assuming the full realization of synergies, the acquisition would have been approximately 40% accretive to Valeant’s expected 2013 Cash EPS.
The transaction will be financed with debt and approximately $1.5 - $2.0 billion of new equity. Valeant has secured fully committed debt financing for the transaction from Goldman Sachs Bank USA. Taking into account the anticipated equity raise, Valeant’s debt to pro forma adjusted EBITDA ratio will be approximately 4.6 times.
Bausch & Lomb would bring to Valeant its well-known contact lenses, drugs to treat eye conditions such as glaucoma, and instruments and devices used in eye surgery. (approx. 17% of Bausch & Lomb's $3 billion in revenues last year came from that business).
Big players including Novartis AG and Abbott Laboratories.
Source: Valeant; Wall Street Journal; ThomsonOne; Companies Websites/PR.
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (75,6 KB)
