item.title: Bayer's Visanne (Endometriosis) Not Included on the National Reimbursement List in Sweden
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The decision of the Swedish Dental and Pharmaceutical Benefits Agency (TLV) was based on a cost-effectiveness analysis that compared Visanne to other progestogens which are already included on the Swedish reimbursement list for this indication.
The TLV maintains that data supplied by Bayer do not provide an adequate base for demonstrating Visanne improvements in terms of efficacy or side-effects compared to other progestogens.
In addition, the price proposed for Visanne has been evaluated as "considerably" more expensive compared to the costs of the comparators.
Finally, the TLV has stressed that, in order to decide if Visanne should have a restricted reimbursement, the company will need to demonstrate its marginal benefit in a clearly identifiable group of patients which would offset its higher cost, compared to treatment with other progestogens.
Visanne was granted marketing authorisation in Europe in 2009.
The TLV decision represents a setback for Bayer as the inclusion into the Swedish reimbursement list would have certainly had a positive impact on product sales.
The drug was approved for reimbursement in Poland and the Czech Republic in 2011.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: Recap from J&J's R&D and Business Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management presented the scope and potential of its pipeline, remaining focused on addressing areas of high unmet needs. New product launches (led by Zytiga, Xarelto and ibrutinib) continue to grow and the business is delivering consistent increase. J&J expects that both oncologists and urologists will drive Zytiga growth. Thus far, the company has not seen resistance from urologists because of Zytiga use in combination with prednisone and monitoring of hepatotoxicity. Further, management indicates that prednisone use may benefit patients in feeling less fatigued and could actually translate into an advantage for Zytiga.
No mention of J&J's botulinum toxin in the presentation.
Marketing Exclusivity - Zytiga has NCE (new chemical entity) marketing exclusivity until April 28, 2016. Provided there are no patents to challenge, a generic manufacturer can file a P3 application with the FDA upon NCE expiration, or April 28, 2016. If a P4 is filed, then the generic manufacturer can file one year prior to expiration of NCE exclusivity or April 28, 2015. There will then be a 30-month stay (that begins April 28, 2016) and thus, will expire October 28, 2018 (unless there is a positive court decision prior).
Reimbursement - Zytiga gained approval in the chemo-naive mCRPC patient in 2012. Chemo-naïve reimbursement is still an ongoing process in the EU with rollout continuing across various regions – however, Zytiga has received reimbursement in Germany (See Oncology8899: Zytiga Receives Second Positive Verdict in Germany), and in 2 Nordic countries.
Market Share - Zytiga currently holds 30% share (Apr-13) in the mCRPC market (up ~3 points from 4Q12) with an approximate 20% share in the chemo naives and a 57% share in the chemo refractory population. Share remains stable in the chemo refractory market and has been steadily rising in the chemo naïve population since Jan-13.
Zytiga Sales - There are an estimated 28,000 chemo naïve patients and 10,000 chemo refractory treated every month in the US. Approximately 45% of Zytiga sales are in the pre-chemo setting.
Since launch, nearly 2/3 of Xtandi use has been in Zytiga-experienced patients.
J&J’s has significantly restructured its pharmaceutical business over the years. Several years back the company started to realign its R&D into more of a end-to-end strategy focused on 5 therapeutic areas.
1) Immunology -- sirukumab (anti-IL-6) for RA, guselkumab (anti-IL-23) for RA and psoriasis, and the JAK inhibitor ASP015K that is currently in a ~900-patient global Phase IIb trial for RA that includes anti-TNF naïve and experienced patients;
2) Neuroscience -- several Alzheimer's compounds including Bapineuzumab follow-on AAB- 003, a therapeutic vaccine AAC-001, and a BACE inhibitor for Prodromal Alzheimer’s;
3) Infectious Diseases & Vaccines -- FlueCell with proof-of-concept on 2-13-2014, Flu monoclonal antibody (mAb), which will have proof-of-concept in 2014, and Rabies mAb;
4) Cardiovascular & Metabolism -- JNJ-54452840, a novel β1-Andrenergic Receptor autoantibody that holds potential as a novel approach to heart failure treatment;
5) Oncology -- daratumumab, which has a breakthrough therapy designation from the FDA for refractory Multiple Myeloma and is currently in Phase I/II trials, and siltuximab for multi-centric Castleman's disease.
Line extensions of existing products - particularly Simponi, Stelara, Velcade and Xarelto.
Emerging markets - 20% of Pharma sales -- up from 12% in 2007 -- and oncology drugs in particular are performing well there. J&J continues to leverage its product portfolio through line extension launches globally, particularly in Japan and China.
1) ibrutinib (partnered with PCYC), an oral once-daily treatment for B-cell malignancies; 2) Sirturo, the first drug to treat tuberculosis with a new mechanism of action in 40 years; and 3) sirukumab, the first anti-IL-6 cytokine monoclonal antibody for rheumatoid arthritis, partenred with GSK.

item.title: Merck & Co. Discontinues Development of Preladenant for Parkinson
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph3 for the Adenosine A2A receptor antagonist included three RCT. Two of these assessed preladenant when combined to levodopa in patients with moderate-to-severe PD, and one evaluated the drug as monotherapy in early stages of the disease. Merck said the decision to discontinue the studies was not based on any safety findings.
Preliminary review of data from 3 Ph3 trials failed to provide evidence of the drug's efficacy when compared to placebo.
Cowen & Co. had predicted preladenant would generate annual sales of $200M by 2016.

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: this part focused on the difficulties of diagnosing & monitoring Cushing's disease and of choosing a medical appropriate treatment for each patient. There were no investigational drugs discussed nor on-going trials, but only medical therapy currently in use, approved or not for Cushing's disease. Pasireotide use was analyzed in this context without particular highlight. J Newell Price showed the results of monitoring pasireotide treatment with salivary cortisol, the corresponding study presented at the same time at the poster session.
Please find the detailed Cushing session in the word document attached.
Please find hereby the pasireotide poster related to treatment monitoring through late night salivary cortisol. Those results have indeed been cited during this session.

item.title: ECE Intelligence Part I - Novartis symposium Part 1 - Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: this year ECE was held in Copenhagen and attended by around 2800 delegates. There were no major results neither new clinical trials presented in pituitary and NETs sessions for our competitors but rather guidelines and state of the art for managing these pathologies.
Both Novartis and Pfizer symposia wanted to be educational, atmosphere was sober (no audience vote, no promotional “film”or material, no ipads) and focused on every day’s life practioners experience and data coming from observational studies and registers.
Novartis Satellite Symposium focused on pituitary tumors, one part related to Cushing’s disease and the other one on acromegaly. The acromegaly part was entirely led by Annamaria Colao.
  • There were no results from PAOLA study, no mention of previous pasireotide trials in acromegaly nor mention of any clinical trial in acromegaly.
  • The focus was on disease control, more particularly on suboptimal control or absence of control of the disease in the “real life” of a non negligible part of patients.
  • Medical treatment ( in particular classical SSA) results were seen through “real life” (registers and observational studies)
Please find the detailed acromegaly session in the word document attached.

item.title: Astellas' Vesomni Approved in the Netherlands for BPH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Vesomni is a once-daily, fixed-dose combination of the antimuscarinic solifenacin and alpha blocker tamsulosin. Approval in the Netherlands kicks off the mutual recognition process for EU-wide registration.
Treatment for lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men with BPH who are not responding to current therapy.
The Dutch approval is based on the results of the phase III NEPTUNE study, which found that Vesomni improved LUTS in men aged over 45 with both voiding and storage symptoms, performing better than both placebo and tamsulosin monotherapy.
Source: http://www.pmlive.com/pharma_news/astellas_gets_first_ok_for_prostate_drug_vesomni_478629?utm_campaign=dailycontent&utm_medium=email&utm_source=fulllist

item.title: AOTM's Transparency Board Favours Reimbursement of Zytiga in One Indication on Condition of Price Drop
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Transparency Board of the Agency for Health Technology Assessment in Poland (AOTM) has recommended that the reimbursement of Zytiga (abiraterone acetate) be continued as a guaranteed benefit, as a second-line treatment, in the treatment of castration-resistant metastatic prostate cancer in men whose disease has progressed during or after chemotherapy containing docetaxel.
However, the Board stipulates that the continued reimbursement of the drug is dependent on its price being reduced to a level within the cost-effectiveness threshold observed in Poland. The Board continues to say that while second-line treatment of this condition has documented evidence of its efficacy, it remains associated with a considerable frequency of adverse events, adding that the financing model for Zytiga should involve a drug programme that includes a defined algorithm for the monitoring of patients.
At the same time, the Board has recommended that Zytiga be withdrawn from reimbursement in the treatment of men with metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer without symptoms, or with mild or slight symptoms, after failed treatment with androgen suppression therapy, in the case of patients for whom chemotherapy is not clinically indicated. This is because, as it states, the drug's clinical effectiveness in this indication is not yet fully documented, while it is associated with significant toxicity, which are not balanced with the potential health benefits – and its cost is above the cost-effectiveness threshold in Poland.
Considering the fact that – according to the AOTM's document – Zytiga is already subject to reimbursement – either within the National Health Fund's list of standard "chemotherapy" treatments, or in the "non-standard chemotherapy" programme, there is a possibility that a similar situation could develop as has developed in the case of two Celgene (United States) drugs, in the case of which the Transparency Board also recommended price reductions to within the cost-effectiveness threshold
The cost per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) threshold introduced in Poland is seemingly being applied quite literally, rather than being seen as a "guideline", as was stated when it was first introduced. Meanwhile, the rejection of Zytiga in the other indication may indeed be based on clinical concerns, but it is also sure that the economic concerns are of an equal importance.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: Immunotherapy May be Used in up to 60% of Cancers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysts at U.S bank Citigroup highlights the growing excitement surrounding so-called immunotherapy after positive results from clinical trials conducted by companies such as BMS and Roche Holding. Other leading players with a range of drugs, vaccines and cell therapy treatments in the cancer immunotherapy field include GlaxoSmithKline , AstraZeneca , Novartis , Merck & Co and Amgen.
Bristol-Myers Squibb's nivolumab (PD-1 inhibitor) and Roche's MPDL3280A (PD-1 inhibitor) had an impressive effect against a variety of cancers. Preliminary results were released last week, and further details will be presented at ASCO.
Analysts believe that the immunotherapy field could also benefit from a new FDA initiative to speed approval of important and innovative drugs.
Source: ThomsonOne

item.title: Medivation Highlights From The UBS Global Healthcare Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
AFFIRM

post-chemo

1,200 patients

Median survival 18.4 months compared to 13.6 months of the placebo arm, 37% reduction in the risk of death.

A 4.8-month benefit in survival compared to placebo, which has not been bettered by any agent.

All secondary endpoints were achieved.

No real difference with placebo arm in terms of AEs

PREVAIL

pre-chemo

1,717 Patients

The co-primary endpoints of the study are OS and PFS. The trial goal is to support registration in second-line and third-line patients. Medivation believe that there is data to suggest that the effect in the pre-chemo population may be better than the post-chemo population

STRIVE (US)

2nd line – H2H bicalutamide

Metastatic patients

Endpoints: Affecting time to PSA and time to radiographic progression

TERRAIN (EU)

2nd line – H2H bicalutamide

Both metastatic and non-metastatic patients

Endpoints: Affecting time to PSA and time to radiographic progression

Hormone-Naïve Trial

1st line pts

Enrolled 67 patients who had not received any therapy, not even Lupron

Median PSA reduction of 99.6% and 93% of patients had a PSA response of 80% or greater

Neoadjuvant Study

Prior to prostatectomy

50 patients

“These patients are going to get XTANDI for six months in a cocktail, and then when they go on to get their prostatectomy, the pathologist will then take the prostate and look at it under very fine sectioning and see is there any cancer left in that prostate. Because if there isn’t and we know they had cancer to begin with, and there isn’t any cancer left in the prostate, that’s important because obviously we’re trying to find ways of moving upstream in patients to see if we can increase the number of patients who actually might not only benefit from the drug but even be cured by a drug”

  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (134,7 KB)

item.title: ASCO Preview and Oncology Update
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysts at Leerink Swann hosted a call with 2 KOLs to discuss the landscape for new therapeutic agents in prostate cancer. Overall the 2 KOLs (one urologist and one oncologist) were focused on determining the optimal sequence of treatment of Xtandi and Zytiga to achieve the best outcomes in patients and less focused on cross-trial comparisons of efficacy. More details available below.
Physicians were impressed with the hormone naïve data for Xtandi, but would want to see longer follow-up and a head-to-head comparison with Casodex to prescribe the agent in this setting but there is clear interest in potentially expanding the use of Xtandi to earlier stage patients.
- KOLs are not particularly concerned with statistical significance of overall survival in the Xtandi PREVAIL study, as survival benefit has already been proven in the post-chemo setting
- With two well tolerated, highly effective anti-androgens available, the key question facing physicians are how to sequence these agents and to find predictors of resistance or response in patients, rather than cross-trial comparisons.
- Provenge DTC advertisements have increased patient inquiries but have not yet led to increases in treatment.
- In the pipeline, KOLs are most excited about immunotherapy such as anti-PD1 (BMY and others), ipilimumab (BMY), and Prostvac (Bavarian Nordic).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Argentina's Pharma Market Expected to Triple in a Decade
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Argentine domestic market is expected to almost triple in a decade, increasing from a value of USD5.6 billion in 2012 to USD15 billion by 2020. The fast growth achieved in the sector is expected to be driven by a strong presence of domestic manufacturers, high-quality production capabilities, and positive clinical trial regulations. With this potential sector boost, Argentina is expected to become one of the fastest growing pharmaceutical markets in Latin America, with a number of local players such as Roemmers and Bago becoming some of the best performing companies in the region.

The size of the Argentine market is expected to almost triple in a decade, increasing from a value of USD5.6 billion in 2012 to USD15 billion by 2020, according to Pharma Times. According to the source, domestic manufacturers currently account for more than 50% of Argentina's drug market, with key domestic players including Roemmers and Bago, while multinationals such as Bayer (Germany), Novartis (Switzerland), Roche (Switzerland), Abbott (UK), and GlaxoSmithKline (UK) also operating in the country.
The generic drug sector in Argentina has also grown, with sales increasing as a result of legislation included in the Health Emergency Act mandating physicians to include the generic names of prescribed drug products, which allows for generic substitution by pharmacists. According to the source, in the past, Argentina's regulations governing international property rights have also provided an advantage to domestic companies, which were free to manufacture and market products similar to patented versions. Furthermore, according to the source, Argentina is also regarded as a favourable destination for cost-effective clinical trials within Latin America, and was one of the first countries in the region to implement the recommendation of the World Health Organization (WHO) on good manufacturing practice (GMP) and control standards, endorsing compliance to an international set of quality standards for pharmaceutical production. Clinical trials in the country are compliant to those of the International Conference on Harmonization-Good Clinical Practice (ICH-GCP).

The fast growth achieved in the sector is expected to be driven by a strong presence of domestic manufacturers, high-quality production capabilities and positive clinical trial regulations that are expected to boost the sector.
Unlike other Latin American countries, the trend towards domestic pharmaceutical production has existed for a few decades in Argentina, given the fact that local players are incentivised by the government since they are provided with benefits such as favourable tariff protection while the costs of raw materials imports undercut the transfer pricing which is generally applicable for multinationals.
On the other hand, Argentina's pharmaceutical sector is also facing a number of barriers, including the fact that they lack the vast production capacities of Chinese and Indian manufacturers, and are unable to compete with the lower process that these foreign firms are able to offer. Argentina is also facing competition from upcoming pharmaceutical markets such as Mexico and Brazil. Furthermore, although investment in research and development has increased in the last few years, local makers have not been able to develop new chemical entities, making it difficult for domestic firms to be competitive with innovative multinational companies.
Nevertheless, with this potential sector boost, Argentina is expected to become one of the fastest growing markets in Latin America, with local players such as Roemmers and Bago rising to become some of the top companies in the region.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: XenoPort Discontinues Arbaclofen Placarbil Program
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : Xenoport has announced discontinuation of the development of arbaclofen placarbil based on top-line data showing that twice-daily doses of the product missed the co-primary endpoints in a Phase III trial to treat spasticity in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
XenoPort had an SPA from FDA for the trial, which enrolled 228 patients. In 2011, XenoPort discontinued development of arbaclofen placarbil -- a transported prodrug of R-baclofen, a GABA B receptor agonist -- to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
XenoPort markets Horizant gabapentin enacarbil, a transported prodrug of gabapentin, to treat restless legs syndrome (RLS) and to manage postherpetic neuralgia (PHN). The company's next most advanced product is XP21279, a sustained-release transported prodrug of L-dopa in Phase II testing to treat Parkinson's disease (PD).
Source : BioCentury Extra for Monday, May 20, 2013

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Actavis Acquires Warner Chilcott
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Actavis to acquire Warner Chilcott in a stock-for-stock transaction valued at $8.5 billion to create a leading global specialty pharmaceutical company.
When fully operational, the combination is estimated to have around $11 billion in annual revenue. It will be the third-largest U.S. specialty pharmaceutical company focused on core therapeutic categories of Women’s Health, Gastroenterology, Urology and Dermatology. See PharmaWorld10443: Actavis in Early Talks to Buy Warner Chilcott for >$4.5bn.
The combined entity is expected to provide a firm foundation to support the launch of new products over the next several years, particularly in Women's Health.
This includes Minastrin 24 Fe, Esmya, metronidazole vaginal gel 1.5%, the progestin-only contraceptive patch and other women's health products in development from the recent acquisition of Uteron Pharma SA.
The newly created company, expected to be called Actavis Plc or a variant thereof, will be led by the current Actavis leadership team. The transaction is expected to close by the end of 2013.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: KOL Viewpoints On Bayer’s Newly Approved Xofigo
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: KOLs lean towards combination use with Xofigo.
Early KOL opinion suggests that combination therapy is integral to the uptake of Xofigo as there seems to be a muted enthusiasm for use as a monotherapy in advanced CRPC patients.
However, buoyed by the median 3.6 month OS benefit, KOLs appear to have little hesitation about using the product in a combinational setting once it becomes available, also advocating its use at earlier stages within the treatment paradigm.
Other notable barriers include:
  • Impracticalities of administration and the stigma attached to radio pharmaceuticals
  • Only licensed radiopharmaceutical physicians based at specialist facilities will be able to prescribe Xofigo in the US
  • Bayer's existing sales force in the cancer space (via Nexavar and Stivarga) will need to be increased or it will be rather stretched as the company will have to target both urologists and radiologists in addition to oncologists
  • Priced at $69,000 for a single treatment course (of six injections), the cost of Xofigo is comparable to Zytiga and Xtandi although if used is in combination, the cost will go up exponentially
    • Dendreon's Provenge could be the one loser, given that patients are unlikely to be prescribed two infused therapies that have a combined cost of between $160,000 and $170,000.
On the positive side, KOLs appear to be sold on the notion that Xofigo as an alpha emitter is significantly more targeted than beta emitters (its shorter wavelength should reduce damage to nearby healthy tissues).
FDA approval of Xofigo (last Wednesday) came more than three months ahead of a scheduled PDUFA date.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sanofi To Overhaul Toulouse Research Site
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Rather than exiting the facility as was suggested last year, Sanofi will now reorganise the Toulouse site and preserve around 500 of the 612 staff employed there.
In September last year, Sanofi stated it would cut around 900 jobs in France by 2015 as well as selling the Toulouse site -which would bring the total job losses to around 1500 personnel. Sanofi and the French government have been at loggerheads over the proposed move and now, it seems there has been a resolution. The move to close down the site in the first place was to counter revenue lost from patent expiries on drugs such as Plavix.
The Toulouse site (Oncology R&D) will continue to operate over the next five years while Sanofi evaluates options including the creation of a technology platform to provide services for itself and other companies as well as establishing local start-ups.
Sanofi also noted that it still plans to regroup its research activities in France in the regions of Paris and Lyon, in Strasbourg and to transform the Montpellier R&D site into a strategic development centre.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: NICE Gives a 'Yes' for Astellas' Betmiga
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NICE has issued final draft guidance recommending Astellas' Betmiga (mirabegron) for reimbursement.
Mirabegron was approved in the EU this January and is recommended for overactive bladder syndrome in people unsuited to antimuscarinic drugs because they are contraindicated, clinically ineffective or cause unacceptable side-effects.
NICE still recommends bladder training and lifestyle advice as first-line treatments.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novo Nordisk Converts Facility for Future Production of Semaglutide (Once-Weekly GLP-1)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The 380 million Danish Kroner investment will be used to convert the existing Kalundborg manufacturing plant. Other ongoing investment projects in Denmark include a new domicile in Bagsværd and a new facility in Kalundborg for the production of biopharmaceuticals (such as haemophilia medicine and growth hormone).
Established in 1969.
Covering an area of 135 hectares.
Since 1999, Novo Nordisk has invested more than 7.5 billion kroner in the facility and, as a result, has created more than 1,000 new jobs.
Source: Novo Nordisk

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Top Messages from MedyTox' 1Q:13 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medytox registered 1Q13 sales of W8.8bn (up 27.4% y-y). Growth drivers were 1/ the joint sales contract with Pacific Pharma, allowing Pacific Pharma to sell ‘Meditoxin’ for cosmetic use in the domestic market, and 2/ the increase of the total exports (18.6% y-y to W2.9bn) thanks to the addition of new exports to Central America and Latin America.
See Neurology6464: Medy-Tox and Pacific Pharma Have Signed Joint Marketing Agreement.
Source: Woori Investment

item.title: re: J&J Seeks Approval For Simponi in Ulcerative Colitis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Janssen has submitted an sBLA to the U.S. FDA and a Type II Variation to the EMA requesting approval of SIMPONI® (golimumab) for the treatment of adult patients with moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis (UC) who have had an inadequate response to conventional therapy. 
FDA approved an expanded indication for Simponi (golimumab) to treat adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis who did not respond to conventional treatment or requires continuous steroid use.
The approval was based on 2 clinical studies demonstrating that the tumour necrosis factor-alpha inhibitor was associated with a higher clinical response rate than placebo.
Simponi is currently approved to treat psoriatic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis.
The drug had sales of $607 million in 2012 and analysts estimate that sales could double to $1.2 billion by 2017.

item.title: Tokai Raised $35.5M Series E Financing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The proceeds will be used to expand the ongoing ARMOR2 Ph2 clinical trial of galeterone in patients with CRPC and prepare for registration studies.
The second study in Tokai’s ARMOR (Androgen Receptor Modulation Optimized for Response) clinical development program.
ARMOR2 is designed to assess the efficacy and safety of a new oral formulation of galeterone in distinct populations of CRPC patients, including both metastatic and non-metastatic treatment-naïve and those who have progressed while taking Zytiga® (abiraterone acetate) or Xtandi® (enzalutamide).
  • The primary endpoints of the study are reduction in prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, and safety.
  • The secondary endpoints include tumor responses by RECIST. Patients who respond to therapy will have the opportunity to continue treatment in an extension arm.
Source: Tokai

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Mirna is First to Advance MicroRNA into the Clinic for Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Mirna’s pipeline consists of 8 lead candidates, all of which are directed toward oncology. The company has initiated a Ph1 of MRX34 in patients with liver cancer. The Ph1 study will follow a standard oncology study design, and is expected to enroll up to 48 patients in total.
http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01829971
The preclinical profile of MRX34 across a range of tumors strongly suggests that miRNA-based therapeutics may represent a potent, new class of anticancer drugs working through a mechanism that affects multiple oncogenic pathways simultaneously.
Source: Mirna

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Algeta Reports 1Q:13 Results and US Approval of Radium-233 for CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Xofigo is the first alpha particle-emitting radioactive therapeutic agent approved by the FDA. The commercial production of the drug is underway, with first doses expected to be ready for patient treatment within a few weeks. Management also reported good progress with the development of its TTC pipeline, and looks forward to the results of further PC evaluations to advance candidates into clinical in 2014.
Patient with CRPC, symptomatic bone metastases and no visceral metastatic disease.

Bayer has received a positive opinion from the EMA CHMP recommending radium Ra 223 dichloride (radium-223) for approval with a proposed indication for the treatment of adults with castration-resistant prostate cancer, symptomatic bone metastases and no known visceral metastases.
According to Algeta CEO: " ...
Algeta is eligible for royalties and milestones based on Bayer’s sales of Xofigo outside the US, and Algeta US, LLC is co-promoting Xofigo with Bayer in the US.
Bayer submitted a MAA to the EMA in Dec 2012.
Please see Oncology5609: Bayer Pay Euro 560M to Co-Dev. Alpharadin for Bone Metastases in Symptomatic HRPC Patients.

item.title: Low-Cost Rotavirus Vaccine to Reach the Indian Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bharat Biotech has announced positive results from a Ph3 clinical trial of a ROTAVAC®, a rotavirus vaccine developed and manufactured in India. The company has announced a price of US$ 1.00/dose for the vaccine, and will soon file for registration in India.
- A originated from an attenuated strain of rotavirus that was isolated from an Indian child at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences in New Delhi in 1985-86.
Design
Findings
The India-developed rotavirus vaccine ROTAVAC® is efficacious in preventing severe rotavirus diarrhoea in low-resource settings in India.
ROTAVAC® significantly reduced severe rotavirus diarrhoea by 56% during the first year of life, with protection continuing into the second year of life.
Moreover, the vaccine also showed impact against severe diarrhoea of any cause
Profile
Products / Vaccines
Pipeline

Comments
Prime Minister Narendra Modi on 9 March 2015 launched Rotavac, the third such vaccine, besides GSK's Rotarix and Merck’s RotaTeq against rotavirus. Rotavac will cost a mere 1$ (vs 75$ for RotaTeq and over 106$ for Rotarix).
In India, diarrhoea caused by rotavirus kills nearly 80 thousand children under the age of 5 years and lead to 10 lakh hospitalizations every year. India accounts for 22% of the global deaths that occurs due to diarrhoea-causing rotavirus.

item.title: Allergan to Start New Ped Trials of BOTOX® for UI Due to NDO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3 study which will assess the safety and efficacy of BOTOX® in approx. 132 patients (between the ages of 8 to 17 years). Another new Ph3 trial will start in September 2013 to assess long-term safety and efficacy of the drug in approx. 100 patients (between the ages of 8 to 19 years). Both PE will evaluate change from baseline in daily average frequency of daytime UI episodes.
  • Start date: June 2013
  • Completion dates: Nov 2016 / Aug 2017
  • Location: USA
  • Start date: Sept 2013
  • Completion dates: Oct 2018
  • Location: USA
Source: clinicaltrials.gov

item.title: New Takeda Device with Safety Needle for Enantone
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Claudia Schymczyk (Marketing) please find attached the Takeda folder that Ipsen Germany got from Austria. The message is mentioning that the new safety needle is necessary because of decree of the Federal Ministry of labor, social protection and protection of employee before injury from sharp or sharp medical instruments, which is part of an EU directive from 1st of June 2010 - now transposed into national law on 11. of May 2013.
The Takeda device looks like the same needle (Magellan™ Safety Needles) we had for Decapeptyl/Pamorelin (here in Germany we had it from 2007 untill end of 2011).
Takeda has also launched Prostap with the same device in UK (Thanks to Sally Hodgson for this information).
As you know the decision was made to go worldwide to a 20 G needle without safety for 1-month, 3-month and 6-month formulations as 20G needles didn't exist with safety needle at that time.
- "to achieve the safest possible working environment by preserving injuries to workers caused by all medical sharps (including needle-sticks) and protecting workers at risk in the hospital and healthcare sector". According the Legal the current EU legislation does not create any legal obligation for Pharma Companies, but only for hospitals/ healthcare sector.

All four geographic regions contributed to the organic sales growth of Merck Serono. Europe accounted for the highest proportion (or 43%), of the division's sales (Q1 2012: 44%). item.title: Actavis in Early Talks to Buy Warner Chilcott for >$4.5bn
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Warner Chilcott total revenue in the quarter ended March 31, 2013 was $593 million (a decrease of $92 million, or 13%, compared to the quarter ended March 31, 2012). The company's ASACOL is the leading treatment for ulcerative colitis in the U.S. market for orally administered 5-aminosalicylic acid products.
http://ir.wcrx.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=763847
- To let Actavis sell Warner Chilcott’s products abroad. Actavis is expanding in European and emerging markets, and had 18 percent of its sales outside the U.S. last year, while 90 percent of Warner Chilcott’s sales were in the U.S. or Canada.
Women's Health
ACTONEL® is the leading branded product in the U.S. non-injectable osteoporosis market for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis in women.
LOESTRIN® 24 Fe was the first oral contraceptive featuring 24 days of active therapy compared with the traditional 21-day dosing regimen. The Company's oral contraceptive portfolio also includes FEMCON® Fe, OVCON® 35 and OVCON® 50 and ESTROSTEP® Fe.
ESTRACE® Cream is a leading topical product for the treatment of urogenital symptoms of menopause.
FEMHRT® is a systemic therapy for the treatment of menopausal symptoms.
Dermatology
DORYX® 150 mg, a tetracycline-class oral antibiotic, is indicated for the adjunctive treatment of severe acne. DORYX is one of the leading branded oral tetracyclines in the U.S. market
Urology
ENABLEX® is prescribed to adults to treat the symptoms of overactive bladder.

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Citing unnamed sources, Globes has reported that as a consequence of the deal signed with Roche, Chiasma cannot move forward on projects at early development stages.
See Endocrinology7265: Roche Acquires Rights To Octreolin in $595m Deal.
CEO Roni Mamluk predicted that clinical study with Octreolin (for acromegaly) would be completed in 2014, and if successful the drug could be launched in early 2015.
Source: First Word Pharma

Comments
Interesting to see that worldwide, "other indications" represent 20% of SSA market sales - amounting 300M€.

item.title: Key Highlights from Medivation’s Q12013 Financial Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Xtandi is going from strength to strength and final EU decision for post chemo approval should come by mid- July 2013.
- Net sales of XTANDI® (enzalutamide) capsules for the quarter were $75.4 million, an increase of $18.0 million over the prior quarter
- From its US launch until the end of the first quarter, prescriptions for more than 19,000 XTANDI bottles have been written by more than 2,800 individual prescribers and more than 400 institutional accounts
o More than 98% of both Medicare and commercial plans now covering XTANDI
o From a prescriber perspective, XTANDI has over 90% aided awareness among oncologists and urologists and leads in share of voice for oncologists
- Medivation expect to hear a final decision from the European Commission shortly regarding their post chemo filing in the EU
o EU final decision should come by mid-July2013
o XTANDI marketing applications are also under review in Switzerland, South Korea, Canada and Brazil for the treatment of post-chemotherapy mCRPC patients
o Astellas expect to file in Japan by end 2013/early 2014
- Key trials (STRIVE & TERRAIN) are progressing steadily - Both trials are evaluating enzalutamide's effects on PFS when compared head-to-head versus bicalutamide
o TERRAIN is enrolling approximately 370 men with metastatic disease primarily in Europe (run by Asteallas)
o STRIVE is enrolling approximately 400 men with either metastatic or non-metastatic disease primarily in the U.S (run by Medivation)
- Still no firm date for data release on PREVAIL
o At the beginning of April, Medivation exceeded the protocol-specified number of radiographic PFS events required for the final analysis of the study and they plan to conduct an interim overall survival analysis this year
- With regards to the new trial announced in the M0 setting, Medivation intend to have this up and running with patients onborded this year
o “We do intend to dose this year. As you know, it’s a Phase 3 trial; it’s large and there are a lot of logistics to get the study up and going from an operational standpoint. We’re making great progress on that, and Medivation will be operationalizing this study. So we are very confident that we’ll be getting it up in a timely fashion” - Lynn Seely
ASCO data release:
o “We have three abstracts that are going to be presented at ASCO. We have more data from the oral – the hormone-naïve monotherapy study that Matt Smith will be presenting. We have some data on men with visceral metastases from the AFFIRM trial and then we have a presentation on docetaxel enzalutamide combination study…” - Lynn Seely
Source: Medivation

item.title: Accelerated Approval Pathway Potential for Sarepta's DMD Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sarepta reported chances looked good the FDA would consider the company's eteplirsen under an accelerated approval pathway. It is finalizing a response to the agency's request for more data to help determine the feasibility of such a pathway, with expectations of submitting documents by the end of May.
Leerink Swann analyst pointed out that :
- it remains unclear, however, whether the FDA would require Sarepta to complete an additional pivotal trial before accepting an eteplirsen NDA, which could make the drug second to market in exon-51 DMD in the US.
- individual patient data for eteplirsen demonstrated fairly consistent six-minute walk test (6MWT) response, with all 10 patients who remained ambulant and received drug at some point during weeks 36 through 74 demonstrated a less than 10% change in their scores.
With the eteplirsen Phase II trial unblinded at 36 weeks and all patients were made aware they were on drug, the FDA could require Sarepta to execute a pre-approval placebo-controlled trial.
http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results/displayOpt?flds=a&flds=b&flds=f&flds=c&flds=n&flds=o&submit_fld_opt=on&term=eteplirsen&show_flds=Y

item.title: Key Messages from Dendreon 1Q:13 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company reported Provenge revenue was $67.6 million compared to $82.0 million for the quarter ended March 31, 2012, down 17.6% year over year. Management outlined it is actively evaluating partnering strategies for European expansion. Analysts at Barclays forecast EU approval of the vaccine delayed from mid-2013 to 2H13.
" ... We are incrementally more concerned about the European approval given that the questions from the European authorities involved both manufacturing and the clinical data. In our opinion, this casts greater doubt on the approval prospect of Provenge in Europe, especially in the context of the high price tag of the regimen".
PROVENGE and ADT sequencing study > presented initial data at ASCO-GU and expect to present additional data in 2013.
PROVENGE and Zytiga® (abiraterone) sequencing study > presented initial data at ASCO-GU and expect to present additional data in 2013.

Ph2 trial for sequencing PROVENGE with Xtandi® (enzalutamide) >expect to begin enrolling patients in 4Q:13.

Continued new physician interest in PROVENGE® (sipuleucel-T):
  • Added 33 net new accounts in the first quarter, bringing total number of accounts that have infused to 835

Demonstrated positive early indicators in effectiveness of direct-to-consumer advertising:

  • Addresses significant need for patient education and awareness
  • First national TV commercial aired March 7
  • Patients contacting Dendreon directly for more information, resulting in a significant increase in call center and relationship marketing activity

Continued improvement in reimbursement landscape for physicians:

  • Reported average time to payment remains less than 30 days for physicians

Continued progress with strategic restructuring:

  • The Company believes it can reduce cost of goods sold (COGS) to below 50% of net product revenue in the third quarter 2013 at its current forecast levels

Source: Dendreon; Barclays

item.title: Aileron Therapeutics Successfully Completes First-Ever Stapled Peptide Clinical Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ALRN-5281 Phase 1 data could support once-weekly dosing, potentially providing a convenience over currently available GH and GHRH injections
Aileron Therapeutics announced the completion of the first-in-human study of its lead Stapled Peptide drug, ALRN-5281, a proprietary, long-acting GHRH agonist for treating orphan endocrine disorders, including adult growth hormone deficiency and human immunodeficiency virus lipodystrophy, as well as broader patient populations involving a wide variety of metabolic/endocrine diseases.
The initial Phase 1 trial evaluated the safety and tolerability of single ascending doses of ALRN-5281 administered by subcutaneous injection in healthy adult subjects:
  • 32 patients
  • no serious adverse events, dose-limiting safety findings, or tolerability issues leading to withdrawal during the study
  • data supports once-weekly dosing

item.title: Teva Believes to be Better Suited Than Competitors to Serve the Chinese Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a telephone interview, Teva CEO reported generic drugs, OTC and respiratory treatments represent the three growth drivers for the company.
He added:
" ... Our portfolio more closely matches the needs of that nation than nearly any other company in the world".
" ... The need for cheap generic drugs in the nation with the world's largest population - many from poor, rural areas - certainly plays into Teva's strengths as the No. 1 maker of generics. And Teva's specialty medicines, with a focus in part on respiratory treatments, could also become critical to a nation battling illness from industrial air pollution".
Source: ThomsonOne

item.title: Sativex Reimbursed for Spasticity due to MS in Italy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sativex has been granted approval for reimbursement in Italy to relieve symptoms in adult patients suffering from moderate-to-severe spasticity due to multiple sclerosis who have not had an adequate response to other anti-spasticity medication and who have shown a clinically significant improvement of symptoms associated with spasticity during an initial trial period of therapy.
The decision was published on the Italian official gazette on 30 April. The drug has been assigned classification H status which indicates drugs that are only reimbursed within hospitals or equivalent structures.
The maximum price approved in the provision is EUR440.00 (ex-manufacturer) and EUR726.18 (retail). The contract between the manufacturer and the Italian agency is valid for 24 months and, according to the conditions negotiated by the parties, is subject to a cost-sharing agreement.
Source: Global Insight

item.title: Russia 2012 Pharma Market Grew 11.6% From Last Year According to Remedium.ru
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : in 2012 Russia's DLO market increases 3% in value terms while Commercial segment grew by 14.7%.
As reported by Remedium.ru :
  • Russia DLO market, the GVT reimbursement programme, has reported a 3% year-on-year increase in 2012, in value to RUB79,950 billion (USD2.52 billion). In USD terms the value however declined 3% y/y.The volume of this segment of the market remained almost flat (0.3% y/y increase). The price per unit of package had decreased to USD27.61 from USD28.5 in 2012. The share of the top 10 companies (including , J&J, Novartis & Sanofi) amounted to 63% on this segment.
  • The Commercial segment on its side, grew by 14.7% y/y in value terms to RUB536.6 billion (USD17.8 bn).
  • In terms of Hospital segment, the value of the market increased 11% y/y to RUB157.2 billion (USD 5.21 bn) but declined by 2% y/y in volume terms.
In 2012 the Russian market was valued USD 25.5bn growing 11,6% from USD 22.8bn and is split into DLO (11%) / Commercial Segment (69%) and Hospital Segment (20%).
Background: The DLO, which includes two lists the Essential Drugs List and the 7 Nosologies (priority therapeutic areas), is the national reimbursement programme, the beneficiaries of which are entitled to 100% reimbursement. The final price level for the DLO drugs to be supplied by a manufacturer is determined during auctions held by the GVT and Region authorities (regional tendering programmes).
Source : Remedium.ru and DMS Group

item.title: Key Messages from Prostate Cancer Survey
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: MEDACorp conducted a survey of 50 US urologists and oncologists (25 in each specialty) with a majority of them practicing in the community setting. The survey suggests significant use of Xtandi in the pre-chemo setting already and a near-term sales trajectory that appears to be ahead of expectations. For Provenge, the survey suggests declining use since the end of 2012. Companies highlighted are Dendreon, J&J, and Medivation.
In order to get a respondent cohort that is experienced in treating CRPC, physicians had to treat at least 30 metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer patients personally over the past 12 months.
The survey respondents are composed of 14 physicians (28%) from the academic medical centers, 6 physicians (12%) from community hospitals, 1 physician (2%) from a VA hospital, 27 physicians (54%) from private practice and 2 physicians (4%) from a clinic.
The survey was fielded and followed up from April 5 to April 29, 2013.
- A little over half of current Xtandi patients had previously received Zytiga, although this differed significantly between oncologists and urologists
- Survey finds a substantial increase of Zytiga and Xtandi of 41% and 80%, respectively, from Dec. 2012 to March 2013
- Majority of survey respondents consider the efficacy and safety/ tolerability profiles of Zytiga and Xtandi to be similar in the postchemo setting

item.title: European Regulator to Begin Reorganisation in August
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : The European Medicines Agency (EMA) on Friday announced it will begin to introduce a new organisational structure from August onwards. The new structure will take 18 months to implement to ensure continuity of operations.
Details of the structure will be published in the coming months, but the EMA said high-level changes will involve replacing two units dealing with medicines for human use.
They will be replaced by four units, supporting the R&D phase, medicines evaluation and lifecycle management, procedure management and business data and inspections and pharmacovigilance.
Current entities responsible for veterinary medicines, ICT and administration will remain, although their names may change.
Staff members, chairs of the scientific committees and heads of national medicines agencies have been involved in the rethink of the structure, according to the statement.
Rationale
The EMA said the changes will reflect the fact that it increasingly acts as a knowledge and data hub, sharing information with different stakeholders.
The agency originally announced the change to the structure earlier this year. EMA executive director Guido Rasi said the changes would improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the organisation.
Source : APM International, May 3.

item.title: Novartis Names Head of M&A and Licensing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Anthony Rosenberg is promoted head of M&A and Licensing from Head of BD & Licensing.
He will be replaced by Corinne Savill, who is head of Pricing & Market Access at Novartis.
Mr. Rosenberg is Head of Business Development and Licensing of Novartis Pharma AG and a member of the Pharma Executive Committee.
He joined Sandoz in 1980 in the UK where he held various leadership positions in sales and marketing, business development and strategic planning. In 1994 he moved to Basel, initially as international product manager (Clozaril), and undertook roles of increasing responsibility in Global Marketing, ultimately as Head Global Marketing Primary Care. In 2000 he became Global Head of the Transplant and Immunology Business Unit and began his current role in 2005. He has overseen several major in-licensing transactions in the respiratory, infectious disease, CNS areas.
Rosenberg has a BSc (Biological Sciences) University of Leicester, and an M.Sc (Physiology) University of London

item.title: Ambrx Initiates Collaboration with BMS for Next-Generation Antibody Drug Conjugates
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The collaboration covers the discovery and development of novel antibody drug conjugates using Ambrx's protein medicinal chemistry technology.
Ambrx will receive an upfront payment of $15 million, funding for discovery and research activities, and potential development, regulatory and sales based milestone payments of up to $97 million per product resulting from the collaboration.
BMS will receive WW rights to develop and commercialize products resulting from the collaboration, and Ambrx is eligible to receive royalties on net sales.
With BMS > The deal is also the second between Ambrx and BMS. In 2011, Ambrx granted BMS exclusive, worldwide rights to develop and commercialize preclinical biologics programs in Type II diabetes and heart failure.
- With Astellas > See Oncology8884: Astellas and Ambrx Have Signed Oncology Deal Worth >$300M.
Source: Ambrx

item.title: Versartis Published Positive Study Results of LA hGH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : Versartis pulished positive results from its first double-blind, placebo-controlled, single ascending dose study of VRS-317 in growth hormone deficient adults. VRS-317 is expected to provide up to once-monthly dosing when at present, the approved growth hormone treatments require daily injections.
VRS-317 is a long-acting form of recombinant human growth hormone (rhGH) utilizing the proprietary Amunix half-life extension technology (XTEN). The multi-center study of VRS-317 was conducted in 50 adults with growth hormone deficiency (GHD).
Versartis is now investigating the safety and efficacy of VRS-317 in a Phase 1b/2a clinical trial in pre-pubertal children with GHD. The Versartis Trial In Children to Assess Long-Acting Growth Hormone (VERTICAL) study is being conducted in approximately 30 clinical sites in the United States.
Source : ahead of print article on April 12, 2013 in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism (JCEM) [doi:10.1210/jc.2013-1437]
http://jcem.endojournals.org/content/early/2013/04/11/jc.2013-1437.full.pdf+html?sid=bcbbe57a-f134-4a09-9d86-e67202c50f00

item.title: Acorda Reports 1Q:13 and Pipeline Progress
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AMPYRA net sales were $62.3M (down from 4Q:12 of $72.7M). Management reported it plans to continue the POC trial in post-stroke deficits. First participant was enrolled in the first Ph1 trial of rHIgM22, a remyelinating antibody for MS. The company is preparing to initiate a Phase 2 trial of AC105 for neural protection in acute spinal cord injury.
Management answered that " ... So, we will meet with FDA when we have finished our analyses and have a plan that we want to propose to them, and obviously we're working on that as quickly as possible. This is a very high priority program, needless to say, for us. With respect to what we're thinking about, again, I don't want to speculate on that until we've actually put a plan together, gotten in front of the FDA and then have something to say about it.
According to Management " ... The efficacy results of the cerebral palsy study suggested potential treatment activity on measures of walking and hand strength, but further analysis is needed to determine if they are sufficiently robust to warrant moving forward with development in this indication. Similar to the post-stroke deficit study, the safety data from this study were consistent with our experience in MS".

item.title: EMA Hopes To Clarify Biosimilar Reference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: EMA has published a draft guidance on biosimilars that use a reference product approved outside the EU
The guidance states that sponsors who use a reference product approved outside the EU must provide data from analytical studies showing an "acceptable bridge" between the biosimilar, the non-EU reference product and the EU-approved originator reference product.
The guidance also outlines general principles for developing biosimilars in the EU.
This document will eventually replace the 2005 guidance and comments are due on October 31st 2013. At this stage, it is still not a ‘black and white’ documents as there are some questions around what the EMA will consider "similarity" or what constitutes a "significant difference" between a biosimilar and reference product.
Please see link for more info - http://www.ema.europa.eu/docs/en_GB/document_library/Scientific_guideline/2013/05/WC500142978.pdf

item.title: Lexicon on Track with Ph3 Development Programme of LX1032 in Carcinoid Syndrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lexicon presented at the Needham 12th Annual Healthcare Conference in New York yesterday, focusing mainly on the ph3 lead programmes including their two diabetes compounds as well as LX1032 in Carcinoid Syndrome (CS).
The slide below provides the status of their pipeline.
Outlining the current and future CS market, stating that the majority of players are SSA’s and injectables whereas LX1032 is oral and a TPH inhibitor.
  • NOTE: Pasireotide has been omitted from this slide due to NVS apparently no longer pursuing approval for CS.
He then went on to discuss the EU Ph2 12 wk open label results which were presented at ENETS, a reminder of the data are found below:
  • Greater than 40% reduction in bowel movements (primary endpoint which was achieved and have also seen a sustained effect)
  • 70% decrease in 5-HIAA
  • 36.6% reduction in flushing episodes
  • 18.4% reduction in pain
Finishing up with an overview of the hP3 trial details. Trial is ramping up, on track and they are on boarding the sites currently.

item.title: New Registration and New Packaging for Botox Therapeutic
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to our colleagues P. Caglioni (PM) and M. de Abadal (MD), we have learnt that Botox 200 will be sold in Italy with a new packaging (1-2-3 or 6 vials), and that the reimbursement authority in Australia has granted listing for Botox 100 for urinary incontinence due to NDO in patients with MS, SCI or adult spina bifia.
- In Italy, Allergan has asked the 100% reimbursement for the pack (1 vial), but the MOH has assigned any reimbursement (class C), probably because any agreement was reached on the price among Allergan and AIFA. As for Hexvix, if the pharmacist decide to by 200U Botox the amount has to be charged on Hospital budget and not reimbursed by MHO.
In Australia, no information about the price yet.

item.title: Allergan Management Discuss 1Q:13 Performance
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan sales grew vs the first quarter of 2012 by 9.0% (lc)) and by 8.4% (in US dollars). D. Pyott reported 'very strong growth in the US' of Botox therapeutic, thanks to the uptake in chronic migraine, to the uro indications (in Q1, the neurogenic bladder indication was launched in the UK and idiopathic in Germany), and also sound growth in the traditional movement disorder areas'.
Migraine indication was reported as being 'a big driver', and urology as second driver for growth.
Sales in Q1 grew year-over-year 15.4% (lc) and 14.8% in dollars, with double-digit growth in both the therapeutic and aesthetic franchises. "Regarding the global market in Q4, the last period for which we have data available, we estimate that growth was 14%, with Allergan outperforming the market at 16%. Accordingly, BOTOX market share moved up to 78% from 76% in Q4 of 2011".
Urology Side
"we’re obviously at an earlier stage of adoption and also training for the newest idiopathic overactive bladder indication where we received approval from FDA in January. Since approval of neurogenic overactive bladder, we have now trained over 2,400 unique urologists in a target universe of 5,500 urologists and urologist gynecologists. Insurance coverage of neurogenic is excellent at 100% of Medicare lives and at 88% of commercial lives".
Aesthetic Side
In the US, based on survey data, Allergan believe that the neuromodulator market is growing high single digits and that BOTOX share was at 82% in March, an increase of 5 share points versus a year earlier given that this was before the injunction issued against Merz.
Xeomin share in March was estimated at 5% and Dysport share dropped to 13% from 16% in March of 2012.
Facial Aesthetic
" ... Facial aesthetics enjoyed extremely robust growth of 32.9% (lc) and almost the same in dollars at 32.6%, with very strong increases in all operating regions of the world. Whilst market growth is strong, a few factors flatter the year-over-year ex-factory increases. U.S. ex-factory sales were affected by the buy-in against the 3% JUVÉDERM price increase posted on March 16, the sell-in of our Proven Results rebate promotion in combination with BOTOX, as well as the low quarter in 2012, which was a period between two of the then-promotions called Duet Dividends. Hence, you should expect moderate year-over-year growth in Q2 of this year.
(Sources: IMS as well as Allergan’s internal estimates).
The top ten markets for neuromodulators are roughly $1.9 billion, growing at a rate of roughly 15% and BOTOX has approximately an 85% market share.
The worldwide market for neuromodulators is roughly $2.5 billion, growing at a rate of roughly 13% and BOTOX has approximately a 77% market share.
The worldwide market for dermal facial fillers is greater than $1 billion, growing at a rate of roughly 6% and Allergan has approximately a 37% market share.
DARPin "Allergan has completed the initial analyses for the second stage of the randomized controlled Phase II trial comparing two doses of the anti-VEGF DARPin and ranibizumab, i.e. Lucentis. The data suggests some product differentiation between the DARPin and Lucentis, but do not support directly moving to Phase III. Instead we plan to perform additional Phase II work to more completely access safety and efficacy and to guide the Phase III study design. This will likely delay eventual approval by approximately one to two years compared to starting a Phase III program by the end of 2013. As previously communicated, data from this Phase II trial will be presented at the American Academy of Ophthalmology Retina Subspecialty Day in November".
bimatoprost scalp hair growth " ... the results of the Phase II trial in male and female hair loss indicated that the formulation was well tolerated but did not provide sufficient efficacy to proceed directly to Phase III. As a consequence, we are extending the Phase II program to include trials with an approximately 10-fold higher concentration of bimatoprost in the current formulation and also in a novel formulation. These trials will start enrolling male patients with androgenic alopecia in the third quarter of 2013".
Highlights of Key Points During Q&A Session (five corporate participants from Allergan side)
Questionned on the aesthetic business, Management answered that '... If I look at the neuromodulator market, I think we’re in a very sound position. As I stated in the US, we estimate that market growth is upper single digits. Then in terms of market share, a very good position. Xeomin is coming up slower than it did in the past. I think Dysport is dipping a little bit on the other side. So obviously where there’s two competitors versus one, one would normally expect some share loss, but so far quite moderate'.
